Each card contains a fact and number of questions on a common theme. Answer correctly and score a point. The player with the most points wins.

Several other rules are proposed including soloplay rules.

name: Five Worker's Morris
description:
This is an abstract game with two boards. The action board is a 2X2 square grid with four actions (Place, Place, Move, Remove) in the spaces. The network board is also a 2x2 square grid but the pieces are placed on the 9 vertices of the grid.

Each player has five workers that use to take actions and/or place on the network board. Each turn a player has two actions per turn (except for the first player on the first turn who only has one action). To take an action a player takes one of their own workers from their supply and places it in an empty space on the action board and resolve the action accordingly. Instead of taking an action they may they may pass on one of their available actions - if they do so they must remove one of their workers from the action board (if they have any).

The three types of action on the action boards are:
Place: Place one of the activating workers in the Network board. Take the worker from either the General Supply or the "Place" Space just activated.
Move: Move either player's worker on the Network Board to an adjacent vertice or move either player's worker on the Action board to an adjacent space (do not activate the action under the moved worker).
Remove: Remove either player's worker from either the Network Board or the Action Board. The worker is returned to the player's general supply.

The game ends immediately when a player has three workers in a row on the Network Board.
mechanics: Action Points, Grid Movement, Point to Point Movement, Worker Placement

name: Ország, város, híres ember
description: Hungarian trivia game. Random draw a letter to different categories (country, city, famous man) each round. The players try to write things with beginning the suitable letters. What somebody else did not write is worth one point. The player collect the most points is the winner.

name: Zauberdomino
description:
A domino variant that uses dice as well as the domino cards. Of course, the cards can be used for a standard game of dominoes except that they feature an image on half the card and letters on the other half. You match a correct initial letter to an image (M next to Moon for example or vice versa). The game is housed in an attractive tin box.

Other games are included that bring in to play the special dice. One dice is what wargamers would call a Fire Die. It has 1 x two on it, 2 x two on it and 3 times two.The other die has letters on each face, four letters or five letters. And sometimes they use the wooden Wizard figure that is included with the game.

In game 1,2,3 - Magic! each player gets a hand of five cards and 12 cards are laid out in a circle, like a clock. However, a clock with 24 divisions because the cards are laid end-on thus forming a chequered track, picture, letter, picture, and so on. The Wizard is placed on one of them. The number die is used in this game. In your turn, you roll the die and advance the Wizard that number of spaces. When he has moved and lands on a picture space, the player looks at the picture and sees if he can think of a word that describes the picture. If he can then he must check his hand and see if the word he wants to use begins with one of the letters in his hand. If he does have such a card he can return that card to the box. If the Wizard lands on a letter space the reverse applies. The player looks to see if he has a picture card that begins with the letter. The first to use up all their cards, wins.

In Enchanting Fairy, the letter die is used. Each gets a hand of cards. The Wizard is placed in the centre of the table comfortably in reach of all the players. The die is roilled and all the players look to see if they have a picture beginning with one of the letters face-up on the die. If they do think they have the right answer, they can grab for the Wizard. Whoever gets it first (several players might grab for it at the same time), announces his answer and, if correct, returns his card to the box. If he is wrong he must draw another card from the shuffled deck.The first to use all their cards, wins.

Interesting additional fact. HABA add the usual disclaimer that the game is not suitable for under threes as some components could be swallowed. Nothing unusual in that except they write it in 40 languages!!

name: Sands 500
description:
Sands 500 is a motor racing game for 2-6 players. The object of the game is to be the first player to have their racing car cross the finish line after an agreed upon number of laps of the circuit.

To begin the game the first player to spin a four on the Spinner goes first and has their choice of which coloured lane to place their racing car. Then the player to the left has their choice of lane and so on until all players have had a lane allocated.

The player who goes first spins the Spinner and whoever has a racing car on the same lane as the colour indicated by the dial moves the number of spaces shown in that segment. The leader can then change lanes to whatever colour they think will come up next. After the leader has chosen a lane the next player in position order can do likewise (it is permissible to have two or more racing cars in the same lane).

The game progresses with each player following the direction of course until the leader crosses the finish line either by a 'flying finish' (crossing the line on any number) or finishes on exactly the right number as decided before the start of the game.

Contents:

1x Board
1x Spinner with rules
4x Racing cars (one each of red, blue, green and yellow)

name: So zählen und rechnen wir gern
description:
East German educational game to help youngsters with their numbers and counting. Based on picture lotto, each player gets a player-card with 10 spaces to fill.The spaces are numbered 1 to 10 but not in order so that the player must count to know where to place a card. Each player-card has a different illustration. The illustration is important because only cards that match that illustration are eligible to be placed on the player-card.

The first player to fill their player-card, wins.

name: Flori Colori
description:
A cooperative die rolling game for toddlers that trains recognition and matching of basic colours as well as turn-taking.

The board shows 16 flower spaces and a track consisting of 7 butterfly spaces. Players take turns rolling the die. If it shows the flower symbol, the active player places one of the wooden flower chips on an empty flower space of the same colour on the board. If the butterfly symbol is rolled, the active player advances the butterfly token one space.

If all the flowers have been placed before the butterfly reaches the end of the track, the players win together. If the butterfly reaches the last space on its track before all the flowers have been placed, the butterfly wins instead.

name: Pirates' Gold
description: Players take turns moving around the board, trying to reach the island listed on their map cards. When they reach the appointed island, they collect tokens that can either be treasure or trash. Once they return to port those tokens are revealed. If they are treasure, they go on the player's treasure chest; if they are garbage, they get discarded. Battles between players and a random pirate allow for treasures to exchange hands during the game. Players continue taking turns until one player collects six coin treasures and returns to port.

name: How Low Can You Go? Card Game
description:
The object of the game is to have the lowest set of 4 cards when all 4 cards are added together. Play your way victory using memory, strategy, and nerve in How Low Can You Go? card game. Each player receives 4 cards and lays out his cards face down in a row and peeks at 2 of his cards only. These are the “seen” cards. The other 2 cards must remain face down. These are the “unseen” cards, which may become “seen” cards at some point in the game. Players draw from the draw pile and keep or swap cards with the intention of making a set of 4 cards that, when added together, are lower than any other player’s hand. Players will need to use their adding and subtracting skills as they try to get the lowest hand on the table. 'Do The Hustle' cards will give you the chance to trade cards with another player. 'Bust-A-Move' cards result in a number of particular rules.

Contents: 48 sturdy full color cards and instructions.

name: The Dandy and Beano Card Game
description:
Promotional game made for Cadbury's, the British chocolate manufacturers. The game is a mix of traditional games like Crazy Eights and Beat Your Neighbour. It utilises characters from Britain's two most popular comics, The Dandy and The Beano.

The Object of the Game: To be the first player to get rid of all their cards.

1. Shuffle the cards and deal five to each player face down. The remaining cards are placed face down.
This is the draw pile. Turn over the top card and place it adjacent to the draw pile. This is the start of the discard pile.
2. Choose a starting player, play follows in a clockwise direction.
3. The starting player chooses one of their cards and places it face up onto the discard pile. Each card shows a Dandy or Beano character inside a coloured border. The chosen card must show either the same character or the same coloured border as the one below it in the pile. Play then passes to the next player.
4. Any player who is unable to play a card on their turn must take the top card from the draw pile and add it to their hand. Play then passes to the next player.
5. When a Roger the Dodger cord is played, the following player must pick up two cards from the draw pile and add them to their hand. Play then passes to the next player. However, a player does not have to pick up two cards if they can also play a Roger the Dodger card on top. In this case, the next player must pick up two cards instead. Play then passes to the next player.
6. When a Desperate Dan card is played, the following player must miss a turn.
7. If the draw pile runs out, the discard pile is shuffled and turned face down. The top card is then turned over to restart as in '3'.
8. The first player to get rid of all their cards is the winner.
categories: Card Game, Children's Game, Comic Book / Strip

name: Malifaux: Gaki
description:
Minion for the Resurrectionists. Its natural leader is Kirai.

From the Malifaux Tactica Wiki:

Gaki are pack hunters. With enough numbers they can consume even human-sized targets with notable ease, making them very dangerous. While they are Graverobbers they are selfish with the corpse counters they collect. Indeed Gaki can consume their own allies to act faster. While employable by any Resurectionist Master, they very much enjoy the company and commands of Kirai who lets them enjoy the corpses she ignores as she enslaves the escaping souls of her victims. Under the command and within the close presence of Kirai, Gaki become even more savage then when ripping their foes apart with their sizable maw

While a Gaki will eat near anything, they love living flesh over anything else and will frequently move with more passion to consume a beating heart.

Gaki work well with most Resurrectionist masters, provided they come as a group (as mentioned, 4 Gaki will only cost you 12-stones). With Kirai however they get a few extra perks.

Kirai can cast "Spirit Food" on living or undead enemy models. If the model affected is killed, a new Gaki will be summoned (with Slow for that turn). This can add to the Gaki's growing numbers and increase their pack-size. However the model MUST be killed and not sacrificed (i.e.: not Devoured or Absorbed by the Gaki) for a new Gaki to appear.

Gaki within 6" of Kirai increase their damage potential to 3/3/5 (two successful Gorges from a Feeding Frenzy will do anywhere between 6-10 damage in Kirai's presence!)

Gaki killed within 8" of Kirai produce Seishin, which Kirai can evolve back into Gaki by spending (1) AP and losing -1 Wound (or -2 Wounds with her trigger if she would like to Summon the Gaki 12" away from herself - possibly beside an enemy who is already in Melee with another Gaki; creating potential for a retaliatory Feeding Frenzy).

As Spirits, Gaki offer Kirai a place to teleport to. As Gaki can move 10" each turn (14" if they can see a living model in the Start Closing Phase), they are quite swift and can offer escape locations for Kirai to teleport to.

name: Het kan vriezen, het kan dooien
description:
Translation from Dutch: Freezing, thawning.

This game is a variant on Memory. Players flip over two cards. If those cards both have the same picture, then you may move you pawn a number of spaces like indicated on the cards. After turning over a duo of cards, put a token on one of the cards. This card cannot be turned over again until the token is removed.

A player wins if his pawn reaches the end space first. It takes about 20 squares to reach finish.

name: Travel Trivia: Birds & Beasts
description:
Game One
Two or more players. One question master.
Object of the Game The winning player is the first to win an agreed number of cards by correctly answering one question per card.
Gameplay: The question master holds the pack of cards question side up, the first player selects any question from 1 to 6 on the card held by the question master If he answers correctly that card is awarded (and is retained question aide up to avoid looking at the answers for future games). If the question is either not answered or answered incorrectly, then any other player with the right answer Is similarly rewarded with that card. If no player answers correctiy. the question master replaces that card to the bottom of the pack. The game continues with each player in turn until one player wins the agreed number ot cards.
Variation
If there is a spread of ages and abilities, give every one a chance by giving greater rewards to younger players. Try — Ages 8 to 11 three cards per answer; Ages 11 to 14 two cards per answer; Ages 14+ one card per answer.
Game Two for Two Players
Object of the Game: The winning player is the first to win an agreed number of cards by correctly answering, according to age and ability, a minimum number of questions per card.
Gameplay: The first pfayer is question master and asks the second player questions from the top card of the pack which is placed question side up. The card is won by answering enough questions correctly. Ages 8-11 score 2/6 to win; Ages 11*14 score 3/6 to win; Ages 14 + score 4/6 to win. When all the questions on a card have
been asked or the card won, the second player becomes question master for the next card. Play continues until one player wins the agreed number of cards.
Game Three
Two or more players. One question master/scorer. Score pad + pencil required.
Object of the Game: The winner is the player scoring the most points over an agreed number of rounds.
Gameplay: Question master asks each player in turn a question. If the player answers correctly two points are awarded, failure to answer or incorrect answer, allows the other players to answer for one point. The first player to do this correctly is awarded the point. However, if different ages and abilities are participating the rewards for correct answers may vary.

If you have collected several Travel Trivia Games set a different subject for each round.

name: Füdlibürger. Das Schweizer Schimpfwortspiel
description:
Memory-style game to build swiss-german swearwords out of pairs. Just for the fun of learning or revisiting swiss dialect words.

The game plays exactly like memory. One word ist the first half of the full word, one the second (1:1 match). To avoid unclarities, the matching parts have the same color - wrong combinations result in funny new creations, adding to the fun.The cards contain also an explanation what the resulting words actually mean (for those that did not know the word before).

It's mainly a fun party game leading to dicussions about local dialects.

name: Shuffled Symphonies
description:
Card game with 45 cards that feature many of the Disney characters.

Deal out all the cards. Each player places their cards, without looking at them, in a stack in front of themselves. The first player turns over a card and places it in the middle of the table. The next follows, and so on. If a 'Value' card is so placed, the next player must add that number of cards to the central pile. The game continues in this way and if you are out of cards you are also out of the round. The round ends when one player has all the cards.

There is a Big Bad Wolf card and if this is revealed, the player must give four cards to any other that shouts "Wolf!" first.

At the end of each round of play, the player winning the round gets 1 point for every other player in the game. First to get 12 points or more, wins.

List of cards:
Value 3 = Elmar Elephant, Pluto
Value 2 = Three Little Pigs, Dopey Horace Horsecollar
Value 1 = Snow White, Mickey Mouse, Donald Duck
No value cards
Ambrose Kitten, Max Hare, Clara Cluck, Goofy
Tilly Tiger, Minnie Mouse, The Twins, Toby Tortoise
Dirty Bill, Clarabelle, Pied Piper, Donna Duck
Country Cousin, 3 Little Wolves
Special Penalty card
Big Bad Wolf
There are two of each card except the only Big Bad Wolf card.
categories: Card Game, Children's Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Charlie und Lola: Verstecken
description:
A memory game based on the children's book and animated TV series "Charlie and Lola".

The game board shows a bedroom on one side and a living room on the other side. The players decide which side they want to use. There is also a smaller board that is divided into four sections (blue, red, green and yellow). Each of these sections shows 4 different objects - mostly toys but also a hairbrush, pencils and a telephone. There are 16 cardboard chips that show the same 16 objects.

The game is divided into two phases:

Phase 1: Players take turns "hiding" the objects on the board: they take a chip, say where they are hiding it (e.g. "I'm hiding the football under the bed) and place it in the corresponding section of the board. Once all objects have been placed on the board, the players try to memorise which object is where. Then the chips are turned face-down.

Phase 2: Players then take turns rolling the colour die. If you roll red, you have to find one of the four objects from the red section of the smaller board. If you find a correct object, you get to keep the chip.
The game ends when all objects have been found. The player with the most chips wins the game.
categories: Children's Game, Memory, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Sqworm
description:
This is a preschool game suitable for small children BUT there are enough interesting tactics to make this a viable game for older children or adults.

Players roll two dice each turn. The first one determines which color worm to move (half of the dice sides permit you to choose a color) the second shows how many spaces to move. If you manage to completely surround an apple on the board you keep it. Play continues until all 19 apples are gone and the player with the most apples wins.

This is not a simple roll and move game. Children will enjoy moving the worms to get apples but there are always a few decisions regarding what path to take each turn. At a somewhat more advanced level there are decisions to make to limit your opponents choices and scoring opportunities each turn and potentially maximize your own.

name: Monster-Alarm
description:
The Monsters are loose. Catch them again, but be aware of who you take on. And wich monster will join you in your fight at the end?

Players have 2 piles with cards face up. On your turn you play one of these 2 top cards. You add your card to the row with the same color as your card. Jokers can be played as any color.

When there are 4 cards in a row you have to take that row.
Red and Blue rows score negative point, Yellow and Green rows score positive points.

The trick is to not only look at your own cards but also what the other players will be able to play their next turn.

Content: 104 playing cards, Rules.

name: Malifaux: Shikome
description:
From the Malifaux Tactica wiki site:

These Rare spirits are very deadly. Seldom alone, often hunting in pairs, and never found it great numbers (Rare 2), they are monsters to be feared. Once they have chosen their prey, they are relentless and single-minded in agenda to slay their prey. Incredibly fast, and viciously savage, they are frequently found in the forces commanded by Kirai.

Shikome are pretty straight forward. If on the board, their first priority is to kill their Prey! This can be any enemy model that is in play, and indeed a pair of Shikome may opt to hunt the same target.

"(0) Hunting Partner" only affects friendly Beasts, but it does give them the advantage of fast, and a plus flip to hit and damage against the Shikomes prey. Within the resurrectionist faction this only applies to Rogue Necromancy, Night Terrors and another Shikome. It is worth using on another shikome with the same prey as it adds another positive modifier to the attack and damage flips.
The bonus from the Hunting Partner will last until the closing phase.
Don't assume that Shikome need to kill their prey. They don't necessarily want the kill - they just want their chosen victim dead (by their hand or another). If your other forces can remove the target, go for it. There won't be a penalty and by doing this your Shikome will be free to attack whomever they want.

Don't assume Shikome must go towards their prey. While they may only be able to attack that specified model, they don't have to make it a priority (although while the victim lives the Shikome is limited in what it can do). You can choose to take a long route to get to the foe if you want, as it may be safer for the Shikome to do so (they are hardy, but not indestructible).

"(1) Stalk Prey" only works if you activate it prior to the Prey's activation and only occurs if they take a move action.

Once the Shikome has killed their Prey (or have just be summoned) they can skip their turn to declare themselves hunting "(all) New Prey". It depends on your style of play, but its usually not that recommended as giving up a turn to just say "I'm coming for you and only you" can be quite wasteful as in that same turn you could have your Shikome move to attack any model in charge range. However, this taunt can be useful - especially if you want to get rid of a target that is on the opposite side of the board (using "(1) Stalk Prey" can quickly make up for the turn you used up selecting "(all) New Prey")
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Horror, Miniatures

name: Verflixt gemixt!
description:
A card game for children in which players try to find shared characteristics between items.

The 38 word cards are printed on both sides. One sides shows just a picture, the other shows a picture plus the corresponding word. The picture-only side is used when playing with younger players who can't read that well yet. With other players both sides can be used.

The cards are shuffled and divided into three stacks. Players turn over the top card from each of the stacks. Players then simultaneously search for a characteristic that two of the three items shown on the cards share. A player who thinks to have found such a characteristic slaps the stop card and tells the other players his/her idea. If they accept it as correct, he/she wins the pair of cards and two new cards are turned over. If his/her idea isn't accepted, the game continues with the same three cards as before.
The shared characteristic has to be something both items have (not something they both don't have), and it has to something that hasn't been mentioned in a previous round, otherwise the first player to use that characteristic wins this pair too.

The game ends when all cards have been used. The player who has collected the most cards wins the game.
categories: Card Game, Children's Game, Word Game

name: Kroko-Kick
description:
A children's dexterity game for two players.

Components:
- two wooden crocodiles
- two ring-shaped nests
- one egg (a little ball that has a blue and a red half; it's not completely round so it always lands with either the blue or the red half up)

Aim of the game: Being the crocodile mommy who first succeeds in flicking the egg into her own nest. Or, if the game is played in multiple rounds, being the one with the most point (one point for each time the egg lands in our own nest).

Setup: Each player gets a crocodile and the nest of the same colour. The crocodiles are placed about 50 cm apart. The egg is placed in the middle, at equal distances from each of the nests.

Gamplay: The starting player places his/her crocodile next to the egg, so that the tail is very close to the egg. He/she then touches the crocodile's head and turns it so that the tail hits the egg and the egg starts rolling. If the egg stops moving with the same player's colour up, he/she gets another turn and flicks again. Otherwise it's the other player's turn now.

The game ends when the egg ends up in one of the nests. This player wins the game. (If players have agreed on playing multiple rounds, the game ends after the agreed-on number of rounds.)

Difficulty can be adjusted by putting the nests closer together.
The instructions also include suggestions for a few variants/other activities with the game materials:
- Which player needs the fewest attempts to get the egg into his/her nest?
- Which player can kick the egg more often with his/her own colour ending up on top?
- Which player can kick the egg the furthest in one go?
- Threads can be used to set a racing course. Which player gets the egg to the finish line with the fewest kicks without the egg leaving the racing course?

name: Helter-Skelter
description:
A party game intended for children.

The host 'hides' each Key Card in different locations around the area where the party is being held. The house or/and the garden would be most likely.

Each player is given a noun and must find that noun, written on the top left of one of the Key Cards. When found, it will say which noun to find next, and so on, until one player has found all 12 nouns in the correct order and written on their score-pad. That player is the winner.

The game is intended for up to 12 players but the publisher is rather optimistic in suggesting that if you buy extra cards (which he says are available at '12 for sixpence) then there is no reason why 500 people can't play. The publisher also suggests that you could play on a much wider area, with cards hidden so far apart, the players would need bicycles to get from one card to another.
categories: Children's Game, Party Game, Word Game

name: Kulla
description:
Game featured in the 1952 Dingbats' Annual.

The board features 4 separate tracks to the Home.

Each player gets 4 counters in their chosen colour and start from the same coloured corner. Throw a dice which shows the four colours. Move a piece on to the next same coloured square on your track. Instead of moving a piece already on the board, you may enter another of your counters on to the board.

If you roll your own colour you may advance one piece towards home and take another turn. Game proceeds in this manner until one player gets all four counters home. He or she is the winner.

name: Dice Age Alpha Edition: Blue Tide series
description:
Dice Age is a line of unbalanced, designer's toy dice! They are playing devices that can be used in different games, of skill, strategy, risk-taking), as divination device or as dominoes. Our players design new games and rules all the time.

Components: Dice (16 different dice in the Blue Tide series), Dice Pouch.
Unique Game Aspect: Unbalanced and artistic handmade dice that can be played in different ways.
categories: Abstract Strategy, Action / Dexterity, Dice, Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy
mechanics: Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Dice Rolling, Pattern Building, Push Your Luck, Variable Player Powers

name: Doodlebug
description:
Can you draw?
Roll the die and choose a subject from the cards, then simply lead your teammate to the correct answer using your creative skills!

name: Visit to the Zoo
description:
Game from 'The Children's Book of Games, Puzzles and Pastimes.

Simple roll and move game but does show a little originality where both players race on different tracks.

Rules: This is a game for two, using a die and two counters. The first to throw a six starts off in a taxi and tries to reach the Zoo before the other. One, representing John and Susan, goes via Westminster, and the other, representing Peter and Joan, goes via London Bridge. The traffic lights on the way alternately impede and help their advance.

name: King of the Mountain
description: Players each select a colored marble and take turns advancing spaces based on the roll of the die. Land on another player's marble and he or she must start all over at the bottom of the mountain. When landing on a designated chance space, players pick up a card and follow the instructions. Exact amount must be rolled to land on the top space. First to land on the top space is the winner and, until the next game, reigns KING OF THE MOUNTAIN.

name: Play Ultras
description:
After 40 years of passion, show and riots, during the last decade the law got very tough on football supporters, introducing prohibitions, cameras, more and more expensive tickets, etc…

The law triumphed, pay-TV became the new owners of the football leagues and the stadiums became again safe and peaceful.

All this process had a very bad impact on the stands, with more and more people who prefer stay at home watching football on the sofa rather than meeting friends on the stadium.

Only the more radicals dare going to watch his team playing away. With Play Ultras you can finally play with all these matters: leading your group of supporters towards the stadium facing policemen, opponent supporters, stupid laws and any kind of trouble. The first strategic game related to the “ultras” world by which you can finally play with your favourite group of supporters and collect them for life.

name: Medieval Monastery
description:
Medieval Monastery is a card game in which players are trying to collect sets of an eight suited deck of cards. The suits are all related to monestary life, such as Prayer, Study, Order, Monk, etc. Each suit is numbered 1-9. The goal of the game is to collect straights, 3/4/5/6/7/8 of a kinds, and flushes. Each is worth a certain amount of points. These are collected at each of the game's 10 turns.

Each turn is divided into four phases (Ascetic, Eremitical, Cenobitic, Salvation). The first is drawing a card, the second is the action phase, the third is the scoring, and the fourth is discarding all cards and starting fresh for the next turn. The actions of the second phase (Eremitical Phase) are determined by playing one card from your hand. Depending on the suit, you'll be able to draw new cards into your hand, trade cards with other players, or bid on cards drawn from the deck.

After ten turns the winner is the player with the most points.

name: The Roskilde Festival Dice Game
description: "The Roskilde Festival Dice Game" is not just one single game. It's several different games - all of them made by festival-goers. (From the Publisher) Rules for the included dice are available at www.Roskilde-festival.dk/dice Develop your own and add them to the collection!

name: Filly Elves: Die Reise zum magischen Baumpalast
description:
Roll and move for very young children. In the simple version, the players roll a color die and advance to the next field of that color. In the advanced version, the players can choose between that first option or doing a special action for each color (such as moving another pony piece backward, jumping over others to a certain position, change positions with any other pony, etc.).
The first player to cross the finish line is the winner.

name: Toss-Up
description:
This exciting, pleasure packed game of skill develops coordination and steady nerves. Toss-Up fascinates old and young. Entertains family and friends. Play Carrom Toss-Up and you will never give up! Now! Get in the swing and make a "ring"!

Players take turns either single, as partners, or in teams trying to make "rings" by trying to toss the ring onto the hook. If you make one ring you get a bonus toss. Two rings in a row give you two bonus tosses.

Each ring is worth 1 point and games are played to any point value set ahead of time. Typically you play three rounds with the winner being the one with the most points in 2 out of the three rounds.

name: Wirbel
description:
Rules:

At the beginning of the game, players take turns placing a disk on one of the 64 squares of the board. Care must be taken to avoid the opponent surround whirl symbols with his own pieces. Then, after all 28 disks have been placed, the disks can be moved one square horizontally or vertically. No diagonal moves are allowed
Once a player has placed four disks around a whirl symbol,he is in possession of that symbol and a marker of the appropriate colour is place on top of the symbol. The disks surrounding the whirl cannot be move any longer. Once a player has made ​​a whirl, he may move an opponent's disk to a different field of his choice.
Once (or twice, if agreed by the players at the beginning), during the entire playing time, each player can jump over other pieces moving one disk as a chess knight does.


The winner is the player that is able to conquer first three whirl symbols. (Additional rules allow to decide the winner in case one player has no legal moves for any of his pieces).

name: American War of Independence: Campaign Set 1 – The Northern Theatre
description:
Nine battles of the early Revolutionary war using a common set of rules. Each battle includes its own specific rules page and map (Bunker Hill has 2 versions).

Battles included in this set include Concord-Lexington, Bunker Hill, White Plains, Trenton, Paoli, Hubbardton, Germantown, Valley Forge, Saratoga

Players take turns moving their forces and attacking enemy units in order to achieve the specific objectives for a battle. One important difference to typical wargames is that before the moving player can attack, his units are subject to defencive fire from the opponent
categories: Age of Reason, American Revolutionary War, Print & Play, Wargame

name: The Penguins of Madagascar Zoo Patrol
description:
From the Box:
Take the role of one of the penguins and race around the zoo trying to be the first to collect three different foods and get back to Penguin HQ.
But you'll have to be quick! When the cog is rotated things keep changing: food begins to vanish, shortcuts open up and visitors start appearing. Don't let them see you or you'll have to drop your food and wait.

Basically it's a themed kid's roll and move game. The interest comes from the changing board and the diverse paths around the game board and choices to be made about when to return to HQ with the goodies.

name: The Game of Rex
description:
Card game "Easy to learn yet scientific" according to the rules. The game has a mammoth 151 cards, 10 of each number from 1 to 15, and a King card, (which acts as a joker that can represent any number required).

Each player is dealt 12 cards which are kept face-down in front of him and the top card revealed. This is your REX pile. Now everyone gets a hand of 5 cards.

The first player to the left who has a card number 1 places it in front of him. We will call this his build-up pile. He can now play a 2 if he has one, and so on. If he cannot play any more cards, he must place one of his cards face-up in front of him. This is his STORE. Eventually all players will have his build-up pile, his REX pile, his STORE pile and a hand of cards. He can play from his hand, his Store top card or his top card on his REX pile. If he can play a card from REX, he must do so, but other cards can be played or not as he so wishes. When the build-up pile reaches number 15, it is placed aside and a new one started with a 1 card.

The first player to use up their REX pile, wins.

name: Catch
description:
From the package: The funny animal catchers game

The players are animal catchers trying to catch as many of the animals as possible.
The board is rectangle of 7x10 squares. The catchers and the animal parts (all animals consist of two parts) are cardboard tiles.
Every player moves his catcher and one part of an animal. If a catcher lands on a correctly assembled animal the player can take it.

name: Rapid Response
description:
From the publisher's press release:

Rapid Response is the fast-paced, question and answer game that pits your basic knowledge up against a twisted timer! Families and friends will have a blast trying to multitask as the questions fly, the balls drop and the bell dings. Don’t get distracted by the “DING!” – as time quickly runs out! Quickly give your partner clues to guess the category on the card: “Cake…Ice Cream, Candles…Streamers“ Your partner shouts “Birthday Parties!” Right! Now grab a marble from the bottom trough and put it back into the funnel at the top of the slide to buy yourself more time.
The object of the game is to quickly (and correctly) guess the phrases being described by your partner before all the marbles run down. Open-ended categories make it easy for all ages to get into the action – hints can be as complex or simple as you need them to be.

name: Tell Me a Story: Animal Village
description:
Join the animals in this village as they dance, sing, and play. Recurring characters, locations and props encourage linking the cards in endless combinations for fresh, new stories every time it’s played.

Variations for gameplay exist, but the basic elements that apply to all are: players are dealt an opening hand of cards. Cards consist of characters, objects, locations. Gameplay consists of some combination of trade/discard/draw from deck in order to complete one's collection with the required elements for the story. The first player to complete his or her story hand of cards, then "tell" the story - wins!

name: Angry Birds: Star Wars – Darth Vader's Lightsaber Battle Game
description:
This game one of the many games in the Angry Birds Series.

"Launch, Stack, Destroy"

Stormtrooper pig, Darth Vader pig, and Obi-Wan Kenobi Bird

This is a new edition to the Angry Birds line. The game comes with a three figures, a launcher, 6 plastic blocks, 1 Lightsaber hilt, and instructions. The object of the game is to launch birds and knock down pigs.

The game is based on the Star Wars Angry Bird app. In addition, the game comes with a App code to unlock game content.
categories: Action / Dexterity, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Video Game Theme

name: Karvisen ÄTSH-peli
description:
In this Garfield game all players have four pawns they must move around the board from their own start space to their own goal. Each side of the square shaped game board holds start and goal of one player colour. You throw one die on your turn and move that many spaces on the board. If you land on a space already occupied by another player's pawn, you get to bump that pawn back to start. If you land in a space where there is a picture of Garfield's paw, then you are safe and no pawns can be bumped back to start from those spaces.

First player to move all pawns of her colour to the goal wins the game.
categories: Children's Game, Comic Book / Strip, Dice, Racing

name: AfterTime: Survival
description:
This four-player post apocalyptic board game leads gamers on the journey with Kai, making decisions that could impact the survival of the human race. In the aftermath of the apocalypse, survivors were forced to make decisions about how to rebuild our society. After Time: Survival follows the adventures of Kai, one of the lucky few who escaped from the crumbling civilization. But Kai's journey was not without its struggles, as he finds himself without a family, caring for a little girl who had lost hers as well, and is expected to lead a group of survivors in the rebuilding process. Faced with widespread hunger, dangerous weather conditions, and the dark temptations of personal greed, Kai's wits will be tested as he leads his group to a better life.

The board has a simple roll and move mechanic but when the players land on a "running Kai" space they draw a "Survival" card. On the card is a piece of the story that has an encounter that has two choices. The Player reads the card and then must choose an option and then turn the card over to see if they have earned community points or resource points. As they move around the board they might be hit by storms. The storms will set them back if they have no shelter token. Shelter tokens are earned when the player builds a community house.

Players compete as they race to amass resource points to build their own houses; but then the game takes a turn when they have to cooperate and negotiate with each other to spend and/or pool their community points to build community houses.

The winner of the game is the person who has been helpful enough to get all of the community houses built but has also balanced their own needs and has completed building their own five individual houses.
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Role Playing, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Gene Rummy
description:
This is a genetics-themed educational rummy-influenced game, with some of the mechanisms derived from genetics as well.

Cards are different from normal playing cards in that each card is a genetic base and also has a sequence number corresponding to its position in a DNA triplet. Players draw cards and attempt to sort the cards into different sets of codons. There are several different versions:
- Quick Game (three complete sets)
- Complete Game (extended to building proteins using the sets of codons)
- DNA Draw (Poker-based)
- DNA 3-card showdown
- Supper-advanced Gene Rummy (collect 5 sets and build the 5 specific amino acids that occur in the chosen protein).

Used as part of the game is an accurate genetic code dictionary and a protein chart of 8 proteins that are found in the human body. The game also comes with a laminated score chart, a wet-erase marker, 60 cards, and rule booklet. The rules also includes 10 pages of background information on genetics and the human body.

name: Draw Something
description: Now you can bring Zynga's Draw Something app home to play with 3 to 4 players. It’s the game that’s hilarious to play no matter how well you draw! One person takes center stage to draw the word while all the other players shout out their guesses. Both the artist and the guesser earn the coins. The harder the word, the more coins they each earn. Sketch and shout guesses to be the first to earn 15 coins.

name: African Fleet
description:
The players maneuver war ships, submarines, aircrafts, ships and amphibious war cargo was covering map Horn of Africa with new rules for expansion Pirete Fleet.

These games are published in Those Following Victory Games from 1985 to 1990, Fleet Command Magazine completely Asian in 2007 and later in Company Technical Term in several other published

These are contemporary games of naval warfare taking place in Middle East, Persian Gulf and Focusing on Iran.
Time Scale:
- 8 hours per turn
- 80 km per hex.

The game rules reuse from Victory Games Fleet series, includes new weapons have aim missiles, ballistic missiles lauched grond, SAM, cruise missiles

There are new rules aussi Regarding submarines AIP, Aegis ships, missile defense systems, long range air-to-air missile...

name: Cassette Juego: En Busca del Tesoro
description:
Cassette Juego was a very popular late 80´s spin and move series of portatile boardgames that were created in spain by CASA CHICO, but later was very popular in Venezuela and Peru,among other southamerican countries.(produced by Loklinka and Maxi S.A.)

The game itself was portable with shape of a 80´s old audio cassette, that come with it cassette box.The cassette was displayed in three sections. One is located in what was the function of the die, which was replaced by a rotating wheel with various numbers printed on it. The other two panels formed the board cassette. It was made ​​of metal, for small magnetic chips (usually four, but this varied depending on the game) could adhere securely and not dropped or lost. When not being used, the chips were placed in a small metal plate located on the upper right of the board.

EN BUSCA DEL TESORO (Treasure Hunt) each players take the role of an treasure hunter adventurer in seach for a big treasure, You roll and move your magnetic pawn having a mishap if steping on yellow squares that represent dangers of the jungle like cannivals, animals even hazardous cliffs. The first to get into the treasure wins instantly
mechanics: Modular Board, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Cassette Juego: Captura del Hombre de las Nieves
description:
Cassette Juego was a very popular late 80´s spin and move series of portatile boardgames that were created in spain by CASA CHICO, but later was very popular in Venezuela and Peru,among other southamerican countries.(produced by Loklinka and Maxi S.A.)

The game itself was portable with shape of a 80´s old audio cassette, that come with it cassette box.The cassette was displayed in three sections. One is located in what was the function of the die, which was replaced by a rotating wheel with various numbers printed on it. The other two panels formed the board cassette. It was made ​​of metal, for small magnetic chips (usually four, but this varied depending on the game) could adhere securely and not dropped or lost. When not being used, the chips were placed in a small metal plate located on the upper right of the board.

Captura del Hombre de las Nieves (Hunt the Yeti) is about a quest of adventurers seaching for the Yeti in the snow mountains going space by space in the dangerous cliffs. The first to get the Yeti is the winner.
mechanics: Modular Board, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Brigadier '38 Jolly Sporting Wargame Rules for A Very British Civil War
description:
A set of skirmish rules for 15-28mm.

From althistory alternative history wiki-
In May 1937, King Edward VIII of the United Kingdom married Wallis Simpson. The marriage to Wallis was not recommended by Stanley Baldwin, the British Prime Minister; and Edward refused to abdicate. This marriage left the British government, and most of the people, alienated; and hatred for King Edward and Queen Wallis rose. In January 1938, a protest by Dockyard workers in Liverpool was brutally crushed by the army; and violent clashes began across the country; between the Kings troops and those of several other factions. The British Civil War had begun!
Factions: The outbreak of conflict led several groups to attempt to seize the country or their own personal goals. Major factions included:
■ The Edwardian Army - Led by King Edward VIII
■ British Union of Fascists - Led by Oswald Mosley, the British Fascisti were aligned with the Edwardian Army
■ The Georgian Army - Led by Edward's younger brother, George, Duke of Kent.
■ The Anglican League - A large army led by a group of bishops and archbishops, they were aligned with the Georgian Army
■ The Red Field Army - Made up of disgruntled workers and Spanish Civil War veterans, they sought to turn Britain into a Socialist state based upon Lenin's Russia.
■ The Scottish, Welsh and Cornish Independence Movements - Groups in Scotland, Wales and even Cornwall who sought to form their own independent nations, they were supported at various times by The Red Field Army and The Anglican League.
■ The British Empire Independence Movements - Groups of people accross the Empire fought for autonomy and independence.
■ Foreign Volunteer Units fighting for the major factions. Examples included the AVAC (American Volunteer Army Corps) formed by Joseph Kennedy and the Hanoverian Legion formed by Hermann Göring fighting for the Edwardians; the ANZAC Volunteers and the Imperial Volunteers fighting for the Georgians; and the International Revolutionary Corps formed by Leon Trotsky and the People's Soviet Volunteer Army formed by Vyacheslav Molotov fighting for the Socialists.

From the publisher's website -
1938 A Very British Civil War has built a considerable fan base dedicated to researching and gaming this world of an alternative 1930's For the first time we have produced a specific set of rules for the period. These are aimed at creating large multi- player battles while retaining the charm and character that has made this project endearing to many wargamers Now with a group of friends, a good curry and a few pints, you have a fast play set of rules that will allow you to storm the defences of Liverpool, raid over the border or lead gallant cavalry charges in the Severn valley. Brigadier 38 as the name implies gives each commander a brigade, where a company is 10 figures, and a battalion of 30-60.

The rules cover-
orders, movement, firing, morale and melee, along with a points guide to provide suitable forces for battles and scenarios

name: Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer
description:
Play with the whole family as you make your way from start to finish. Answer questions about the beloved 1964 Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer animated classic along the way! It's full of holiday fun for the little ones, and packed with nostalgia for everyone else!

Contents:
Tin Game Board (inside box lid)
100 Question Cards, 6 Pawns, Rules

name: Winnie the Pooh: Wo ist I-Aahs Schwänzchen?
description:
Eeyore has lost its tail, and Winnie the Pooh and his friends go looking for it. Each player has an Eeyore to which different tails can be attached. The game board is set up inside the box. Trees with various items which could be used for tails are inserted into holes in the board (without looking at which tree has which item). A card is flipped over, and all players now look for the tail that is depicted on that card. They do that by rolling and moving along the trees; at the end of their move, they pull out the tree and check if it is the right one. When finding Owl, the active player may secretly switch two trees; finding other characters from the book cause other effects.
When all tails are found, players have to find Owl who has the original tail which is worth two other tails.
The player with most tails collected is the winner.

name: Empathy
description:
The goal is to get to know his friends better, using situations from everyday life (or not!) and classified into 7 categories: the seven deadly sins!

Empathy is a game where you unmask the true face of your friends and where they are racking their brains to identify you! You score points when you guess what your friends would feel in a given situation. For example, in the following situation: "You do the tail and a celebrity passes you by apologizing with his smile".

You surely know how you would feel in this situation, but do you know how to react your best friend? And your nephew? And your parents? And your friends / girlfriends / friends / uncles / aunts / grandmothers / grandfathers / son / daughter / colleagues / relatives / acquaintances / ... ?

You enter more feedback, and more chances you have to win!

How to play:
1 - Draw a "sin" card and read aloud one of the crazy situations.
2 - From your 9 "emotion" cards, choose the one you secretly feel. Then, the other players try to find it by each providing one of their nine "emotion" cards.
3 - Then reveal all the cards. All those who have found your emotion earn points on the "empathometer".

name: dysFUNction
description:
Play dysFUNction and you’ll find the fun in your dysfunction…but more importantly, in everyone else’s.

Grab a Cart and claim your Baggage- in this game, the player with the most Baggage wins. dysFUNction is not only hilariously entertaining, it’s cheaper and less painful than therapy! Take a ride on the Emotional Rollercoaster, acknowledge the elephant in the room, drag your skeletons out of the closet, or simply wake the f*** up and get out of Denial. Share family stories and One-Up your friends as you fill your Cart with Baggage you’ve earned the hard way, from the people who supposedly love you the most.

You can’t choose your family, but you can use them to win this game!

dysFUNction is a unique, fun storytelling game that will have you laughing and competing with your friends over who has the most dysFUNctional family. Dig Deep cards prompt players to share funny family stories; Baggage is awarded for the quality and entertainment value of each story. More Baggage can be earned by One-Upping another player's story, or by interaction with the Family Fun cards (and other board squares). Some players may also end up stuck in Denial. The first player to fill their Baggage Cart (with 15 Bags) wins the game.

name: Finders Keepers
description:
Objective:
To go round the board guessing clues and unveiling hidden objects (letters) in each one of the rooms. Each correct guess earns coins and the first player gaining 6 coins is the winner.
The game uses a turntable showing numbers in different windows of the board and a clue booklet referring to those numbers.

How to play:
Players go around the house on the throw of the dice. When stopping in any of the rooms a player may look at all the Key Cards in that room. If any one of those Key Cards matches the top Lock Card then the player can make his way to the Playroom and gain one coin.

Going into the playroom: To raid the room the player looks at the number shown at the window of the Playroom (ex.3). Another player then opens the clue booklet and reads the clue for that number (ex. ¨used to sleep´). The timer is set and the first player tries to find one of the letters he thinks form the right answer to the clue (ex. B-E-D). If he is right he gains another coin, and player continues to the next player.

name: Rare Snuiters
description:
In English, the title means something like 'Oddballs' or 'Weirdos'.

Contents:
44 Cards
There are 22 Matching Pairs and the backs of each card are marked as traditional dominoes so you get two games for your money.

The aim is to collect matching pairs. A matched pair consists of the top half of a character and a bottom half of the same character.

In your turn, you can either ask a player for a card that you would like, or you can tell a player a card that you would like to get rid off. When your appeal fails, the next player plays. Completed matches are set aside.

The obvious end is that the winner is the one who collected the most pairs but the rules suggest that you could create 'oddballs', i.e. the wrong lower half with the wrong upper half. The one who creates the best oddball (as judged by laughter, I guess), wins.

The backs of the cards each feature a different domino piece so Dominoes can be played with the cards.
categories: Card Game, Children's Game, Humor, Memory

name: Campfire
description:
In Campfire, each player is attempting to build three campsites before any other player. The game focuses on building up campsites while using camp wrecking critters to prevent your opponents from finishing first. Campfire is a family-friendly card game designed to be quick to learn for players of all ages.

Players draw from a shared deck full of cards to help build their camp, wreck other camps, and alter game play. Taking turns, players draw a card, play cards on the table in front of them in three camps, and play camp wreckers and game changer cards to the discard. At the end of a player's turn, they must discard one card from their hand (if they have any cards left) and replenish their hand. Play continues counter-clockwise. Discards are shuffled to replenish the deck when it runs out.

Campsites consist of two comfort cards, two food cards, and are completed with a campfire card that must be the last card played on a campsite. Cards are stacked in the order they are played and only the top card of any campsite is vulnerable to camp wrecking attacks.

The first player to complete three camps wins the game.
mechanics: Hand Management, Set Collection, Take That

name: App'd: The Card Game
description:
App'd is a game for 2-4 players where players try to be the first to fill up 100% of their brain's space with apps without going over. Players draw cards from the deck trying to get App cards, expansion cards or hardware cards that will help them reach that goal of 100%.
Taken from Kickstarter description

name: The Knot Game
description:
In harbours you see ships which are moored to the jetties and quays with thick ropes and complicated knots. These knots were developed by seamen a long time ago and are still used to this day. Each knot has its own special function and meaning.

In The Knot Game you learn more about the knots and you can lay as long a rope as possible in your colour. Up to four players can take part in the game.

The Knot Game is a tile-laying game. Each tile shows a rope, or two (differently coloured) ropes knotted together. The players start the game with four tiles. Each turn, a player may add tiles to those already on the table in order to inecrease the lenght of one of the ropes depicted. At the end of his turn, the player draws new tiles to replace the ones he has played. The game ends when all tiles have been drawn. Each player then gets one more turn.

Each player is secretly assigned a colour. The player that has the colour of the longest rope that has been created wins the game.

name: Final Order
description:
Final Order is a small trivia based game. Players decide on a number of rounds to play and the player with the highest score at the end wins.

Each round, one question card is drawn from the box. The card lists a question and three answers. It is the players' task to order the answers as requested.

For example, one card might read "From Highest to Lowest, put these countries in order of population: A. United States, B. China, C. India"

All players must lay out their answer cards (reading simply "A", "B" and "C") in the right order score points in each round.

name: Group of Tanks: North Europe, Spring 1945
description:
Simple 2-player hex-and-counter tank battle wargame.

Each tank unit have 3 traits: movement point, attack strength and defense strength.

The objective is to capture the opponent's capital (the hex with square icon)

Combat is very simple, with attacker roll a die, the result add to the attack strength of the attack unit. The defender roll a die, the result add to the defense strength and add by the terrain modifier. If the attacker's total more than the defender's total, the defender is eliminated. Otherwise, nothing happen.

name: FlipOver!
description:
The Matching Game You'll Flip For!
In this fun matching game for 2-6 players, kids try to be first to get their animals into the barn! Players search their cards to complete an animal image, then use the Barnyard Flipper to reveal the next image to be matched. Play continues until all images have been matched and all animals are back in the barn!

name: 駅前タクシー (Train Station Taxi)
description: Number 9 (of 12) in the Epoch Manga game series. Bookshelf game based on the comic strips of Fujio Akatsuka. All movement is spin and move. Each player controls a taxi and picks up fares from the train station. Destination and fare collected is determined by a card draw. Opposing players can move police cars when they land on a police icon to impede other players and force them to draw an event card. Event cards are generally misfortunes, but there are occasional good events (tipping customer, a bonus fare, etc). The winner is the player with the most fares collected once the are deck is exhausted. Art on the board, pieces, and cards are a mish mash of characters from Fujio Akatsuka comics.
categories: Children's Game, Comic Book / Strip, Transportation

name: poco a poco
description:
User Summary

The board game "poco a poco" is an excellent musical educational tool for any piano instructor. It is extremely versatile and can be used to facilitate learning in both group piano lessons and one-on-one piano lessons. It can be easily adapted for many or as few as two players, and the written board game "rules" are meant to broken if the needs of the class require the piano instructor to do so! The piano instructor must have these following items to actually play "poco a poco" successfully in conjunction with the board game itself: "one piano, metronome, basic technique, sight reading and ear training books/materials, manuscript paper or white board, and [little candies] or other treats." (Poco A Poco Game Rules, p. 1 poco a poco productions 1996)

Game play
Players or teams each roll die to move around the "keyboard" board, answering musical technique or term trivia and performing musical exercises in the varying categories required. Points or candies are awarded to players or teams who have completed their trivia or exercises successfully. The player or team who has the most points or candies is declared the winner.

Only a few hundred copies were produced and sold locally. Production ceased when the designers diverged.
categories: Action / Dexterity, Children's Game, Educational, Music

name: Six-Gun, The Cowboy Action Game
description:
Each player takes on the role of one or perhaps a handful of Wild West characters in a variety of situations--bank robberies, claims jumps, wagon train raids, etc. Each situation will take place on a map that is hand-drawn and divided into irregularly shaped zones.

Players roll dice to determine their action point allowance, which they then spend to perform actions like moving, shooting, reloading, etc.

When a player wants to shoot at another player, he or she has to try to guess the suit of a card drawn from a normal deck of playing cards.

If the guess is right, the shot hits and inflicts damage unique to its suit/value/weapon used. If the guess is wrong, the shot misses. Certain character traits and conditions of the shot can increase or decrease the number of suits the player is allowed to guess.
categories: American Indian Wars, American West, Print & Play
mechanics: Area Movement, Chit-Pull System, Dice Rolling, Push Your Luck

name: Klettermaxe
description:
Objective: be the first reaching target zone with all (5) your meeples
- moving by turns -
'three-dimensional' Halma with possibility to bounce your opponents -
1.) three-dimensional board is plugged first
2.) 2-player game: each player chooses one side/4-player-game: 2 players use one side each
3.) move your meeples according Halma rules climbing vertically
(plug in)
4.) an opponent's meeple (on reverse side) will be bounced if another meeple ends on that space (circled spaces are safe - can't be reached)
5.) game ends after all 5 meeples reached target zone

remarks:
should be published during end 1950's
tower is about 12" high

name: Think smarter! Querdenken
description:
"Lateral Thinking"

75 playful and practical exercises for cross-thinking solutions.
Who solve them fastest scores points.

Winner is the player with the most points.

Contents:

75 cards,
1 hourglass,
1 notebook

name: Space Raid!
description:
"War Game of the Future"

"Luck is not a factor... only courage, skill, and guts!"

This is a sci-fi strategy game with two battle fleets of plastic starships maneuvering on a galactic grid. One player represents the Alien Empire, the other player represents Earth Command.

The game uses a diceless combat system with a slightly complicated matrix comparison of "Ship A" to "Ship B" with an additional variable if "Ship C" is involved. Certain spaces on the diamond grid represent objectives for each player. Total domination of the galaxy is the final goal.

Designed for 2, 3, or 4 players at least 12 years old. Includes a colorful board, two starfleets, combat charts, and the rules.

name: Emperor
description:
Emperor is a climbing card game (in the mold of President, Tien Len, The Big Two, Tichu, The Great Dalmuti, etc.) that is playable with two regular card decks shuffled together. It was designed as a climbing game primarily for 6+ people (though rule variants permit 4-5 people to play as well).

The game allows singletons, sets (pairs, three of a kind, etc.), runs, and multi-runs (consecutive pairs, consecutive triples, etc.) as legal plays, which must then be followed by a play of that same type and of the same length, except in the case of special combinations known as "bombs." Several jokers are used as wild cards. Between rounds there is a unique redistribution phase in which all players discard a card face down; these are shuffled and dealt randomly back, one to each player.

Advanced rules allow for "calling a coup" in which one player names a calling card; the first person to play this calling card is the coup caller's partner. The coup succeeds if either player goes out first. A coup partnership receives a bonus or penalty depending on whether the coup succeeds or fails.

Other advanced rules allow for "class division" rounds in which face cards ("noble cards") cannot appear in combination with number cards ("commoner cards"), and in which there is "taxation" between rounds instead of redistribution (during taxation losers give winners their highest card). Further successful coups cause the game to toggle back and forth between such a class division round and the initial "class harmony" style of round, in which there are no restrictions on the play of face cards and there is "redistribution" between rounds.

name: Jimmy the Greek Odds Maker Football
description:
The game is based on American football and used cards to determine the outcome of plays. The plastic board represents an American Football field with a scoreboard, 10 yard marker, football, and has identical player charts on each side of the field. There is an Action deck of cards (52 in 4 suits) and two scrimmage decks (52 in 4 suits each). The suits represent different offensive and defensive play options, long pass (heart), short pass (diamond), running play (spade), or line play (club). The Action deck is used for non-scrimmage and special plays. Each player uses one of the scrimmage decks for plays from scrimmage. The scrimmage decks have a number 2-14 inclusive and a suit on the front. The back also has the suit. This allows the player to decide what type of play to run from the back of the cards without knowing how strong the play will be.

For an example of a scrimmage play, assume the offensive player looks at the back of his deck and chooses long pass (heart). The defensive player chooses running defense (spade). Both players turn over their cards and show 10 of heart and 7 of spade for a +3. Cross reference +3 and spade on the long pass chart to see that this is a 16 yard gain.

There are also rules for field goals, interceptions, fumbles, penalties and options, fair catch, on-side kick, etc.

The Odds Maker wheel is used to handicap the people playing the game and uses the number of times they have played this game, age, did they play football, do they like football, and do they follow football.

name: You've Been Sentenced! Country Music Edition
description:
Additional 80 cards for the game You've Been Sentenced! with Country music theme.

This sentence-building game uses unique five-sided cards with multiple conjugations of a base word. With a hand of 10 cards, players try to score the most points per round by constructing the longest, grammatically correct, and sensible sentence. Each card used in a sentence is worth 5 points, but using some of the more difficult conjugations on the card can earn you bonus points. Any player can object to another players sentence, on either grammatical grounds, or the fact that the sentence just doesn’t make sense. The defending player and the objecting player get to argue their points to the rest of the players, who form a jury. The jury gets to vote on whether or not the sentence is acceptable. Half the fun is trying to defend, explain, and justify a completely ridiculous sentence to the other players. Accepted sentences score points, rejected sentences get you zip. First player to reach 200 points wins.
categories: Card Game, Children's Game, Educational, Expansion for Base-game, Music, Party Game, Word Game

name: The Opera Game
description:
There are 3 ways to play.

Game Type 1
The first involves dealing out cards face down. The remaining deck is placed faced down. The first player draws a card. Cards are drafted by each player. There is a 5 card maximum hand limit. You may discard cards and other players may draft the discarded cards. You are trying to collect the sets of performers to perform your famous opera.

Game Type 2
Same as first game but the completed operas are scored and better operas will score more than more minor operas. The game is played to a score of 40 with operas scoring from 12 to 18 points.

Game Type 3 is the expert game

To score bonus turns you must answer trivia question correctly about the operas in the game.

Photography: Ron Scherl
Opera questions: Kenn Harris
mechanics: Hand Management, Open Drafting, Set Collection

name: Awesome 80's Trivia Game
description:
Pull on your leg warmers, back comb your hair and get ready to test your knowledge of the outrageous decade we all secretly love, with Spinning Hat's set of 80's Trivia Cards! Test your friends on topics such as the music, fashion, films and TV of the most talked about decade!

Ask the question and the player who answers correctly first gets the card as a point. There are also 3 variants on some cards.

Player with the most cards at the end is the winner.

name: Basileus
description:
Basileus is the classical logical game created by Marek Łukaszewicz in November 2010. This strategic game for two players is played on the board 8x9 squares. A king (called basileus) making a capturing move must leap over one or several of the opponent's chessmen but cannot jump over the opponent's king.

The goal of the game is to eliminate the king (basileus) from the board.
Each player has 4 pawns, 4 pieces and a king at the beginning of the game
The capturing is obligatory

1. A chessman making a non-capturing move (not involving a jump) may move only one square in all allowed directions.
2. A chessman making a capturing move (a jump) leaps over one of the opponent's chessman. Only one chessman may be captured in a single jump; however, when possible the player must perform multiple jumps in one move in all allowed directions.
Pawns
1. The pawns can only move diagonally, one square at a time.
2. The pawns capture the opposing chessman by jumping over it to the nearest square of the same colour. To do this they can move to the left or to the right, forwards or backwards, but not diagonally.
3. Pawns can only move on squares of one colour, so if they start on a white square they must always stay on white squares.
4. Pawns may only capture the Basileus or other pawns, they may not capture other pieces.
5. The game ends when one player captures the opponent’s Basileus by jumping over it to the next empty square.
Pieces
1. The pieces can only move diagonally, one square at a time.
2. The pieces capture opposing chessman by jumping over it to the nearest square of the same colour, diagonally in four directions, not to the left or to the right, forwards or backwards, Pieces can only move on squares of one colour, so if they start on a black square they must always stay on black squares.
3. Pieces may only capture the opponent’s pawns or Basileus, they may not capture other pieces.
4. The game ends when one player captures the opponent’s Basileus by jumping over it to the next empty square.

Basileus
1. The Basileus can move one square at a time in all directions, also diagonally.
2. The Basileus can capture opposing chessman by jumping over it to the nearest square of the same colour. To do this they can move to the left or to the right, forwards or backwards, or diagonally.
3. The Basileus cannot jump over the opponent’s Basileus, so if it finally stops on a square next to the opponent’s Basileus, the opponent can replace it with his own Basileus, thus winning the game.

name: Charades In-A-Box: Family
description:
Charades game with Family theme.

Players must perform and guess a whole host of fun charades that will have everyone laughing out loud. Each charade is ranked by difficulty – the harder the charade the more points your team can earn by guessing it correctly. The team with the most points after 10 rounds is the winner.
categories: Card Game, Deduction, Party Game, Real-time

name: Millennium Quiz
description: 1100 trivial and educational quiz questions. Via a 6 sided die players determin the category and question they have to answer.

name: Junior Blockbusters
description:
Game based on a British television show, but here geared down in difficulty of the questions so that 8 to 12 year olds can play.

Played over a 20-hex game board, two teams (one having one more teammate than the other) compete to answer questions with the initials given (What BE is Noddy's friend? Answer - Big Ears. That hex then belongs to the side with the correct answer. The first team to connect top-to-bottom or side-to-side wins the game.
categories: Children's Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Trivia

name: Equilispace
description: Equilispace is a dexterity game. The main feature of this game is a plastic disc, with an hemispheric base (on which it oscillates). On the upper side of the disc there are twenty cavities (11 holes and 9 furrows). Players alternate in putting a glass marble into a cavity, trying to avoid a serious imbalance of the disc. The player whose move causes some marbles to roll off the disc, is out of the game.

name: Bank-Letterspel
description:
Promotional game for the Dutch bank Raiffeisenbank and this is The Bank Letter Game.

Simple crossword card game, similar to games like Lexicon and Kan-U-Go. In your turn you may play a maximum of 4 cards. Words must be formed that use at least one letter of an existing word (except for the first word obviously which, incidentally, must be a four letter word). Any word can be extended though, if possible. Game includes two Jokers which have an image of an old motor car.

The first player to use all his cards wins the round. The other players total the values of their unused cards and the winner of the round scores a total of all those points (each card has a number value on it).

The winner of the game is the first player to reach a pre-agreed score.

The backs of the cards are quite novel. They can be used to make four different jigsaws. It is suggested that 6 to 8 year olds might like to do the jigsaws. I doubt it, they are extremely difficult for their size.

name: Queen Victoria's Navy Ship List Pack #1: China/Russia/Japan
description:
From the Rules

QVN Ship List Pack #1 includes additional ship lists and counters for use with BoneGames game of late 19th century warfare Queen Victoria's Navy. This is not a complete game. Ownership of Queen Victoria's Navy and its free expansion Admiral on Deck is necessary in order to use these ship lists.

Ship List Pack #1 includes ship lists for the Chinese, Japanese, and Russian navies as they were from the period 1880-1907.

name: The Bombardment of Alexandria 1882
description:
From the Rules

The Bombardment of Alexandria 1882 is an additional historical scenario for use with BoneGames game of late 19th century warfare Queen Victoria's Navy. This scenario is not a complete game. Ownership of Queen Victoria's Navy (and the Admiral on Deck expansion) is necessary in order to use this scenario. Visit the BoneGames website at www.bonegames.com for information about Queen Victoria's Navy, Admiral on Deck, and other games by BoneGames.

Historical Background

Early in 1882 the Egyptian Army forced the Khedive, Tewfik Pasha, to appoint Colonel Said Ahmed Arabi AKA Arabi Pasha as the new Minister of War. In this position, and with the backing of the army, Arabi was the de facto ruler of the country. Arabi was viewed with distrust in both Britain and France. This distrust was not without reason as he and his followers viewed the Khedive as a puppet of the Europeans, attacked Europeans in the streets, and threatened to nationalize the Suez Canal leaving the stockholders without a cent, and to repudiate Egypt's foreign loans.

A combination of fear for the Canal, the shortest route to India after all, the outraged cries of the investors and a pinch of concern for the Europeans in Egypt, plus a heavy dose of Jingoism led the British government to prepare for war. France, for some very convoluted internal political reasons, reversed policy and refused to help.

While an Army was being assembled the British decided that their first step should be to neutralize the extensive coastal batteries defending Alexandria. On 10 July,Vice Admiral Sir B. P. Seymour demanded that the forts, then being strengthened, be surrendered. The navies of other nations and all commercial shipping quickly sailed out of port. The Egyptians refused this demand and Queen Victoria’s Navy cleared for action. On 11 July, 1882 the bombardment began at 0650 hours.

name: MindTrap Brain Cramp
description: This Travel size MindTrap card pack focuses on various types of lateral thinking. Brain Cramp includes challenging Rebus puzzles and conundrums that leave you with a good kind of headache; this game proves a good headache exists!

name: Flights of Fantasy
description:
An LPS bonus mini-game.

"As the situation at Dien Bien Phu deteriorated, a relief plan was put into effect. Dubbed Operation Condor, WWII hero Colonel Boucher de Crevecoeur organized four battalions and 500 porters (PIMS) to march towards the beleaguered garrison..."
(From rules introduction)

Contents: One small mapsheet, one legal size cardstock sheet of rules, and a small sheet of 40 counters are included.

name: Hockey Night in Canada Challenge
description:
Hockey Night in Canada Challenge is a head-to-head stand alone game and an expansion to Big League Hockey Manager.

The object of the HNIC Challenge stand alone game is to win the championship by winning four matches. Each "coach" selects a team of one goalie, two defensemen, and three forwards, plus two extra players. Each match is played in three periods. Dice rolls determine the score in each period by both teams. Challenge cards can be played in each period to influence the score or affect the entire match. If the score is tied after three periods, overtime is played until their is a winner. Once a team has won four matches (of a possible seven), they win the championship!

The expansion pack option for Big League Hockey Manager allows General Managers (GM's) to collect a Challenge each time they win a match. Challenge cards can be traded or sold before the "trade deadline". Once a GM was won five matches, the first and second place GM's are determined. The HNIC Challenge stand-alone rules are used to play the championship final between those two teams.

(Note: The standard rules for HNIC Challenge are best played with two players. The expansion pack rules can be played with two to four players.)

From the publisher's web site:
Get ready for a quick, exciting best-of-seven series that's pits you and a rival coach in a challenge for the championship. This game is easy to learn and fun to play.
