Your teams face off as you roll the dice and strategically play your Hockey Night in Canada Challenge cards. Add quarter and semi finals and up to eight people can play. Each playoff round takes less than ten minutes and is perfect for hockey fans ten years old and up. This is also two games in one: Hockey Night in Canada Challenge AND an expansion pack for BLM's award winning General Manager game.

name: Fool the Farmer
description:
Game from The Beezer Book, 1976.

The object of the game is to reach the apple store first.
Any number of players can play. All you need are a dice and some counters. Throw the dice before the game. The one who throws the lowest number is Farmer.
Each player gets two throws at the start except Farmer. He throws last and only gets one throw.
If Farmer lands on a square with a player on it that person is caught and is out of the game. If a player lands on Farmer’s square, Farmer loses one turn.
The penalties in square D and square I apply to Farmer only. The penalties in square 2 and square 14 do not apply to Farmer. Players must throw the exact number to finish on 35.
mechanics: Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move

name: România (fan expansion for Ticket to Ride: Europe)
description: To play, you either need to have the original Ticket to Ride or Ticket to Ride Europe. The Romania map can be played with either rule set and components, but is preferable to play with the Ticket to Ride: Switzerland rules.

name: En galen värld
description: En galen värld is a party game. One of the players reads a question, like "Why did Americans scalp Mexicans in the 16th century?" or "Why did an American billionaire fill an airplane with ping pong balls?" The other players then writes down an answer. The player how read the question then have to decide how of the other player that is closest to the answer. That player gets one point. The player with most points at the end of the game is the winner.

name: Cartas Assombradas
description:
Cartas Assombradas (Haunted Cards in English) is a game where the players are supernatural investigators in a journey inside an old haunted manor. In each round, the players try to explore more and more of the house to prove their courage and gain points. The bravest (or luckiest) player that was not catch by the house's ghosts and explored more of the house, win more points. When dawn came, the player with more points is the winner.

Using a Push Your Luck mechanic, in your turn, each player take a card from the stack. If it is a house hallway, it means that the player explored that hallway and receives its points. If it is a ghost, he can lose some points, or even get out of the round. There are also equipments to help players in this adventure. Before he plays, a player can choose to leave the house in that round and gain the points he collect so far. If a ghost catches him, he loses all points.

The game ends when dawn came, being dawn a card that is shuffled in the deck before the third round.
categories: Card Game, Children's Game, Exploration, Horror

name: Álmok e Cartas Assombradas Edição de Colecionador
description:
This is a collection of Card Games by Vince Vader published by Ceilikan jogos. It was avaliable only during pre-order for both games and limited to 200 units.

Álmok is a game about deep buried memories in the mind. It is a journey between dreams and nightmares. It is an experience based on the unconscious perceptions of the oniric mind.

In Álmok, the players are in deep sleep, trying to collect parts of their dreams to scape an eternal nightmare. Use your memory, find your way to the wakening, tap in sleeping powers of the unconscious mind, be the first to get free from your dreams.

Álmok
Álmok uses the classic Memory Game mechanic with some twists to make the game more dynamic and enjoyable. In your turn, you turn cards face up and check if they are a group, like the classic game, but here, the groups must have 3 cards, but you can combine then using their color or their number, much like a rummy game. Each group you form, give you points and also a special dream ability that you can use later to gain even more points or save for bonus points in the end of the game.

The player who reaches a certain amount of points first (based on the number of players), is the winner.

Cartas Assombradas
Cartas Assombradas (Haunted Cards in English) is a game where the players are supernatural investigators in a journey inside an old haunted manor. In each round, the players try to explore more and more of the house to prove their courage and gain points. The bravest (or luckiest) player that was not catch by the house's ghosts and explored more of the house, win more points. When dawn came, the player with more points is the winner.

Using a Push Your Luck mechanic, in your turn, each player take a card from the stack. If it is a house hallway, it means that the player explored that hallway and receives its points. If it is a ghost, he can lose some points, or even get out of the round. There are also equipments to help players in this adventure. Before he plays, a player can choose to leave the house in that round and gain the points he collect so far. If a ghost catches him, he loses all points.

The game ends when dawn came, being dawn a card that is shuffled in the deck before the third round.

name: Widget
description:
Widget is a fast, easy-to-play, card game that asks players to make crazy, silly, funny, weird, unusual or otherwise great sentences out of the words they have in their hands.

The person who creates the "best" sentence, as judged by the other players, wins. Special cards that allow players to switch cards around along with other special rules add an element of strategy to the game, making it easy to learn but different and exciting every time you play.

The words and the illustrations have been carefully selected such that it makes Widget a family-friendly game that also works as a good party game for adults.
categories: Card Game, Humor, Party Game, Word Game
mechanics: Hand Management, Simultaneous Action Selection, Storytelling

name: Kaboom!
description:
Kaboom! is a card game for two to five players. The objective of this game is to, well…blow stuff up. You are under attack by well-armed and not-so-polite enemies. You can erect walls to protect yourself, and lob all kinds of incendiary devices at your enemies. But they will be doing the same to you. If they destroy all of your walls and take you out, then it’s Kaboom! You get the picture.

Game play is very simple. Players have a hand of cards that are made up of four different types that can be used to attack their opponents and defend against incoming attacks. As the game progresses, the players will have their protective walls slowly whittled down to nothing. This leaves them exposed and the next attack from any opponent that cannot be blocked immediately eliminates the player from winning the game, but does not remove them from the game. As soon as this happens, the endgame is triggered and the Endgame cards come into play. The Endgame cards are special cards that keep eliminated players in the game to hinder all those who are still in the running to win the game.

The game ends when there is only one player left who has not been eliminated. This player, being the only one to survive the battle, is automatically the winner.
mechanics: Hand Management, Take That, Variable Player Powers

name: Monsteropoly
description: A children's clone of Monopoly where the object is to be the player with the most Goosebumps (money) at the end of the game. The game ends when any player owes more Goosebumps than he or she can play. Small plastic faces with "hair" standing on end and mouth in a "scream" position are used to identify the owener of each property who also has a deed to the property.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move, Stock Holding, Trading
publishers: Late for the Sky Production Company

name: Succubus: The Reborn
description:
While at first glance nothing more than a deck of vampire-themed playing cards, Succubus: The Reborn is a new take on a classic game tool: cards. Each card bears a symbol – Rock, Paper, Scissors, Bomb – that makes the deck ideal for fans of Live Action Role Playing (as they often need some randomizing element during play).

What's more, each card contains one or more unique (and sometimes hidden) symbols, which allows the deck to be used for Succubus: The Reborn, the first title in the Party Poker RPG line of games which is playable by 8-90 players (with one deck needed for each ten players). One player serves as the Dealer, who oversees gameplay and leads others in what to do; everyone else is divided as evenly as possible into four teams, the teams being vampires who are members of four great Lineages represented by the four card suits:


Diamonds – The Marquisi (The Elite Ones) blend in among mortals that they might trade in money, power, and control, all while clinging to an old world sense of protocol and social decorum.



Hearts – The Copeadora (The Beautiful Ones) are universally insane, but also very beautiful – a benefit which they utilize in order to slake their unholy thirsts at the necks of beautiful socialites and wealthy benefactors.



Clubs – The Bas-Bazouk (The Outlaws) are the enforcers, criminals, anarchists, and street-toughs of the Vampire world, plying their wits and their supernatural strength to devastating effect in combat.



Spades – Unlike other Vampires, the Profugos (The Forlorn) do not possess a soul; they are therefore cursed with deep, soulless, black eyes, and are prone to acts of immorality and depravity.


Succubus: The Reborn is played over three acts, and in each act, players try to improve their hand of cards to create the best poker hand. In the first round players can trade however they wish amongst each other as long as each player always has five cards; if a player manages to trade away a joker, that player takes a card at random from the other person's hand instead of any card agreed upon. When the Dealer calls time, the player on each team with the highest card in that team's suit is the Captain, and all the Captains then compete in a single poker hand with the cards they hold, trying to win chips in the process.

From the second act on, players can trade cards with the Dealer for the cost of one chip, taking a random card from what remains in the deck. To trade cards in the second act, you trade in the same manner as the first act or you challenge another player, paying them a chip to do. In a challenge, each player chooses and reveals a card from his hand, with scissors beating bomb, which beats rock, and so on. The winner of the challenge decides whether or not to trade. For the third act, you can trade only with your teammates. After the second and third acts, each team Captain again competes in a poker hand, with the winner of the third such hand winning the entire game and bringing glory to his team.

Succubus: The Reborn includes a number of advanced rules that add quests, shadow symbols that allow for better trades with the dealer, character sheets that add special powers to the game, and more.
mechanics: Acting, Cooperative Game, Hand Management, Rock-Paper-Scissors, Role Playing, Set Collection

name: Master Esportes
description:
A sports trivia game with questions involving many sportive themes, like, Soccer World Cups, Olympic Games and etc. The game mechanism includes a little arena where the game pieces are throwed by the players.
The players impulse the game pieces in the "arena" and the final position of those pieces determine what theme question has to be answered.
The arena has 3 tipes of holes, like a pool table, the kind of role (by proximity) determines a kind of question (True or false, direct answer, or multiple choice question).
So, the colored pieces determines theme and the hole determines a kind of question to be answered by the players.

name: Monopoly: Bietigheimer Wohnbau
description: The classic Monopoly with constructions and other elements from Bietigheimer Wohnbau, a company from Bietigheim (city north of Stuttgart)
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading

name: Emperors and Eagles: Wargaming Rules for Napoleonic Tabletop Gaming
description:
Publisher Blurb:

In 1789, the French Revolution acted as the spark that ignited the volatile powder keg of Europe, pitching the continent into a conflagration of war and bloodshed that would last for decades. Amidst this chaos rose Napoleon Bonaparte, under whose influence France would become a dominant power, controlling, directly or indirectly, the majority of Europe. This companion for Field of Glory Napoleonic gives players all the information they need to recreate the French Revolutionary wars and the rise of Napoleon through to the campaigns of the Grande Armée and the early Empire. Emperors and Eagles also includes full army lists for the Peninsular Wars, where Britain and its Portuguese and Spanish allies slowly, but surely, turned the tide of the war and pushed Napoleon's forces back to their own borders.
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Napoleonic, Wargame
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Line of Sight, Measurement Movement, Simulation

name: Меценат
description:
Simple auction card game. Players have a money cards from 10 to 150 dollar bids, and two special cards "Sheikh" and "Forgery". They bid on paintings, the paintings bring victory points (4 to 15) and have a frame of color, if you collect three pictures of the same frame, yout get another 5 points. Forgery of "fake"

Gameplay is a blind auction. After considerm players scoring points for the picture and points beyond.

Theme of the game: the auction of paintings XIX - XX centuries.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Set Collection, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: Wingo Dingo
description:
In a two players game, the aim is to find the card hidden by your apponent according to its resemblance to your own cards in a minimum of turns.
Each player take a identical deck of card.
Each smiley on card offers 3 features: Head, eyes and mouth in 3 colors.
the first player choose a card from his deck. The second player other choose a card from his deck and show it to the 1st player. Then, 1st player with one of the three special cards show the second player the scale of resemblance between the chosen card and the hidden one: Thumb up, flat hand or thumb down
- Wingo Dingo Trio: test your reflexes.
Depending of the result, the 2nd player place the played cards on the row in front of the special card.
Then he propose a new card, and so on.
At the end, once the card has been discovered, players count cards placed in special cards rows and score the number of turn it took to discover the oponent card.

name: Genwelt
description:
One player represents the world's elites, who is trying to increase the assets of the elites. The other players represent the ambassadors of the peoples from the seven continents, who want to improve situations in five genetic application areas.
Before the beginning of the game the players must decide to play 10, 12 or 14 rounds. The agent of the elites receives 24 genetic research card. Each round he starts by playing one of these cards. Every card takes influence of the assets and the different application areas. The ambassadors of the peoples must decide to support and simultaneously make an own offer or block up the offer of elites-player. Clockwise the ambassadors of the people throw a dice to reach the target location named on the card. Always a 6 is rolled, a scenario-card is drawn and a scenario-round follows.
At the end of the game all players lose, if the total situation of the five application areas has worsen compared to the beginning. If the total situation is better than to the beginning, then the side with the higher assets wins the game.
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Age of Ravens
description:
From the publisher:

Age of Ravens is the second source book for Clash of Empires™. This book provides gamers with detailed army lists to fight battles from throughout the Age of the Vikings and the centuries of warfare in Spain. From the close of the 8th century, raiders from Scandinavia terrorised the British Isles and France, eventually establishing powerful kingdoms that made a resounding influence upon Europe. The book is split into three parts each focussing on a specific time period and series of conflicts and combatants, covering 18 stand-alone army lists plus variants.

Wolves unto the Fold
The first section covers the first Northmen raiders and their victims in Britain and Ireland to the establishment of Viking kingdoms. 18 army lists including variants are included for the Viking Raiders, Irish, Welsh, Picts, Scots, Middle Anglo-Saxons and Viking Great Army.

Invasion and Conquest
The second part charts the events in France with the competing interests and clashes between the Western Franks, Bretons and the Duchy of Normandy, and the invasion of England by William the Conqueror. 7 army lists including variants cover the Anglo-Danish, Bretons, West Francia, Normans and Anglo-Normans.

The Battle for Spain
The final part of the book deals with Spain from the arrival of the conquering Umayyads through the wars of El Cid to the nadir of Islamic presence in Iberia. 9 army lists including variants focus on the Visigoths, the Umayyad Invasion, Early and Later Christian Spain, Al-Andalus and the Berbers.
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Medieval, Miniatures, Wargame

name: American Chess
description: 'American Chess' basically plays by the rules of standard chess. Each player has a king, 7 primary fighting pieces, and 8 pawns. Unlike chess the 7 primary pieces capability of movement is controlled by the color of the square they occupy any any given moment. The starting positions of the playing pieces are identical to regular chess and the color of the square they are initially on serves as a guide to the relationship between the color of a square and the fighting pieces capability: black = rook; white = knight; blue = bishop; and, red = queen. A player may have no more than one queen at a time except when capturing a pawn or a queen that stands on a red square and in the next move must move one of the queens off a red square. With the exception of the beginning set-up, as just described, the colors of the remaining squares on the board are randomly distributed, there is no symmetry between sides.

name: Farming For Fun
description:
A game characterizing the oldest and largest industry known to mankind.

From the Introduction: "This game was designed with as much reality as possible to depict the actualities of farming. It is impossible to inject all the complexities of modern-day farming into this game, yet it does contain enough reality to be educational to the nonfarming-oriented person and at the same time provide a competitive and fun atmosphere for all. As you play the game, you can to some degree sense the frustrations that farmers face but yet realize the real competitive situation that farming has come to be, neighbor versus neighbor and, likewise, player versus player. You might note that virtually all the option positions in the game are akin to decisions that farmers must make. While playing the game you will find that what you thought was the best decision would later not be so, as the real life farmer has experienced so many times. Another likeness of the game to farming is that your destiny depends on when and where you are."

From the Object of the Game: "The object of the game is to buy and sell production as each player takes his turn. Production is defined as Corn, Soybeans, Wheat Cows, and Hogs. Commodities are defined as Corn, Wheat, and Soybeans. Livestock is defined as Cows and Hogs. Each player should try to buy as cheaply as possible and sell as high as possible as he stops on various spots around the board in order to accumulate the enough money to buy all the production that belongs on a player's farm. Players should keep in mind that they must make several transactions in order to buy their production and, at the same time, retain enough assets to take care of the expenses that will surely come their way. The first play to buy all production for their farm is the winner. Each farm's production consists of 1 bin of Wheat, 1 bin of Corn, 1 bin of Soybeans, 1 Cow, and 1 Hog. Bins are identified by colors. Yellow represents Corn bins, Light Gold represents Soybean bins, and Dark Gold represents Wheat bins. As a player buys these commodities, he may place them in their respective places on the board and, likewise, the same for livestock."
mechanics: Commodity Speculation, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: Chance oder Logik
description:
Unusual game intended for a communist state as East Germany was at the ime.

Players start with 10,000 Deutschmarks. The board has a long track that, at times, offers a short or long route (and on two places a third track is offered). Movement is by a die.

At several points there are numbers. These numbers relate to cards (there are thus 26 cards and 26 special spaces). Before you start on a short or longer path, you can look at the numbers on such a track. This might imfluence your decision. A general rule is that the longer the track taken, the more your money is secure. However there are bonuses to be earned by finishing the track quickly. So you must balance speed against risk.

After all the players have finished, money is counted up and the player with the most Deutschmarks, wins.

name: Shades and Glamour
description:
SUMMARY from the designer:
"Shades and Glamour is a card game based on an alternate history of the English Regency. The game mimics social life in 1814 — if one adds magic. The goal is to improve one’s social standing. Social standing is the value of one’s cards. One improves it by acquiring better cards. As with all romances, the game ends when a character becomes betrothed by losing his or her last card."

AVAILABILITY:
The game is available from the designers website as a print-and-play. Some character cards are only available directly from the author at conventions. The game additionally requires a standard deck of playing cards and a pen and paper.

GAMEPLAY SUMMARY:
Each player will play the character on their character card. Each character card has a different balance of a number of different attributes. The attributes each map to a suit of a standard set of face cards. Each player holds five facecards with which one will attempt to acquire the other player's character cards from them.

Players will take turns making advances via one of their attributes toward another player. That player can respond in kind, or counter with a different, attribute (analogous to each suit having a different suit which can trump it). Players then simultaneously reveal their played cards and add that total to the corresponding attribute on their character card. The player with the higher total triumphs, and takes the opposing player's character card.

If one does not hold a suitable card one can attempt to bluff by playing a face card as if it is suitable, but when it comes time to compare scores, only the attribute on the character card is counted, with no additional strength given via the face card. Alternatively one can opt to not participate in an exchange at all, before the face cards are revealed, but one will lose a turn as a penalty for doing so.

Play continues in rounds until only a player loses her last card. Points are counted, and the player with the highest points wins.
categories: Bluffing, Card Game, Novel-based, Print & Play

name: Find the Treasure
description:
Game published in The Jolly Play Book.

Rules:
'A Fascinating Board Game'
In this game, you and a friend each try to reach the Treasure. All you need to play this game are two buttons and a coin. Get buttons which are different in colour, for one button will be your marker, and the other button will be your friend's marker.

You both place your buttons in the Starting Box. The first player tosses up the coin. If the coin falls Heads, he advances his button two spaces; if it falls Tails, he advances his button one space.
The players take turns. Each player, of course, follows the board directions. As you see, sometimes a player may have to go back a box or two; sometimes he may lose his next turn; and sometimes he may be lucky and advance a few boxes. That’s the fun of the game.
The player who reaches the Winning Box first, wins the game.

name: Penguin Pals' Passing Puzzle
description:
Each player will lead a team of penguins through an icy passage to reach the other, colder, side.
Each player must lead his 5 penguin pals to the opposing side of a 5x5 board. Each space may or may not contain an ice block, and penguins may only land on these blocks, but may swim across one iceless space. Players take turns in which they either move a penguin, move an ice block or draw action cards, which anyone can play at any time.
The goal is to be the first to get all five penguins across, which requires you to move forward while blocking the others' passage.
mechanics: Area Movement, Network and Route Building

name: Apples to the basket
description:
It's a family game for 2-6 players with a strong memory component.

Players compete against each other by placing apples in a basket in such a way there are as many as possible from the same player altogether. The difficulty lies in that all apples have the same appearance and only at the end of the play when all apples are turned around (apples are marked on the back side) you can see if you have placed all your apples together. To make it more difficult there are some apples with special effects that can be used to obstruct other players.

name: Skunked
description: How high can you roll without rolling a one? The more you roll, the higher you score, the higher you score the faster you win. But, watch out that you don't roll any ones or you will lose your points and be required to pay a poker chip to the pot. The ultimate game of risk-taking and pushing the limits.

name: Tom & Jerry Run-around
description:
"It's magnetic! Hilarious! Fast and furious fun!"

A two player children's TV tie-in game produced by Berwick in the UK in 1970s.

Game consists of:

- thin raised cardboard board with 4 small pegs in the centre to secure a cardboard chimney piece
- 2 thin cardboard walls, one of them with a chimney attached; the walls have slots in them to denote doors. The chimney has a small slot on one side to denote a mouse hole.
- 2 plastic pegs to secure the walls
- 1 plastic "cap" to the chimney
- 3 plastic doors
- 2 plastic and cardboard sections that move - a fridge and a bookcase
- a cardboard kennel
- a cardboard shelf
- 5 cardboard Jerry "life" cards
- 2 plastic cheese pieces
- 1 plastic sausage piece
- 1 plastic dog bowl
- two plastic rods with magnets attached, the larger one used to control Tom, the smaller to control Jerry
- two plastic and card magnetic playing pieces, one for Tom and one for Jerry
- assembly instructions and rules

Each player has a rod with a magnet on end of it. The rods are slid under the raised game board and used to control the playing pieces. The rod controlling the Tom playing piece attracts the Jerry playing piece as well as the Tom playing piece.
The object of the game is for the player controlling Jerry to get three items of food into the mouse hole whilst avoiding capture by the player controlling Tom. To achieve this they have 5 lives, represented by 5 cards. If the player controlling Jerry places three items of food into the mouse hole before they lose the 5 live cards, they win. If not, then the player controlling Tom wins.

A variant of Balyna Magnetic Super Soccer, for smaller children.

Components were made of thin cardboard and plastic, and were therefore easily ripped/bent/broken. That, combined with the frantic nature of the game, means that complete copies in good condition are extremely hard to find.
categories: Action / Dexterity, Children's Game, Comic Book / Strip, Real-time

name: Cognosis
description:
Fairly straightforward snakes-and-ladders style game with 600 numerical, verbal and non-verbal reasoning questions (200 of each type) used to determine progress. Designed to help children improve their 11+/CAT scores (Cognitive Ability Tests used in the UK either as part of 11+/school entrance exams/streaming exams within weeks of starting secondary school) but with a "hard-mode" for adults consisting of a 30 second timer for each question rather than the 50 second timer for children. Cognosis Challenge squares add an extra dimension.

Cognosis is an exciting, problem-solving family game. It includes 600 questions based on the 3 question types that are used in Cognitive Ability Tests (CATs)*, tests that are faced by almost all children aged 10 or 11 in the UK.
Children have 50 seconds to answer the questions (the time allowed in a test) but over 12’s only have 30 seconds, making it a game for all the family. Land on a square and answer the question. Get it right and remain where you are or get it wrong and go back to where you came from. Land on a Cognosis Challenge square and challenge one of your opponents to answer a question of your choice – which category do they find the hardest? If they get it wrong, they go back.
Reach the Final Challenge square and answer the question to be crowned the Cognosis Champion.
Cognosis can be played simply as a fun game by all the family but it is also so much more. It gives children valuable practice in answering CAT type questions in the typical time allowed in the tests and so promotes familiarity and builds confidence. The best bit - as it is fun, children want to play it and don’t realise that they are learning and developing with every throw of the dice and every question answered. They also love beating their parents, grandparents or any adult so don’t think this is just a game for the children, they will want you to play too.
Cognosis with a twist
Alternative 1
If you're under 12 and want more of a challenge, why not play the game using the 30 second timer
Alternative 2
Going on a long journey but still want to play/practice, why not take a box of cards (you choose which type) and a timer ( you choose which one) and play simply by pulling out a question, turning over the timer and trying to get the right answer before the timer runs out.
Alternative 3
Out of the house and with a friend. Again, take a box of cards and a timer. One person pulls out a question and lays it flat and the other turns over the timer. Who can get the correct answer first? The first one to correctly answer gets to keep the card. Play for 15 minutes. The winner is the one with the most cards at the end.

name: Stalingrad Hall n°4
description:
Stalingrad Hall n°4 is an ideal introduction to wargaming. The game, through two scenarios, recreates fighting in the Stalingrad "Krasnay Barrikady" (Red Barricades) building in Autumn 1942.

Game sequences are divided in turns :
A-Reinforcements
B-Events
C-Activation phase
D-Close combats
E-End turn

The German plays first by activating one of his 3 squads. A squad can move or fire. Russian player then activates 0 to 3 of his units.
Once all units are activated, units adjacent to enemy units can engage close combat.

Available with French rules, but English rules can be downloaded from Vae Victis website.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Hexagon Grid, Movement Points, Ratio / Combat Results Table, Simulation, Zone of Control

name: Teenage Mutant Hero Turtles: Search for Shredder Game
description:
April O 'Neil,Ace Channel 6 News Reporter and Friend of Our Heroes Has Been Captured by Evil Shredder.

Held Against Her Will Down a Sewer in a Dark Alley,Your Mission is to Team Up With the Teenage Mutant Hero Turtles and Free Her From His Clutches.

Your Objective Therefore,is to Move Around the Board in Search of the Teenage Mutant Hero Turtles and Rescue April O,Neil.
mechanics: Push Your Luck, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Per Rotterdamsche Lloyd Naar Egypte Ceylon Sumatra en Java
description:
Players travel via ships toward former Dutch trading colonies.

The title of the game is a play on Arnold Weruméus Buning's book "Met de Rotterdamsche Lloyd naar Egypte, Ceylon, Sumatra en Java."

name: Rhymo Dominoes
description:
Played like regular picture Dominoes but you match rhyming words.

The major difference though is that the 'Start' domino has four sides. You can therefore match to four different dominoes each turn.

When you are the first to use up all the dominoes in your hand, you get one point for every domino still in your opponents' hands.

Play an agreed number of games and the one with the most points is the winner.

name: Are You On The Ball?
description: This classic game of skill can be learned in seconds, but it offers a fun test of hand-eye coordination that is challenging to people of all ages and skill levels. 10 metal balls must be skillfully maneuvered to the correct hole (only the central hole counts). You are rated for your efforts, from 1 ("You're Not Trying") to 10 ("You're Champ").
publishers: John Sands Pty Ltd, Milton Bradley

name: Mein erster Kalender
description:
First puzzling - and then play! First, the children get used to weekdays, months and seasons by playing. On the track assembled from puzzle pieces then they also can play the dice game "The Great Calendar Rally"!

The game consists of two parts: in the first part you put together the playfield from puzzle parts. It consists of a circle with the twelve months (each a single part of the puzzle) and kind of a "bridge" of the seven days of the week (again each weekday a single part of the puzzle) - there you can describe the months, the four seasons and the days.

In the second part the winner has to collect the most chips during a race through the months. A dice determines the number of months to go, you have to name them as you pass by. The game stops when the two chips of every month have been collected.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement

name: Quattro
description:
Quattro is board game variant of the classic game Connect Four.

The game is played on a 5x5 game board and the goal is to get 4 of your pawns in a row.

Each player has 12 pawns. On their turn, a player places one of their pawns on any edge of the board. Already placed pawns are pushed inwards. If the player manages to get one or more rows with 4 of their pawns, they score points.

After the last pawn entered the playing field, the game ends and the player with the most points wins.

Originally published in spielbox magazine.
mechanics: Enclosure, Network and Route Building, Square Grid

name: Color-Sets
description:
From the box:

"A fascinating game for two to four players. In three moves per turn, each player must try to match the color patterns on three cards to the colors on the playing board."

The game board features an inner and outer ring of indentations along with 5 colored balls and two decks of cards. For the easy game you use the inner ring, four balls, and the associated deck of cards. For the normal game you use the outer/larger ring, all 5 balls, and the other deck of cards.

Three cards are displayed at the beginning. The cards display the balls in various patterns (such as all colors sequential or colors in specific clumps with gaps between them, etc). On each turn a player gets three actions each of which he can use to relocate a ball. If at any time during the turn the balls match one of the card patterns the player wins that card (winning at most 3 cards per turn). At the end of the turn the display is re-filled to three cards before the next player starts their turn.

Once the deck is exhausted the players count their cards. The player who has won the most cards wins the game.

name: Stac-Tac-Toe
description:
Stac-tac-toe is a variation on the traditional tic-tac-toe game. Instead of being able to play into any one of the nine positions, a play must be made into one of the three "columns."

The columns may be stacked as high as desired.

After all of the beads have been played, then a player can split a substack ( 1 to number in stack) from any stack, and then move that substack of beads to any position.

First player to make 3 in a row wins, or play for a score.

The beads have a hole in the top and a post sticking out of the bottom. So the beads stack onto the board without the need for a post.

The boxed game includes rules, and a board. In addition each player has five "beads" and a peg to keep score. The player colors are yellow and orange. The playing board is black.

name: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Jagd im Untergrund
description:
Game description from the publisher:

In Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Jagd im Untergrund, Shredder and his ninjas have kidnapped April! Together the Turtles will track them through the dark sewers, but beware as Shredder might be lurking behind a manhole cover in order to stop you. Who will reach April the fastest to release her?

name: Shapeshifter Wars
description:
User summary:

Shapeshifter wars is a two-player abstract game that requires four stashes or Treehouse sets of Icehouse pyramids, as well as a 5x5 grid (or Volcano board), to play. Each stack of pyramids moves and captures differently, and can be transformed into other types of stack during the game.

name: Deal a Word
description:
This has 108 cards: 76 single-letter, 30 double-letter, and 2 wild cards.

Each player has a 9-card hand, and on their turn they may:

A) play as many 2+-letter words from their hand, scoring the sum of the values of the cards,

and/or

B) add 1 or more letters from the hand onto other players' words (without rearranging the other letters) to make new words, scoring the value of the cards played plus 2x the length of the new words formed;

OR

C) discard as many cards from the hand as desired (instead of playing any cards).

Cards are then drawn to fill out the hand to 9 cards again. There is a bonus of 50 points for playing all 9 cards in a turn, or 100 if all 9 cards are in the same word.

The first player to reach the goal (e.g. 300 total points) wins.

Also included are rules to use these cards to play word versions of:
- 3 kinds of solitaire
- 4 kinds of poker
- Casino
- Rummy
- Anagrams
- Memory

name: Pyg Farmer
description:
Imagine you’re a goblin farmer raising temperamental orcish pygs who would do anything to get their cute razor like teeth sunk deep into you. Now imagine, these pygs want to make babies and you’ve got to keep them happy or else. Finally, imagine every other nearby goblin farmer is eying your rich fertile lands and have no qualms sending their pygs to take them over!

OVERVIEW

Pyg Farmer is a unique and fun themed 2-4 player game of rich resource management, market trading, pyg battles, and keeping your deadly cute pyglets happy lest you risk losing life and limb!. Players take turns harvesting materials, completing quests, and exploring new farm lands to settle their ever growing horde of Pygs to breed and harvest to sell materials on the market.

GAME PLAY

Each turn is broken up into four seasons each giving unique bonuses and penalties. At the end of the cold winter will you have enough food to feed your pygs? In Spring will you pygs be in the mood to make babies? In Summer will you be ready for the invasions? In Fall will you have enough resources to trade with other players? Players win by collecting the most rewards by the end of year 5.

Players will have plenty of interesting combinations of options to choose from including: what resources will you sell or buy from the market, will you upgrade your farm, explore new lands, keep your pygs lazy or move them, harvest your pygs for resources and risk their wrath, battle other pygs, play unique action cards, mutate your pygs into new vile species, complete secret goals, and much more!

Each player has a Pyg Happiness track that measures how much they love or hate you, if they feel safe, and if they’re getting enough play time. Should these levels fall to low you’ll face the deep wrath of these brutish creatures!

Pyg Farmer was developed to be a fun, yet strategic game of decisions to survive the seasons and stick it to other players!

COMPONENTS

Final components have yet to be decided, but rest assured they’ll be plenty of pyg meeples, terrain cards, tokens, reference cards, and tons of pyg love packed into the game box!
publishers: (Looking for a publisher), (Self-Published), Giant Goblin Games

name: Jinsei Game
description: A 2008 reprint of the 1968 original The Game of Life, Japanese version ("Jinsei Game", literally "Life Game"). Includes the standard game in Japanese as well as an additional game board, the "Junior Stage" board, which lays over top of the standard board and roulette spinner wheel. The Junior Stage variant, designed specifically for children but playable by anyone, features larger, easier to read print (in Japanese) and thematically follows the player from birth through job-hunter stage (where the standard game board begins). The game can be played in three ways: Junior Stage only (30 min approx.), Standard only (60 min approx.), or full version playing straight through from the Junior followed immediately by the Standard stage (90 min approx.).

name: Fiefdoms
description:
Fiefdoms is a 2-4 player dice based, area control-type game. Each turn players roll four dice from which they create two grid references - determining where on the six-by-six map they can place armies and workers; occupying castles to gain points or controlling villages to gain extra powers. Once placed, your armies will have to fight for the most important locations - using a positional, dice-free combat system.

Thematically the game is inspired by the influx of Norman barons into England during the reign of William Rufus - all vying to grab lands and castles. Despite the theme, this is very much a Euro-game - rather than a wargame.

In keeping with the printandroll promise - to provide everything but the dice - the pdf includes a page of cut out and fold armies and workers. However, you may find it easier and more satisfying to use pieces from another game. As with Siegecraft, the rules are printed on the board for ease of reference.

The files for the game can be found in the files section, below.

name: Mensa Word & Number Puzzle Pack
description:
This collection contains cards, dice, a 2-sided board, counters, and a 72-page book with 106 puzzles and answers, as well as rules for the following games:

- Number Nightmare: Number counters are randomly laid out on the squares of the checkerboard. A number card is drawn and players look for 3 adjacent numbers on the board that can be combined in an equation to equal the card's number.

- Puzzle Piracy: Parchisi with squares that require you to answer a randomly-drawn puzzle card to progress.

- Word Wizard: Like the Memory game, except that you are trying to combine a word on a card with one on a die to make a valid compound word.

- Syllable Storm: Players try to make words from the syllable cards in hand and letter counters drawn from a bag, scoring the total of the values on the counters.

- The traditional dice games Craps, Rounders and Mexican.
categories: Card Game, Dice, Math, Puzzle, Word Game

name: Rock 'N Tour
description:
Rock 'N Tour it's a trivia game where you can explore more than six decades of Rock and Pop music in the best trivia in spanish language.
Remember bands, classic songs, significant moments in rock history and discover the truth over facts and myths around the rock world.

Contains:

1 Board
306 Trivia Cards (with over 1,400 questions)
2 Tuckboxes
8 Concert Ticket Tokens
18 Musician Tokens
1 Die
4 "Rock On" Pawns
1 Rulebook

name: Foxes and chickens!
description:
The object of the game is the first player/fox to get one chicken back to his den wins the game.
How to play:

Place the chickens in the coop in the center of the board .
each player takes 3 foxes and places them in their den marked on board.

Throw a 6 or 1 to get a fox out of den.
Throw the dice and move on that number of squares in a clockwise direction,you are trying to get to the coop in the center of the board .once in the coop you can pick up a chicken and make your way home to the den,always moving in a clockwise direction.
If another player/fox lands on your fox they capture your chicken and you are returned to the den .

You may stay on any track and keep going around for strategic purposes e.g. to capture a chicken of your opponent.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Events, Kill Steal, Pick-up and Deliver, Race, Static Capture, Take That, Track Movement

name: Predestination
description:
Predestination is a 2 player cooperative trick-taking cardgame. It is a companion game to the 2 player competitive trick-taking cardgame Foreknowledge, with both being inspired by Romans 8 in the Bible.

In the game, the dealer player will be dealt a set of cards from the deck and then allocate the cards between themselves and the non-dealer player. The dealer then arranges the cards in order they will play them, and play proceeds.

The object for the round is to make exactly the number of tricks that was revealed at the start of the round. Play continues a set number of rounds, with each round consisting of a different number of tricks that need to be won.

In the advanced version, additional rules are added and change each round, to mix things up.

name: Don't Tip The Trash Can
description: Each player attempts to balance a piece of "trash" on the top of Oscar the Grouch's trash can. The player who last placed a piece of trash when the trash can falls over loses the game.

name: Shogi4
description:
A shogi variant intended to introduce classic board games to young children. It has been released under public domain and made available as a print and play game.
Each player start the game with 5 animals: a carp (pawn), a tapir, a raccoon-dog (bishop), a fox (rook) and either a crane or a pheasant (king). Each piece move one square towards any direction shown on the piece, but may jump over allied pieces, which makes the game quicker and more dynamic. A captured piece is invited to the captor's farm, from where it can be summoned to play for the captor's team. All pieces, save the kings, will evolve (promote) upon reaching the last row, becoming creatures from japanese folklore (koi, baku, tanuki and kitsune, respectively), and adding more movement options.
It is a cute and colorful game, easy enough for seven yers old to play but still challenging for adult players.

name: Drinking Games From Around The World
description: Contains 30 drinking games from different countries printed on cards. Randomly select a card or use the spinner to tell you which continent's games to try. Comes with game cards, a deck of regular cards, a spinner, 2 dice and a red chip.
categories: Card Game, Dice, Mature / Adult, Party Game
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Open Drafting, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Where's the Wizard?
description:
The object of Where's the Wizard? is to collect three Silver Charms by listening and guessing correctly where the young wizard is hiding.

The game consists of a turntable with 10 conical wizard hats along the edge. One hat conceals an electronic wizard.

Players start with a hand of six cards and must draw on their turn until they have a complete set which allows a spin of the turntable. The suits (wizard, wand, owl, spell book, newt, rat, and toad) require different numbers of cards to form a set. Wizards require only one card, spell books require four cards, but newts, rats and toads are worthless and can never be used to earn a spin.

When the player has collected a complete set of cards, he spins the turntable which causes the hidden wizard to laugh. The player then lifts a hat and if the wizard is found, the player collects one silver charm.

The first player to collect 3 silver charms wins.

name: Family, The Game
description: Family members, or at least friends who know each other well, take turns answering questions from a booklet while the remaining players attempt to correctly predict their answers. Correct guesses allow your pawn to advance towards the goal.

name: Pentominoes
description:
A pentomino is a five-square puzzle piece. If you took five squares, and laid them against each other, edge to edge, then that would be a pentomino. There are exactly twelve different ways you can arrange five squares. In the original puzzle, the task was to create interesting patterns using the pieces.

This version of Pentominoes is played on a 10" x 10" board ruled into 100 squares. (Solomon W. Golomb's original design for a pentomino game featured an 8x8 grid of 64 squares.) Each player has one set of Pentominoes and these are placed anywhere on the board in turn. The object of the game is not to make patterns, but to place pentominoes on the board in such a way that the last player cannot place a shape on the board.

Limits to placement:
1. A vacant space of at least five squares must be left after placing a piece on the board.
2. The winning player may place some of his remaining pieces in the vacant spaces to score double points for one and triple points for two.

The rules add a tip: It is advisable to try to reserve a space in the shape of one of your pieces after your opponent has played that shape.

name: MLB Chipz
description:
MLB Chipz is a basic dexterity game from Topps using themed, collectible poker chips. The components are themed poker chips with a baseball-inspired design and featuring MLB players. The chips come in several variants such as magnetic, glow-in-the-dark, and metallic but the variants do not affect game play. The game board is reminiscent of a baseball diamond, with scoring zones marked for value. The themed components do not impact game play. Each package contains four random chips, a sticker, and a game board.

Rules are included on the back of the game board for three dexterity games: Shuffle Chipz, Flip Chipz, and Spin Chipz. In all three games, the board is laid flat with the final resting position of the chip determining the score. In Shuffle Chipz, chips are slid onto the board and players have the opportunity to knock away opposing chips. In Flip Chipz, chips are flipped onto the board, and chips landing face up score double. In Spin Chipz, the chip is placed in the middle of the board and spun. The goal of the game is to accumulate the highest score within a set number of rounds.

name: Move It
description:
Translated from the back of the box:

Move It is an entertaining and social family game which makes your spare time efficient time.
Move It makes activity a game, and is the perfect solution to a more active way of life.
Move It is won by making a series of simple and funny physical exercises, which can be made by healthy kids and adults.
All exercises can be done indoors, and are developed in cooperation with leading experts in health and sports.

User description:
Players roll dice to move their pawn around on a field track. Passing the 100 meters, 200 meters, 300 meters or 400 meters line makes you draw a card describing a physical exercise you have to do. If you do the exercise correctly you will get a gold medal. First to 10 gold medals win the game. Medals can be lost by meeting other players pawns or the trainer.
categories: Action / Dexterity, Dice, Party Game, Sports

name: Moocho Sudooko
description:
The goal of Moocho Sudooko is to be the player with the most tiles on the board and the least amount left in your pile.

Players place tiles by rolling two D6 and the adding, subtracting, multiplying or dividing the two results to get a number between 1 and 9. The player then places the tile on the board, a 9 by 9 grid representing a sudoku board. Tiles must be placed such that they don't break the rules of sudoku. The game ends when no possible legal move can be made (whether or not the puzzle is completed).
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Pattern Building, Tile Placement

name: Kidz Cardz 4 Favorite Card Games
description: Kidz Cardz treatment of Go Fish, Old Maid, War, and Crazy Eights. The 4 decks come individually boxed in cardboard and in a big tin.
mechanics: Hand Management, Open Drafting, Set Collection

name: Sea World Treasure Key Board Game
description:
A Seaworthy Adventure for Little Treasure Hunters!

Each player in turn spins the spinner and moves that number of spaces on the game path to either "Treasure Cove" or a "Sea Place." Each player tries to collect 3 keys; one each from 3 Sea Places. The player who collects 3 keys and is first to return to Treasure Cove is the winner.
mechanics: Pick-up and Deliver, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: They're Coming
description:
They're Coming is a zombie survival game. You must move your survivors through several locations to the rescue station while fighting off your opponent's zombies.

Depending on the version of the game, players have two modes of play. In the "Single Pack" or "Travel Edition" of the game, one player take on the role of the survivors and the other the zombies; in the "Standard" or "Two Pack" version, both players take turns being survivors and zombies in a round of play. Survivors draw from a survivor supply deck and must navigate locations (chosen by the opponent) that are infested with zombies (which are played from the opponent's zombie deck).

In the Standard game, the player who gets the most uninfected survivors to the rescue station wins. Non-standard games can be played by increasing the number of locations that survivors must pass through and/or by reducing the number of survivors to start the game.

name: Outside These City Walls
description:
Outside These City Walls is a short story in puzzle form.

In this print-and-play card game, the player takes on the role of two jewel thieves, Amy-Bax and Zeke, and attempts to flee from one end of the city to the other to the safety beyond.

The city is laid at as three columns of eight cards. Each thief only moves onto cards of their own colour, which display the internal monologues from the character. As the thief leaves their card, the card is flipped, showing the opposite thief's colour and monologue. Some locations become locked and cannot flip, while other locations can be collected for their valuables. The game ends if both thieves can make it to the other end of the city, and an ending is determined by the number of cards collected throughout the thieves' escape.

Outside These City Walls is an experimentation in card game narrative, and the story told throughout play is of long-forgotten places and unrequited love. Even if the player resolves the puzzle and escapes with both thieves, their actions throughout the escape will determine the destiny of the two ill-fated nightrunners.

name: Shadowrun: Hostile Takeover
description:
Game description from the publisher:

In Shadowrun: Hostile Takeover, players assume the role of megacorporations attempting to assert dominance over the city of Seattle.

Hostile Takeover is a game of intrigue, shifting alliances, and secretive schemes in the most famous futuristic megaplex of Shadowrun’s Sixth World. The most wealthy and influential megacorps of the city contend for dominance of Seattle, and they use shady dealings and deniable assets to wage a war in the shadows for supremacy.

Additional description from the Publisher:

The Year of Shadowrun gets an extension into 2014 as Catalyst will publish Shadowrun: Hostile Takeover, a Euro-style board game with a strong, immersive theme running through every aspect.

“Games such as Lords of Waterdeep have shown you can take elegant Eurogame mechanics and wed them with an immersive world to create a wonderful tabletop experience,” said Randall N. Bills, Managing Developer for Catalyst Game Labs. “Shadowrun is a universe that screams for a host of board games to expand player’s enjoyment of visiting the Sixth World often. Pairing up award-winning designers with Shadowrun is going to be a fantastic combination.”

name: Mega Bloks Race Car Builder
description: Mega Bloks Race Car Builder Game utilizes board and building game play requiring both strategy and luck. Players move throughout the city stopping at different locations to build their racecars. Be the first player to complete your car and reach the winner's circle to win.

name: Shakes & Fidget: Das Kartenspiel
description:
UNRELEASED GAME



Note that all details for this game are preliminary. If you have information about this game, you are invited to edit this section or submit corrections.




Right now the only details about this item are the Shakes & Fidget: Das Kartenspiel name and what's included below.

name: Ascoola 90-talet
description:
Swedish trivia game (translation: "the super cool 90's). With questions relating to (predominately Swedish) 90's pop culture in TV, music and film.

The players divide into teams or compete individually. It is a party game where having fun is more important than keeping score, though one correct answer equals one point.

name: Wie gehen die Geschäfte?
description:
User Summary

'Wie gehen die Geschäfte? Ein Unternehmerspiel voll Spannung und Humor' was published by Haus Hachenburg in the 1950s or 1960s in Germany. Another edition can be found published by SALA (Sala-Spiele GmbH & Co.)

A game reflecting the economic miracle in Germany. Similar to Monopoly you can buy/build businesses, starting from a 'Milchgeschäft' (dairy) over a 'Konfitüren-Geschäft' (jam business) to the most expensive 'Leihbücherei' (library). The player with the most money in the end wins.

name: XandO
description:
XandO is played on a 6x6 square grid. The game begins with the players taking turns to blacken four squares of the grid (two each). After that the players take turns to mark their symbols (X and O) in empty squares, with the option of blackening a square instead on their last turns.

Once the grid is full players score for consecutive lines of their symbols in any direction. However, while even numbers of symbols score positively, odd numbers (greater than one) score negatively.

A game consists of two rounds. In the second round of a game, the same four squares are blackened as were chosen at the start of the first round and the player who went second now goes first.

name: Divoshi
description:
Divoshi is a two-player abstract strategy board game themed as a battle of two savage tribes. While similar to chess at first sight, the rules are very different. It is played on a square/rectangular board which may vary in size somewhere around 7x7. Like in chess, players make alternative turns, attacking and capturing opponent pieces and trying to capture the chief. But here the similarity ends.

Divoshi has five types of pieces, and all of them may move in eight straight directions like the chess queen, but within a limited scope. What is most specific for Divoshi is the rule of pushing/retreat and capture. If a piece enters a square occupied by an opponent piece, the latter is pushed off one square further. If there is no room for the retreat, the piece is captured.

The rules favor an aggressive playing style in which having your own chief under attack usually entails losses. The freedom of movement and the possibility of moving two pieces in one pushing move make the game unusually dynamic.

name: Hermit Boxes
description:
Hermit Boxes' is a two player game from Games magazine, March 2013. It can be played on a 4x4 or a 6x6 board. At the start of the game, the board is empty. Off the board is a supply of three dimensional rectangular pieces having dimensions of 1x1x2 units, where a unit is about the same length as the side of a square on the board. The pieces come in three colors - red, yellow and blue.

Each player in turn chooses a piece of any color and places it on the board either upright, so that it covers just one square, or on its side, so that it covers two squares.

Pieces may only be placed on empty squares, and a piece may not be placed next to a piece of the same color, not even diagonally.

The first player who is unable to make a legal placement loses the game.

name: Conquest of Canaan
description:
The year is 1300 BC. Take command of an Israelite tribe of warriors, priests and tribesmen in order to conquer the land of Canaan and be crowned King of the Israelites! Command legendary warriors, powerful relics, and awesome miracles to battle the Canaanites together with your fellow tribes, while deviously scheming to claim the lion's share of glory!

Conquest of Canaan is a worker placement game for 2-5 players. Each player controls one of the tribes of Israel, strategically managing his workers and resources while trying to take control of ancient Israel from the Canaanites. You'll undoubtedly battle with your fellow tribes to conquer high places, but if you hope to defeat cities, you'll also need to work together.

Resources and workers are limited, so you'll need a sharp wit, good planning, divine favor, and a little luck to succeed in the Conquest of Canaan.

name: Volim Hrvatsku
description:
Board game where players in three rounds answer trivia questions about Croatian history, culture, sport, music, geography, etc.

Društvena igra na ploči u kojoj igrači u tri kruga odgovaraju na pitanja vezana za hrvatsku povijest, kulturu, sport, glazbu, zemljopis…
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Team-Based Game

name: Pro & Contra
description:
Aim of the game
Players have to make others guess words by giving positive and negative statements about the term in question and without mentioning that word. By doing so, they practice argumentation skills and looking at something from different angles.
Game play
The game can either be played in teams (4 or more players) or everyone against everyone else (up to 5 players). The stack of cards is placed face-down next to the board. Each of the cards has a word on it (e.g. "talk shows", "mobile phone apps", "EU enlargement"). The starting player starts by giving a positive statement about the word on his/her card. If a player guesses correctly, both the player who explained and the one who guessed move 6 spaces on the board. If the word isn't guessed, the same player has to use a negative statement next round, and if successful both players get to move 5 spaces (one space less per round that it takes to explain the word). The player whose token reaches the finish line first wins the game.

name: Maya: El Florado
description:
A "Maya the bee" themed memory and dexterity game for children.

Theme
A thunderstorm is coming! Maya the bee and her friends are trying to bring home as much honey as possible before it gets too wet. Who'll manage to collect the most honey?

Aim of the game
Collect the most honey by remembering where the honey is and by skillfully throwing your token in the right places.

Setup
The 32 square meadow tiles (4 water lilies, 6 honey flowers, 22 dandelions) are shuffled and placed face down in the middle of the table. They form the meadow.
The player tokens (Maya, Willie, Flip, Beatrix) are placed at the edge of the meadow.

Game play
Players take turns throwing their player token on the meadow tiles. If your token lands on one or more meadow tiles, you place the tile face-up next to the meadow (if it is a water lily), place it face-up in front of you (dandelion) or place it face-up in front of you and get to look at two of the face-down meadow tiles and place them in a spot of your choice in the meadow (honey flower). If your token lands on another player's token, you have to give him/her one of the tiles you've collected.
When a player turns over the fourth water lily, he/she finishes the turn, and then the game ends. The player with the most flower tiles wins the game.

name: Trubel auf dem Bauernhof
description:
Game description from the publisher:

A new animal has come to Farmer Ben's farm — Sparky, the little dog. He immediately starts investigating his new surroundings. Which animals still live on the farm? In Trubel auf dem Bauernhof, players accompany Paulchen as he goes to see the different farmyard animals and listen as they welcome him loudly!

This collection of games offers plenty of variety in the form of a cooperative dice game, fun sound memory game, lightning-fast reaction game, and two story games.

name: Batty
description:
Batty is basically a competitive version of the classic Tower of Hanoi puzzle. Players each get three cards (A, B, and C) to place stacks on and then try to get a given set of numbered cards arranged in one stack in descending numerical order; the cards are moved from stack to stack with the players forbidden to place a card on a card with a lower number.

Players start with three cards, then proceed to four the next round, etc., up to a maximum of fourteen (the number of cards provided per player). All except the highest-numbered card in each round are shuffled, which is the only difference from the usual Tower of Hanoi puzzle.

name: Daredevils & Co.
description:
Daredevils & Co. is a steampunk-fantasy tactical card game for 2-8 players. Lead your army of brightness or forces of darkness to conquer mighty fortresses. Massive rivalry and adrenaline from beginning to end of the game. Beautiful, diversified cards offer great variety of tactics that lead to the victory.
The goal of the game is to take enemies' Fortresses. Players choose their units and special cards and each turn attack other players or defend their own fortresses. There are the following game variants:
1. The game ends after an assigned number of sieges. After each siege score is counted up for every Fortress taken. Player who scores the highest after the last siege is the winner.
2. The game ends when a player takes an assigned number of Fortresses.
3. Both scenarios stated above can be played in two variants:
- Deathmatch - each faction competes against the others.
- Team play - bright factions team up against dark factions.
mechanics: Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Hand Management, Open Drafting, Take That

name: Mezmo
description: Mezmo is a collaborative game for 3 to 11 players, ages 5 and up. In the game players take turns adding a single tile to a slowly growing game board where the other players judge whether or not the played tile fits the "Theme" of the pieces it connects to. The game focuses on the personal judgement of each of the judges, as was as the current player's ability to convince others of their artistic vision. Failure to appease the judges forces the player to take back their piece, as well as receive another random tile from the bag. The game ends when one of the players has no more pieces to play. It's a laid back, casual game that inspires alot of conversation and thought, and is best played with a creative crowd.

name: Ends of the Earth
description:
This is a free print and play game.

Life on Earth rides on the back of huge continents, and in the seas around them. Different species are interconnected with one another and influence the habitat for all life. In this game you introduce species (represented by playing cards) to your individual continent. Each species influences the global temperature, as well as having a preferred temperature range of its own. The individual continents have a unique special ability, playable once per game. The aim of the game is to collect the most victory points by having species on your continent survive Extinctions. This game lets you play out an alternative history of Earth, past, present and future!
categories: Card Game, Educational, Environmental, Print & Play

name: Über den Wolken
description:
An adventurous flight over Germany.

Above the Clouds is an entertaining search-and-strategy game for learning geography. Each player must reach his plane some destinations which are assigned to game start. But since everything is under a blanket of clouds, you have to push the right cloud aside to find the right place. By his flight on the board, he may, under the clouds that obscure the destinations, the geographical position of towns, rivers, lakes discover and mountains of his country.

But watch the lightning!

name: Marching to Richmond
description:
Marching to Richmond is a simple strategic game covering the American Civil War in the region containing the two capitals; the map depicts most of Virginia, most of Maryland, and Pennsylvania as far north as Gettysburg.

The system is very similar to that in Watt's The Peninsular War 1808-14; on each turn a player can spend 12 movement points among their forces, with a maximum of 6 per unit. Units can be moved by ship to a limited extent, and in this game also by railroad. Only one attack can be made each turn, with the outcome determined by die roll; the die results don't depend on the opposing forces at all, but the number of die rolls allowed depends on the number of attacking units and the defensive terrain.

The game is played to an agreed-upon time limit (2 hours is suggested) at which point a small fixed number of final turns is played. The Union player wins if they control enough Confederate cities (depending on whether they still control all of theirs or not), otherwise the Confederates win.

The game was originally published as a do-it-yourself kit (Watts' description) in 1974. A revised version titled "prototype trial edition" was published in 1989. It is unknown if a further edition was released.

name: Andaman Fleet
description:
Andaman Fleet is a contemporary game of naval warfare taking place in the Eastern Indian Ocean. It can be played alone or with Asean Fleet.

Time Scale :
- 8 hours per turn
- 80 km per hex.

The players maneuver war ships, submarines, aircrafts.

The game reuse rules from Victory Games Fleet series, but improved with new weapons as AWACS aircrafts, Ballistic missiles, and SAM.

There are also new rules regarding submarines, Aegis ships, AWACS, and long range air-to-air missiles.

The game includes 7 scenarios, from simple to more complex:

1/ A few Acre of Island
2/ Assault on Andaman Islands
3/ Sword of ASEAN
4/ Wolf Pack
5/ Invasion Bengal
6/ The Enemy Below
7/ Last days of Yangon

name: Mango Republic
description:
Mango Republic is a tabletop game for two to four aspiring dictators. Players use their cards to expand their power and attempt to take complete control of the government of a nascent democracy.

There is a board to keep track of the activists, parliamentarians and generals in Mango Republic. Tokens placed by the player on the districts count as activists, tokens on parliament count as members of parliament, and tokens on Fort Peace count as generals.

The more activists in a district the player has, the more parliamentarians he gets. The more parliamentarians he has, the more cards he can hold. Cards give you options to gain activists, generals and hurt your opponents.

Whoever establishes complete control over the government, wins.

name: Walking The Tight Rope
description:
The images and story for the game include the most famous tight rope walker of the time, Blondin.

Charles Blondin is famous for first walking across Niagara Falls Gorge on a tight rope in 1859. He would later walk across numerous other times and entertain the crowds by crossing blindfolded, on stilts, or with his manager on his back.

Game board shows an amusing scene with a tight rope stretched across a river flowing down from a waterfall. Directions for the game state ‘Ben’, who stands on the cliff dressed in the sailor suit has already crossed safely. The four walkers still attempting to get to the other side by way of the rope are named Ez, Uncle Tom, Fatty Fisk, and ‘the expert Blondin’.

The game board also shows people falling from the tight rope and landing in the water below. These are named in the directions too. Ebenezer is tumbling into the water, only Nebuchasnezzar’s feet are shown as he sinks below the water, Ezekiel is swimming to shore, and Jeremiah is said to be going up the ladder.

The boat in the scene is named as well. Commanded by Uncle Sam and carrying a small African-American boy, the boat represents the Freedmen’s Bureau. This agency was created in 1865 to help the newly freed slaves. With the tight rope bridging the gap, and the dangers of failing, the game is seen to give subtle references to the post civil war era.

Tight Rope is played by the spinning the indicator (earlier edition - rolling the two dice).

To step on the rope (place his piece on space 1), a player must spin a 1. To move across to number 12, a player must then spin the next number to where his piece rests. This is done by spinning two times in a row. If a player does not spin the number needed to move his piece one step ahead, the player then moves down the grid. Whenever he spin the number needed (no matter how far down the grid he is), he moves to the number near the rope. If the player does not spin the needed number and is in the last space below his numbered step, he moves back one step.

The first player across wins!

name: Break In
description:
Break In is a push-your-luck card game in the vein of Incan Gold, with players trying to steal as many gems as possible from a bank before they get caught. The longer you stick around, the more you'll earn — but stay too long and you'll find yourself wearing handcuffs!

Break In — first published online in the game compilation "Femtitvå" — can be played with a standard deck of cards or with the free downloadable card deck provided online. To set up, remove the 7-10 in each suit from the deck. Shuffle the cards into three or four equal stacks, after which each player can look through one stack, then reshuffle that stack.

On a turn, a player draws the top card from a stack of her choice. If a face card shows up, it counts as a guard and is placed face-up on the table; any other card counts as cash and is placed in front of the player. (An ace also allows the player to look through one stack, then reshuffle it.) At any time during the round, a player can cash out, scoring one point for each pip on the cards in front of her and one point for each card face-up on the table, whether cash or guards.

If a second guard shows up in a suit, then the round ends and no one still in the round scores for the cash in front of them. After five rounds, whoever has the highest score wins.

name: Dwarven Miner: Summoner Patron Card
description:
An additional card offered as a Kickstarter exclusive.

The Summoner allows you to copy any Patron that is played by another player and cash him in for the same amount of Victory Points points as that other Patron card.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Hand Management, Push Your Luck, Variable Phase Order

name: Tenshō karuta
description:
This is the earliest of a range of Japanese card games based on Portuguese playing cards brought to Japan in the mid 16th century. All these games as well as some unrelated and more recent games are denoted by the word "karuta" from Portuguese "carta". Due to the age of this loanword, it can be written in a bewildering number of ways. About equally frequent are かるた in hiragana as other old loans that have been naturalised and カルタ in katakana, like modern loanwords. Archaic and more rarely seen are "sound-ateji forms" like 歌留多, 加留多 or 嘉留太 using kanji for their sound value without reference to their meanings. The kanji 骨牌 might be read karuta, but primarily represents koppai こっぱい, meaning a particular type of cards, or "bone mahjong tiles" (from Chinese gǔ pái meaning "bone tile", referring to dominoes). Besides this, the term fuda ふだ might be used for at least some forms of playing cards. This may also be written with the kanji 札 with the primary meaning "paper money", and in this sense read satsu さつ.

The term "Tenshō karuta" is a later term later applied to distinguish the oldest form (which in origin actually predates the Tenshō period) from later developments.

The 48-card deck is divided into the four suits of pau ぱう – from paus "clubs", isu いす – from espadas "swords" (shortened), koppu こっぷ – from copas "cups" and ōru おうる – from ouros "coins" (literally the plural of "gold"). Each suit consists of 12 cards: rei れい – from rei "king", kaba かば – from cavaleiro "knight" or cavalo "horse" (shortened), sōta そうた – from sota "servant" literally "lower [rank]" and number cards from ace to nine. As in the Portuguese precursor, the ace cards depicts a dragon holding the suit symbol. In the "short" suits of cups and coins the number cards rank in reverse from ace (high) to nine (low), while the "long" suits of clubs and swords are ranked normally. This feature is not only shared with older European cards, but at least for coins goes all the way back to the earliest Chinese playing cards.

Later some of the Portuguese-derived names are replaced by indigenous ones. Pau becomes hau はう, "flower", and the clubs are shown sprouting flowers; while kaba becomes uma うま "horse".

Unsun karuta and Sunkun karuta are rooted in Tenshō karuta

name: Reverse Charades: Canadian Edition, Eh!
description:
From the back of the box:
Hysterical fun from "a" to "zed"

O Canada! Get ready to show your Great White North pride as you face-off against your fellow Canucks for some big-time laughter. Reverse Charades is a hilarious twist on the normal charades game you know-where one person acts out the words for the team to guess (boring)! With Reverse Charades, your entire team has 60 seconds to act out as many classic Canadian-themed words as one guesser can guess.

It's fast-paced, fiercely-fun team competition-a strange brew of action-packed hilarity sure to have Canadians from sea to sea raising their hockey sticks and jumping on their chesterfields to celebrate! You'll have such a blast that no party, game night, family gathering or team-building event will ever be complete without Reverse Charades (ok, and Nanaimo bars, too)!

name: Flug um die Welt
description: There are two playing choices: In the plane race, the winner is the player who is the first to fly around the world and return to his starting Airport. In the flight around the world, the winner is the player who is the last who completes his world trip, because he's the one who visited the most locations.

name: Leijonan Metsästys
description:
Leijonan Metsästys (Lion hunt) is a roll-and-move game set in Finland. Players move on a map of Finland, trying to find the Finnish heraldic lion somewhere in Finland.

In order to examine cities, players must answer trivia questions correctly. Whoever finds the lion, must take it to Helsinki or Ruokolahti. Other players can find "Sisu" tokens and try to reach the goal first in order to win.

The game is designed for the whole family, and features two levels of difficulty in the questions to make the game balanced between adults and children.

name: States and Statesmen
description:
Tagline:
Educational and Entertaining for All Ages!

Description:
Candidates run for Office in each of the 50 states represented on the Game Board. Each State is delegated a set amount of Electoral Votes. When all 50 states are represented, a National Election is Declared, and the party resident with the MOST Electoral votes is Elected President and declared Winner of the Game!

Contents:
17 1/2" x 18" Board
Six (6) Individual Player Pawns (red, yellow, green, blue, black, white)
Fifty (50) State Cards
Two (2) six-sided Dice
Assorted Candidate Markers (yellow for Congressman, blue for Senator, red for Governor)
Fourteen (14) Political Message Cards
