categories: Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Mafia
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Auction/Bidding, Hand Management, Simultaneous Action Selection, Take That, Trick-taking

name: Dwarven Traders
description:
Dwarves are best known for their mining skills - but what's the use of all those jewels when only gold is accepted at pubs? Therefore - from time to time - dwarves abandon their mining equipment for a year, roll up their sleeves and try to get most money for their gems. And to get some tension - and keep trading interesting - some small bets and wagers are placed, for finding out who's the best gem trader among the dwarves!

In Dwarven Traders players try to get most profit from buying and selling different gems. Every action you make changes prices and creates new opportunities for other players, so you must have a really good plan for outwitting them all! With no randomness or hidden information it's not an easy task... but also for them!

During his/her turn, player has always two options available, displayed on 4 public action cards: player can buy 1 gem (indicated on card), sell 1 gem (indicated on card) or do both - with only limit being gem storage (max 2 gems). After that prices change, according to card information, used card is flipped upside down and it's clockwise next player's turn. Round ends when one player is not able to perform either of actions; game ends after fourth round - and whoever has most gold is the winner!

name: Space Chase Math
description:
A roll-and-move game testing addition and subtraction facts, set on a board themed around the international space station. The board can be flipped to switch between difficulty modes.

Description from the box:
Have fun playing this "out of the world" fast-paced game of addition and subtraction.

name: Oshi-jō no tatakai (忍城の戦い)
description:
忍城の戦い (Oshi-jō no tatakai) translated in English as "Battle of Oshi-jō", although "The Siege Of Oshi" would be a more accurate name for this wargame.

Published in 2011 by a small group Dōjin Club Ludens Faber (同人会ルデンス・ファベル), the designers and illustrators of the game want to remain anonymous. All game elements are contained in a ziplock. This game was later substantially revised and upgraded and published in a new game Battle of Oshi-jou, with a larger map, revised rules and more than double the number of units.

The 1590 Siege of Oshi (忍城の戦い Oshi-jō no tatakai) was a battle during Japan's Sengoku period. Oshi Castle, a stronghold of the Narita clan, was besieged by forces loyal to the Toyotomi clan. The castle was famously defended for over a month by a force consisting of only 619 samurai and 2000 local conscripts against forces numbering over 20,000. The battle is also famous for the actions of Lady Kai (甲斐姫 / Kaihime), who led 200 Narita men into battle to rout the initial attack against the castle.

The game incorporates standard hex-and-counter movement on a map representing the region around the castle. The game proceeds in an "IGO-UGO" manner. Units may perform ranged fire in an attempt to cause enemy units to become disordered (recovery from disorder may be attempted at the beginning of each turn). Enemy units may also return fire to cause disorder on their attackers. Close combat proceeds on a simplified, odds-based combat resolution table using a single die (d6), and can result in disorder, losses and retreat. If an army suffers enough losses, it becomes demoralized, suffering combat penalties and the elimination of any unit that becomes disordered. The game includes special rules for Lady Kai's ability to boost the morale of conscript units under her.

Components:

A4 map (210mm × 297mm / 8.3" × 11.7")
50 mounted, back-printed counters (not die-cut)
A5 rulebook: two pages historical notes, four pages "Warring States Folio" series rules, two pages game-specific rules


(User description)
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Hexagon Grid, Ratio / Combat Results Table
publishers: Dōjin Club Ludens Faber (同人会ルデンス・ファベル)

name: TradeWorlds: Exterra Edition
description:
Plagued by world conflicts, the Terrans came to the realization that their survival was dependent on the colonization of other planets, resulting in the formation of four distinct Terran Megacorporations (aka the Exterras):


The Acolytes (Red): Economic, old money, wealthiest Megacorporation.
The Brethren (Blue): Militaristic, new money, geared for space combat.
The Covenant (Green): Covert, smallest faction seeking global power.
The Destined (Purple): Disenfranchised, a collection of dissidents from all the others.


When the period of time known as The Trials ended, the Terran factions pursued their own interests and ceased nearly all contact with one another. More than a century has passed since the last Acolytes moved freely among the planets negotiating contracts; Brethren members seized vulnerable outposts; Covenant scientists revealed the latest technologies; and Destined raiders captured vessels in their space lanes. But, all is not well.

Espionage agents working for the various Factions gathered significant intelligence on their current leaders' intentions. As the decades receded into history, the families, clans, and tribes of long-forgotten names, including Avalon, Augustus, du Lac, and Ravndotter have coalesced their efforts. One hundred years of isolation have taken their toll on the Factions. While each has exploited particular assets, the lack of connectivity with others has created its own set of complications.

The current generation of Terrans remains guarded and suspicious of others, but they are also filled with a desire to fulfil the providential future ordained by their leaders so many years ago. Scout ships and exploration vessels, commanded by pilots and astronavigators who have never ventured out beyond their own controlled space, have only begun making the arduous journey among the stars. Will these intrepid Faction members bury the sins of their forbearers, achieving a compromise among the others, or will they simply abandon all hope for a peaceful coexistence? Historians gazing out at the political landscape agree that after a long period of silence, the Tradewars shall begin.


TradeWorlds is a 1-4 player competitive space battle deck-building game, which includes different scenarios to determine how the game is won:


Traderwars: Players must balance the collection of wealth with their need to defend their homeworld.
Spacewars: This scenario is all about survival. Be the last player standing to win.
The Derelict: A single-player scenario that focuses on surviving an alien assault.
Solo AI: A full solo play experience which simulates the multiplayer game.
Co-op Mode: A cooperative scenario that entails fighting off an alien invasion.


During a player's turn, the player first selects any 1 of the 10 roles in the game, which are:


Chancellor: Can initiate a diplomatic vote to reach an agreement in the game
Treasurer: Discard cards for funds
Admiral: Control multiple starships
Captain: Reconfigure starships
Commander: Reconfigure crews
Engineer: Reconfigure weapons
Sergeant: Force all opponents to discard
Private: Force 1 opponent to discard
Smuggler: Steal 1 card from 3 chosen cards.
Trader: Draw extra cards


The scenarios determine which of the 10 roles are more desirable during the game, though each role has its purpose. Players must determine what actions and benefits they need in order to move their agenda forward. Once the role is resolved, the player may trade cards to buy Upgrade cards.


Cards may also be sold to increase the player's Treasury value.


Adjustments are made on the Score Pad whenever necessary and in accordance to card effects or player actions. Wealth, Homeworld Defense Points, and the number of starships the player can build are kept track of on the mat.


When a player acquires starships, they may deploy them to the "Space Lane", which act as walls to protect their Homeworld from invasion. Before a starship can be deployed, it must be configured, which entails connecting 3 Upgrade cards; the starship Upgrade card, crew Upgrade card, and weapons upgrade card. Configuration of a starship means that it is manned, armed and ready to fly. Each Upgrade card has an Energy rating (or "capacity"), Weapon rating (or "firepower"), and Crew rating (or "resistance").

A player may command up to 4 starships at a time, from an array of 5 unique classes. Starships can be configured in up to 125 different combinations.


Combat is initiated when the player decides to use their starships to attack an opponent’s starships or an opponent’s unprotected homeworld. Attacking is only possible if the player elects to take the Admiral role for their turn.

Attacks can be done with 1 or more starships and the attacker gets to decide which of the opponent’s ships are included in the skirmish.

Initiative is determined by rolling dice. If the attacking player wins the initiative, the battle continues. If not, the opponent is able to escape the fight.


A player's turn ends when the player is done taking all their actions, at which point they may draw back up to 5 cards. If their draw deck is exhausted, the discard pile is shuffled and becomes the new draw deck.

The players continue to take turns until the game is won. The victory condition is determined by the scenario selected by the players. Once the objective has been met, the game is over and the winner is announced.
categories: Dice, Economic, Science Fiction, Space Exploration
mechanics: Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Dice Rolling, Hand Management, Trading
publishers: K2 Games Inc., Outer Limit Games (II)

name: Wall Climbers
description:
You compete against your opponent to climb to the top of the wall before your opponent. You will use dice with images of hands and feet, which you will roll and then match up with the same images on the game board. By placing your dice on the images you can progress up the wall to the top.

You can place do on the wall to block movement or use cards to hinder your opponent, all the while trying to make your way up to the top of the wall face.

First one to the top of the wall wins.
categories: Action / Dexterity, Card Game, Children's Game, Deduction, Dice, Print & Play
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Hand Management, Point to Point Movement

name: Das neue Wien Quiz
description:
Das neue Wien Quiz is a trivia game containing 220 question cards with three multiple choice answers each.

The game is played in turns. Every player has to answer a question but can choose not to hear the multiple choices. If he opts to do so, he gets 3 points for the correct answer or 0 points if he was wrong. If he chooses to use the multiple choice option, he gets 2 points for the correct answer, but if answered wrong, he gets another chance but then only 1 point is awarded for the correct answer.

The game ends at the end of a round in which a player collected 30 points. The player with the most points is the winner.

name: Perplexus Micro: Drakko
description:
From the publisher's website:

The second in the new Perplexus Micro line! The clear egg houses a fierce dragon, whose body forms a twisting path for marble maze fun! Perplexus® Micro was designed to attract the attention of Perplexus fans, as well as draw in new players with its 3" size and smaller price. These collectible games are easy to pick up, but hard to put down!

There are 33 challenges to this 3D maze game.

name: Dust Warfare '47
description:
Dust Warfare '47 is the latest incarnation of the Dust Warfare miniatures game. It is a fast-playing tabletop miniatures game set in an alternate history of WWII, in which alien technology has changed the nature of warfare in the era. The Axis, Allies, and Sino-Soviet Union (SSU) fight not only for their peoples' political goals, but also to secure the coveted vK alien technology used to power their war machines. Players build armies of 28mm scale miniatures and face one another on an open-table top using measure tape and specialized dice. Dust is a game of strategic planning, tactical maneuvering, and dramatic firefights.

Dust Warfare '47 is a community-driven game that picks up where the original Dust Warfare left off. New units have been added, existing units have been re-balanced, and core rules have been tweaked. While the official version of Dust (Dust 1947) which is published by Dust Studios is now the only sold version of the game, Dust Warfare '47 is officially sponsored by Dust Studios but maintained by the community. To play Dust Warfare '47 simply requires the same miniatures used for the official Dust 1947 game and a free set of rules.
categories: Miniatures, Science Fiction, Wargame, World War II

name: Jet-Alert Game
description:
A full color game of skill in which you pilot your own jet airplane through exciting maneuvers with life-like jet replicas. There is no dice and no luck. Your skill brings you victory or defeat.

This game uses a board with irregularly shaped playing spaces where the player moves his aircraft a certain number of them changing altitude at the same time. It is therefore difficult to be sure where the aircraft will end up since some playing spaces are much larger than others. There is terrain which is at a given height. The game uses color coded bases to indicate altitude. Planes are equipped with missiles which automatically hit aircraft at a certain range. Aircraft can also bomb cities (presumably with nuclear weapons) and destroy them but must be at certain altitudes to do so. It's a little like chess with aircraft based on the only documentation I have which is the patent application.

The original publisher is listed as MGK but as far as I can tell that company does not exist. It's possible this was a self-published game. The designer was listed as Garcia-Kuenzli. I do not know if this reflects 2 designers or what country he or they were from. This is the only copy of this game I have ever seen. Neither the designer nor the publisher is in the BGG database.

name: Rainbow
description:
Easy memory-style board game that is well suited for both adults and/or children or the whole family.

In Rainbow, 9 cloud tiles will be arranged in a square. On their turn, players will flip over the clouds to their rainbow side to find colours matching on of the three rainbow cards that are the current goal cards. As long as the revealed rainbow colours match one of the goal cards, the active player can continue to reveal further colors until either one of the rainbow goal cards is fulfilled (take that card and score at the end of the game) or the sun is revealed (player is allowed to unflip colours again for a new try) or the raincloud is revealed (shuffle all revealed tiles!).
The winner is the player who scored the most points on the rainbow cards he completed.

For buyers at the Tokyo Game Market Dec 2016, an additional tile "Thunder" was added as a give away to create even more variety.

name: Huckepack
description:
A push-your-luck game involving donkeys. The object of the game is to move your donkeys to the feeding spaces and take the best food. Every turn each player will anounce how many spaces the would like to move. Then they will throw the die and if the result is equal or higher than their declaration, they will move that number of spaces.

However, if the result is less, they will stay in the same space, an also they can move backwards if the result is a -1. The neat part of the game is that a donkey lands on a space with another donkey, they pile them, and the player on the bottom must obey the orders of the higher donkey.

Has nothing to do with other games called Huckepack, and is suspiciously similar to Die Heisse Schlacht am Kalten Buffet. No author is credited on the box.

name: Meduris: Essen Promo
description:
The 10th rune stone: awarded to first player to erect both their temples



Protective Amulet: given to first player to build four huts.



The Spring: Affects druids crossing the great river.


These promo items are contained in the HABA catalog that was given away for free at Essen 2016. Rules can be found on the publisher's website.
mechanics: Network and Route Building, Worker Placement

name: The Worst Game Ever: Little Drop of Poison Promo
description:
Place in front of another player. At the start of their turn, they must roll a die and pay that many tokens to the kitty.

Comes inside the game "Little Drop of Poison"

name: ¡Escándalo! El robo del siglo
description:
A great art exhibition is celebrated. For the first time it has managed to gather in a great exhibition numerous objects, jewels and artworks that until now it had not been possible to contemplate together. This exhibition is assembled for the first time in a museum enabled in The Alhambra Palace (Seville, Spain). Incredible safety deployment, protection systems have been carefully designed. cAmong all the pieces featured are five valuable jewels coveted by the world's most famous thieves, who will meet there in an attempt to prove who is the best of them all. They will all try to steal them without being trapped.cNo one can enter without jumping the system. No one? ... Nothing can be removed from the museum without being detected. Nothing?...

Penetrate into the Palace of the Alhambra, getting as many jewels as possible and escaping without being discovered is the challenge of the game. Each player becomes a thief for the duration of the game, and must use all his ingenuity to avoid escape the strict security measures that have been put in place to protect the jewels. All the tools and weapons necessary to carry out the stole have been buried in the Palace Gardens: the Arrayanes's Garden and the Lion's Garden, months before the Opening of the Exhibition, and so during the first tour for these two gardens, simulated to be innocent visitors, the players are collecting the necessary equipment.

The only escape route is through the Mosque located in the northwest corner of the Palace, as the Alhambra is surrounded by walls around its perimeter. There are a powerful off-road vehicle that will take the triumphant thief down the mountain with the precious booty. If you get it, you will have won and the first pages of the international press will open their editions with "Scandal! Theft of the Century".

Goals of the Game:

The players decide when starting the game which game mode they will play:


Win the first player to steal a jewel and escape.



All jewelry must be stolen, and that player who gets the most value by adding the points of the jewels obtained is the one that wins. In case of a tie, the thief who holds the Recesvinto's Crown will win.

name: Dogs Night Out: Poker School
description:
Description from the publisher:

Get ready for a thinking player's game. Dogs Night Out Poker School will not only make you think about your plays, but you will have fun leaving your money off the table. Whether you are new to Texas Holdem or a long time player, your're going to gain an understanding of the game that you have never had before. Gambling is not required.

Two complete games! OUT CARD (the more challenging game) and FIVE BALL POKER (the simpler game). Play with friends, teach friends, play solo. No Matter how you choose to play, you will continuously be improving the game.

Out Card
An entertaining, innovative approach using a combination of tools to analyze a poker game. A visual representation of a poker hand makes it easier to see winning possibilities. Numbering Out Cards in priority order is a challenge that will improve your poker game. This game can be played with friends as a challenge or teaching tool, or play solo for individual learning.

5 Ball Poker
Learn to analyze the top current and best potential hands at five different analysis points represented by Pool balls in a street map format. A simple, yet important tool for your poker game, showing the road to the money hand.

name: Dumb A** the Card Game
description: Be the first player to answer four cards correctly to win. The game contains 96 question cards (18 Hard Ass and 26 each Who, What, and Where cards) with instructions. The reader announces four items that all appear to have a correlation. Players then choose which item they feel does not belong. Each player gets only one try at answering each card. The first player to yell out the correct answer earns the card. If no player answers correctly, the reader wins the card. The player to the left of the reader becomes the new reader.

name: Murder: il Gioco di Carte
description:
Detective Boso has been murdered! Suspicious falls on some of the main characters of his previous investigations.
Every player will have to gather as much clues as he can to solve the riddle and bring the suspected to the trial: you choose randomly the color of your suspect and noone knows it. Every players receive four cards with three cubes random coloured: every cube is a clue that lead to the suspected of the same color. You choose to play the card that maximize the gathering of clues for your suspected pay attention not to be discovered and minimizing the clues for the suspected of other colors.
The game is based on a mix of strategy and luck, but mostly on bluffing skills.

name: Mouth Trap
description: This is a light party game in which players take it in turns to read out phrases drawn from a deck of cards while wearing one of the included "Mouth Traps" which impede the player's speech. Their teammates attempt to guess the most phrases being read within the time limit. The team or player (in a 3 player game) with the most correctly guessed phrases wins and the loser must perform a forfeit drawn from a deck of cards.

name: Campus Mundi
description:
Game about World Youth Day consists of 64 cards - illustration depicting the young pilgrims in scenes typical of the events of World Youth Day: among others, adoration, during a concert or gathered around the Pope's moving in the popemobile.
The task of the players is to direct the movement of pilgrims to be combined in appropriate groups, according to the dynamically changing criteria. The gameplay counts perceptiveness and speed. The game is developed in a way that does not require verbal communication between players. So they can play it by people of different languages.

Both sides of the cards are important. One of them is showing the scene with the pilgrims, the other one of the 16 features which are showed on the cards. Player one by one take card from the pile and lay out near the card pile. The top card on the pile shows what features on the cards the player are looking for. For example if the card on the card pile shows red clothes players are checking is there at least three cards with this features. If yes whoever will be the first to notice this and put his hand on the pile is the winner of the round. He will take two cards as a reward. After that next person lay out the next cards from the card pile. So feature which players have to looking for is changing continually.

The winner is the person which have the most cards at the end of the game.

name: Flower Fairy: Dominoes
description:
Flower fairy Rosalina is waking up at the beginning of spring and sees that buds are about to open everywhere in the meadow. She quickly sets to work, waves her magic wand, and awakens the other flowers and plants as well. Who can help Rosalina bring the meadow into bloom and entice the bugs and butterflies out of their hiding places? A flowery classic matching tile based game.

--description from the publisher

name: StoryCards: Die drei ??? Kids – Spuk im Schloss
description: StoryCards: Die drei ??? Kids – Spuk im Schloss is a storytelling game of sorts in which a player or team is confronted by a situation that presents them with two options for a journey. Which way should they go to solve the mystery? Once they choose, they lay down the card, then search for the appropriately numbered card that they chose. The more cards they lay down, the more they score. If a card is no longer available, however, then the game ends and the detective trio has failed.

name: Emoji 2
description:
From the publisher

The intuitive gameplay, different levels of difficulty and different game modes offer a satisfying puzzle experience. The independent Emoji 2 also provides for many new funny puzzles. Thus, unsuspecting players soon become uncontrolled puzzles, which they can assemble with the new cards themselves.

name: Sabrina Stachelschwein
description:
Bang, pow! Someone didn't think ahead clearly when the animals' balloon party was planned and Sabrina the porcupine was invited.

In Sabrina Stachelschwein, each player has a number of balloon cards on the table in front of them, with the balloons having different values and all of the balloons being placed in a circle. Sabrina wants to say "hello" to all of her friends, so she keeps running around the circle, with her movement determined by a die roll. Wherever she stops, the balloon pops, with that card being placed on a discard pile. Sabrina can circle in either direction, and players can add new balloons to the table as well.

Once one player runs out of balloons, the game ends, and whoever owns the most valuable balloons wins.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Memory, Roll / Spin and Move, Track Movement

name: Dust Tactics: USMC Observer Squad – "Artillery Scouts"
description: The Marines have arrived in the Middle-East! Nothing as efficient as a good artillery barrage to keep the enemy on its toes... Thanks to these observers, regimental and division artillery pieces can deliver the most powerful punch to crush the enemies of the Allies.
categories: Miniatures, Science Fiction, Wargame, World War II
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Modular Board

name: Das Spiel mit dem Essen
description: In Das Spiel mit dem Essen, players move their pieces around the plate on the game board that's divided into different food groups and attempt to answer food-related questions in order to win chips — and no, not potato chips, but point chips!

name: Shake, Rattle & Roll
description:
The game is a handheld dome containing 15 dice (5 red, 5 yellow, 5 blue) and whose base contains a 4x4 grid of slots for the dice to settle into.

The object is to shake and rattle the dome so that 4 dice of the same color form a straight line or a square. You score the sum of the numbers on the dice in that line or square. A diagonal counts double, and a center square counts triple.

name: Bushido: Junichi
description: The conch blower has made the role his own and is held up as an example of how auxiliary support should operate in the forces of Ryu. Renowned for his ability to reinvigorate the soldiers around him with his rallying calls, Junichi simply states to new recruits ‘When you hear the call, try harder’.
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Variable Player Powers

name: Captain Jack Pott
description:
In this pirate game you have to find the chest which is hiding Jack Pott's treasure and after getting it be the first to make it to the canoe to win the game. For playing the game you need a free app that guided you through the whole game.

When it's your turn you roll the dice within the app and walk with your pirate figure the eyes number on a symbol on the game board. Depending on what figure your move ends you interact with the app which tells you what happens next or what you have to do. The game board shows a pirate ship which is devided in different parts. In each part is a treasure chest which maybe hides the treasure of Jack Pott.

The app uses augmented reality to scan the game board and it shows animations of the different characters which guided through the game

name: Warhammer 40,000: Sanctus Reach – The Red Waaagh!
description:
Description from the publisher:

This 112 page hardback book introduces the Sanctus Reach campaign fought on the Knight world of Alaric Prime. Inside you will find: Waaagh! Grukk, which is the story of the Red Waaagh! and its attack upon Alaric Prime. There are eleven scenarios that allow you to refight the battles of the Red Waaagh!

There is one Imperial Knight Formation datasheet, two Astra Militarum Formation datasheets and two Ork Formation datasheets.

Also adds rules to Warhammer 40,000 for Planetary invasions called Planetstrike and the Planetstrike mission: Planetfall.
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Science Fiction, Wargame

name: The Plane Game
description:
The object of this math-game is to stay in the air, avoid the thunderclouds while collecting as many golden points as possible.

On your turn you roll dice to gather lift-points which you need to keep your plane in the air. You´ll have to gain altitude by spending lift points or save points by descending. But beware, if you drop of the board the game is over. It will get increasingly harder to stay in the air. With every level the amount of lift points needed to gain altitude rises.

The goal in Solo play is to beat the game, level 13, with as many golden points as possible. In a multiplayer game, the player who stays in the air the longest time is the winner.
categories: Aviation / Flight, Dice, Educational, Math, Maze, Print & Play
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Modular Board, Push Your Luck, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Mont-à-Mots Gribouillis
description:
Mont-à-mots Gribouillis est un jeu de dessin où petits et grands doivent faire preuve de dextérité.

Fais tourner le crayon de la roulette et laisse le sort décider de ce que tu devras dessiner : un objet, un personnage ou le contenu d’une carte « Défi surprise ». Dessiner les yeux fermés ou avec ta main la moins habile ou sans lever le crayon sont au nombre des défis à relever. Et sois sans crainte, des cartes de jeu s’adressent aussi aux débutants.

Mont-à-mots Gribouillis is a dexterity drawing game for all ages.

You turn the "Pencil Roulette" and it will give you the type of drawing you will have to do : an object, a character or follow the directions on the "surprise challenge" card. Drawing with your eyes closed or with your non-dominant hand or without lifting the pencil are among the challenges you will have to face. And for the youngsters there's also a set of special cards just for them.
categories: Action / Dexterity, Children's Game, Party Game

name: Historia: gra karciana
description:
Historia: gra karciana is a card game for 2-4 players who play in either Middle Ages, Modern or Contemporary times epoch and use famous historical personas, symbols or military units to win the outcomes of the historical events.

The goal of the game is to score Victory Points, by:

winning the events
generating Culture
winning wars


The game consists of 4 rounds (3 for 3 players), in each round one historical event is active (events are sorted chronologically). Players manage the resources of their factions (politics, economy, science, culture) in a way similar to euro games and use them to put into play personas, symbols and units. Players perform actions one by one, until they all pass (or are out of resources). Then the winner of the current historical event is determined.

There are 12 factions in the core set, grouped into the following "clashes":

Polish-Teutonic Wars: Poland vs Teutonic Knights Order
Hundred Years' War: England vs France
"Deluge": Poland vs Sweden
Thirty Years War: Habsburg Monarchy vs France
Polish-Bolshevik War: Poland vs Soviet Union
I World War: UK vs Germany
categories: Economic, Medieval, Political, Post-Napoleonic, Renaissance, World War I
mechanics: Action Points, Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Trading, Turn Order: Time Track

name: Swordplay 2015
description:
What: A free introduction to the Reaction System used by Two Hour Wargames.
Scale: Man-to-man sword and shield combat. 1 figure equals 1 man.
Your Role: You lead a small group of 1 to 5 figures in a series of man-to-man scenarios.
Playability: Designed for solo, same side and head to head play.
Sword Play 2015 allows you to learn the Reaction System used by THW without spending a dime.

While our counterpart Chain Reaction is about modern firearms, Swordplay is about hand-to-hand combat with sword and shield .

It's an entry level, free look, into THW games, that works well for any period, including Fantasy, when it was all about swords, bows, and shield.

Swordplay gives you a chance to see if you like the Reaction System, before trying one of our period specific games. Think of SP 3.1 as a preview. The nice thing is it contains the same mechanics, but less detailed and period specific, of our other games.

Replaced by Swordplay 2018.

name: Relic Knights: 2nd Edition
description:
Relic Knights: 2nd Edition is an anime-themed miniatures skirmish game featuring breathtaking models from Soda Pop Miniatures. In this dynamic miniatures game you control a heroic Knight and their enigmatic cypher. Fighting at their side are the warriors, psychics, and soldiers of the Last Galaxy. Relic Knights features a diceless, card-based game mechanic that puts you in control of your forces through managing esper to unleash devastating attacks, gallant defenses, and achieve strategic goals on the field of battle.

This is a brand new edition of Relic Knights, featuring a fully updated rulebook, resculpts of many existing models, all new models to expand and customize your forces, the first Relic Knights expansion book—Void Break—and a brand new 2-Player Starter to make it easier than ever to join the battle for the fate of the Last Galaxy!

name: Ivanhoe
description:
One side of the board has a simple roll and run game. The first player to reach space 120 wins th game. On some spaces events hinder or benefit the players.

The game on the other side of the board can be discribed as "roll, run and collect". On some spaces the players can collect small cards, worth different amounts of points. If a figure gets on an occupied space it robs the cards the other figure is "carying". Cards may be brought to safety by using the shortcuts into the caste along the way.

The game ends when all players are back in the castle, but only if one player has found the card with Ivanhoe's coat of arms. If not, the players have to continue the game till one finds this card and thereby ends the game. The player with the most points wins the game.
categories: Book, Medieval, Movies / TV / Radio theme
mechanics: Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: Bushido: Gengo
description:
A man of excesses, Gengo was attracted to the Cult to satisfy his more base urges. He finds the sacrifice of others particularly appealing. One shouldn’t underestimate the difficulty in taking such a big man down.

Blister contains one miniature, one30mm base and one full colour profile card.
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Variable Player Powers

name: La Pour'Suite Masquee
description: The Masked Pursuit is a fast-paced card game for 2-4 people where all players play at the same time. Place your cards as fast as possible and before your opponents. The fastest wins!

name: Stapelspiele: Minimonster
description:
Stack the monsters to form a giant pyramid! Who can match the dowels with the colors of the monsters and carefully slide them in between each figure without knocking them down?
5 quick games with varying rules and difficulty levels to provide engaging play and stacking fun for toddlers two and up. With entertaining options for older kids as well.
Each game varies slightly in its complexity which means as your child grows, you can advance to harder games or harder versions of the games you already know.
Contents include: 12 stacking monsters, 12 plugs, 1 stacking frame, 4 tiles, 1 die and set of instructions.
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Memory, Pattern Building, Pattern Recognition

name: Hot Cross Bunnies
description: The goal of the game is to move your pawn to the finish while moving across a grid reaching numbers on Easter-egg-tiles from 1-24 in the right order. In your turn you roll two dice and move forward if you can. Bunnies are sometimes in your way and by spending coins you can move quicker. Make sure you reach the finish the first and you will win.
mechanics: Grid Movement, Modular Board, Point to Point Movement

name: Color Slap!
description:
Color Slap Card Game

The Slap the Splat card game!

Slap your way to victory in this test of color coordination and fast reflexes.

Players take turns placing cards face up in a pile.
Whenever a card showing a splat with matching text is flipped, players must race to Slap the Splat and win the pile!

Easy right? Things get crazy with splat cards with no text and splat cards with non matching text.

Whoever gets the most cards wins!

name: Bulls & Bears
description:
Description from the designer:

A fun, interactive family board game that teaches you how to get smart about money. Players make real-life investment and career decisions, learn to balance their portfolios and plan for retirement, manage budgets and debt, and answer questions on fundamental principles of economics and finance. No prior experience needed.

Players start out with $100,000 cash, roll the dice, and proceed around the board. Spaces on the board correspond to different life events such as getting paid a salary, going on vacation, or picking from the three decks of cards that sit at the center of the board. The three decks of cards are: news flashes, knowledge cards, and wild cards. Newsflashes provide a news story, and players must buy and sell investments accordingly in order to win or lose money. Users may accept advice from other players for a shared win or loss in the investment. Knowledge cards are multiple choice cards that teach users key finance information that will be used in the game and life. Wild cards are life events that will cause the loser to win or lose money depending on whether or not they own the right assets. To win, a user must double their money and own a home, life and health insurance, and a retirement plan.

There are several levels of game play that allow for beginner users all the way through advanced users to play the game and be continually challenged. Additional card decks are available through our company website as they become available.
categories: Card Game, Deduction, Dice, Economic, Educational, Math
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move, Trading

name: Chica Loca
description:
An educational game about utilizing addition, multiplication, and number color matching. The game is played in rounds utilizing 5 cards in which each player must follow the color or number prior. At the end of each round the players add or multiply the cards in front of them and the one with the greatest sum is the winner. They are given a golden egg which are the victory points. The one with 3 or the predetermined number of golden eggs is the overall winner.

This is definitely a children's teaching game.

name: P.Y.G.: Pretty Young Girl
description: P.Y.G. or Pretty Young Girl is a card hand management game of romantic affection theme. In this game, he who has the closest numbered card to the open goal card (pretty young girl's heart) number at the end of each round wins that round and takes 2~3 points according to the position. After several rounds the game ends when there is less than 2 untaken points and the player with most point wins the game.
publishers: オトコマエゲームズ (OTOKOMAE GAMES)

name: Bay of Bengal (fan expansion for Ticket to Ride)
description:
This map is an unofficial fan made expansion. Symbols & Graphics Copyright © 2004-2015 Days of Wonder, Inc. Produced with permission of Days of Wonder, for non-commercial use only.

This follows the principles of the basic Ticket to Ride Rails and Sails game on a special board with special cards and rules. The object of the game is to gain the most points by travelling various routes and outwitting other players. You will need all the train and ship pieces, the train and ship cards and the rules from the base game.

There is an extra set of Explorer cards for the cities, each with a value to be earned by visiting that city. These cards are dealt/picked up alongwith tickets in the same quantity and with the same 'keep/dispose' rules.

There are also Challenger cards which may help or hinder you. The 9 bonuses and the secret city card give you extra points.

There are many new options in the rules such as 'exchange all your cards at the start but keep all the new ones' and 'discard 5 cards and pick up 5 new ones'.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Fan Expansion, Print & Play

name: Reise durch Kreise!
description: Each player has nine pawns. Movement is determined by a die and is permitted in all directions. The players begin at the nine starting spaces at their side of the game board. The first player to get his nine pawns to the starting spaces of his opponent wins the game. It is not permitted to jump over opposing pawns. So, the players are able to block each others movement by placing pawns in the path of their opponents.
mechanics: Grid Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Legends of Baseball
description:
Description from the publisher:

Legends of Baseball (LOB) brings the all time greatest players to life on your tabletop. LOB is fun and fast paced dice and card game for 1 or 2 players. Ninety percent of plays are resolved in 1 die roll and no play takes more than 2 rolls. Game times range from 20 to 30 minutes.

The 'Legends of Baseball' series uses the 2nd Edition of the Pine Tar dice game engine . The individual cards are made with a 12 point 305gsm black-core matt card stock. This provides excellent color quality, sheen, and snap back. Cards are poker sized (2.5 x 3.5")

name: ワイルドゴールド (Wild Gold)
description:
In the card game ワイルドゴールド (Wild Gold), players create tools from cards and use them to dig a gold mine.

At the start, each player has a "small axe" made of one stone card and one wood card. In the play area are item cards — wood, stone, iron, and fire — and treasure cards. As players collect item cards in their hand, they can assemble various tools, such as a "big axe", "small pickaxe", "spear", and "wood bomb".

Each tool is assembled by placing the item cards in the shape of the tool. With the "small axe", a player can draw one card from the play area. With the "big axe", a player can draw two cards. With the "small pickaxe", players choose and take one card from the discard pile. With the "spear", a player can draw one card from another player's hand and snatch it if it's a treasure card. With the powerful "wood bomb", players choose to draw four cards from the play area or draw one card from each player's hand and snatch the cards if they're treasure cards.

The active player can have only up to seven items in total of the cards in their hand and their tools. Because of this, the player may have to discard some tools or treasure cards in their hand. The game ends when a player gains 10 points through treasure cards.
mechanics: Action Queue, Hand Management, Pattern Building, Push Your Luck

name: Duplicitous
description:
Duplicitous is a light, simple, bluffing game of truth and deception for 2-players that plays in 5 minutes and uses only 9-cards.

Each player is dealt 1 card and a common deck of 7 cards is setup. On a turn the start player draws a card and announces the card to be either a colour or number. Their opponent must determine if they are telling the truth or if they are lying.
The winner collects the card face-up and the process repeats until all 7 cards are played - the player with the most cards at the end of the round is the winner.

Duplicitous was designed for the The 2017 9-card Nanogame PnP Design Contest.

name: Bushido: Shichiro
description: “Rotten to his core,” was how Shichiro’s own mother described him, even before he left with the last of the families meagre savings. Joining the cult wasn’t chance, it was inevitable for someone like him. He relishes killing but prefers a well-placed tanto in the back over the risk of direct confrontation.
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Variable Player Powers

name: Kingdom of Heaven: 2nd and 3rd Crusades
description: Kingdom of Heaven: 2nd and 3rd Crusades is an issue game of War Drum Games' wargame mook for beginners "Battle on the Table" #3. The game is solitaire. The player tries to defend the Latin Kingdom of Jerusalem against Muslim invasions. The system was inspired by Victory Point Games' Cruel Necessity.

name: Twilight of the Reich: The Berlin Campaign 1945
description: Twilight of the Reich: The Berlin Campaign 1945 is an issue game of War Drum Games' wargame mook for beginners "Battle on the Table" #4. The game is basically played by two players. Soviet player tries to occupy the whole of Berlin, German player tries to prevent it.

name: Revenge of the Blank
description:
Revenge of the Blank is a light party game, where players write witty responses to prompts like:
An odd item that Batman keeps on his utility belt is ______.
A talking doll should NOT say “______” when you pull its string.
A fortune teller once told me I would live a life full of ______.

How To Play
1)Players are dealt a certain amount of Prompt cards depending on total number of players and desired game length.

2)One player "The Judge" reads a prompt off one of the cards they were dealt at the start of the game.

3)Everyone else then writes a response to the prompt.

4)Once all answers are submitted The Judge then selects their favorite and awards the player who wrote it the card with the prompt.

5)The player to the left of The Judge becomes The Judge and play continues like this until all the cards dealt out at the start of the game have been awarded to other players.

6)The player with the most cards wins.

name: MoonQuake Escape: Access Card
description:
Access Card is a promo card for MoonQuake Escape. It is an Equipment card and with it a player may "aim and use [a] Tractor Beam or Defense Gun, or Launch Rocket".

It was released as part of a three card promotion pack called the All Access Promo Pack, which included the Mug Shot card, Access Card card, and a bonus rules card. All three cards were packaged in a single card sleeve.
mechanics: Action Points, Grid Movement, Modular Board

name: Aardvarks vs Aardvarks
description:
Players travel around a world they created one card at a time. Players grab ants and race home before other players can garb the.m You can attack other aardvarks, build a home, and raid their other aardvark homes to steal ants. Be the first player to get three ants safely home and keep them there to win.

The cards in the game are used for all elements of play, building the map, moving the players, constructing houses, and attack others.
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Pick-up and Deliver

name: Piraci: Karaibska flota – Atak Hiszpanów
description:
Can be used on any round and is put out of the game thereafter.

After bidding, the winner of the bidding puts entire sum to the bank. It is not split among players!

The card was added to 23th issue of Świat Gier Planszowych magazine.
categories: Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Pirates

name: Crazy Doodles
description:
A drawing game involving headbands.

You have a drawing-board on your forehead, and take a card which tells you what to draw on the board. Points for correct guesses to both drawing and guessing player.

name: Cypher Math
description:
Cypher is a fast-paced math game for both children and adults. 5-15 minute rounds. The object of the game is to win the most cards.

Includes 55 cards high quality per deck. 44 Number Cards. 9 Operation Cards, 2 Times Table Cards, and Instructions.

A great supplement or alternative to flash cards.

Win cards by being the first to yell out the correct answer. Easy to learn and is adaptable to different children's abilities. Perfect for 3-6 players, Ages 8+

Operations in the game include addition, subtraction, and multiplication.
categories: Card Game, Children's Game, Educational, Math, Number

name: Dinotopia: First Flight Board Game
description:
Dinotopia: First Flight is the third Dinotopia book written by James Gurney. The first edition of the book included a fold-out board game. The front cover opens up to reveal an easy-to-learn board game. By Detaching the game cards from the back of the book, players can join Gideon on his adventures, experiencing his crushing setbacks and his high-flying triumphs.

There are a set of other Orange cards to the game I think that they are used to move around the foldout game board in the James Gurney book, I found and bough a second hand copy fo the book for my son and daughter but thee were some of the blue cards that you have displayed on your site missing from the book that I bought I was unaware of this at the time, but have since seen other copies of this book avalaible for sale. they have been quite expensive as the books by this author are now very collectable.
categories: Book, Card Game, Children's Game, Prehistoric

name: Zootopia: Mafia in the City
description:
The king of the underworld Mr. Big and his gang are intimidating civilians, forcing them to flee the city. The time has come to rein in the carousing bandits.

The game is based on the classic, Mafia. Good citizens with the help of police are trying to expose the criminals and the bandits. Good citizens should find the bandits. Bandits' goal is survive till the end while citizens fighting against each other.

The mechanics of Mafia have been simplified for children, keeping the deduction part but removing the "killing" of other players. Child friendly cards identify which team the player is on and what special powers/hidden roles they have. As with traditional Mafia, the goal of the game is to find all the Bandits, before the good players are all exiled from the game.
categories: Animals, Card Game, Children's Game, Deduction, Movies / TV / Radio theme
mechanics: Deduction, Hidden Roles, Negotiation, Role Playing, Team-Based Game, Variable Player Powers

name: Hot Seat: Even More Expansion
description:
Description from the publisher:

Been through the original game a few times over? Know every question by heart? Freshen up the Hot Seat with all new questions that will keep everyone at game night on their toes.

These cards are similar in nature to the cards included in the original game.
Hot Seat is required to play this expansion.
categories: Bluffing, Card Game, Deduction, Expansion for Base-game, Humor, Mature / Adult, Party Game

name: Westfront: Tabletop Game for the First World War
description:
Description from the publisher:

Westfront is a company to battalion level game for WW1 forces, designed for 1/72, 15mm or 10mm miniatures. Smaller scales could also be used.

Westfront is designed with simplicity in mind, but since it represents communication issues, orders from above, random events like units becoming lost, as well as the actual movement and attacking of the various types of forces, it can become quite in-depth.

Westfront has a fairly free-form army list composition; allowing players to choose infantry, cavalry, vehicles, various types of artillery, fortifications and barbed wire at their will. Units behave historically, and 4 different theaters are available to play in. Some will have a higher chance of poor weather, and if the entire tabletop is mud units like armored cars simply wont be able to function. Thankfully season is determined before players write their army lists, so they will know ahead of time what to expect.

Westfront covers the evolution of the war and the changes in doctrines and units involved;

Early war (1914 - 1915) will have only the most rudimentary artillery usage in preliminary bombardments, and only the basic units available (no tanks!).

Mid War (1916) will see the standardization of the creeping artillery barrage (which really works in-game: artillery provides cover as troops advance, and causes enemies to keep their heads down if it explodes near them), indirect machine gun fire and of course the introduction of the first Mk.I tanks.

Late war (1917 - 1918) will see advanced infantry tactics like Germans advancing machine gun teams through creeping barrages to set up in no mans land, and the introduction of more refined tanks and German anti-tank rifles.

Westfront provides army lists for the Allied forces and the Central Powers, covering most of the units available. 3 qualities of infantry and cavalry are available (sup-par, regular and assault/veterans), and artillery is broken into 4 categories: Trench mortars like the minenwerfer or stokes mortar, flat-firing field guns like the 37mm maxim, and the various 77mm German guns (these have varying ranges depending on the specific gun), howitzer batteries like the 18-Pdr or 15cm SFH, and heavy howitzers like the 42cm Mörser or the BL 12-Inch. Fortifications are covered, with shallow and deep trenches, dug outs and pillboxes all available

Westfront aims to give fun games around 2 hours long and to give a WW1 feel for the players. Much research has been done based on the accounts of actual combatants, attempting to implement some of the important features for those on the ground. For example a forward unit on the attack may start to run low on ammunition, so could send a runner back to request supplies, but the runner may get killed along the way... Another example might be a friendly unit capturing an enemy trench, only to get shelled by friendly artillery controlled by H.Q. They desperately send a runner back to their lines to tell the barrage to stop, but it will take a few turns for the order to get through...
categories: Book, Miniatures, Wargame, World War I

name: Wartime Easy Money
description:
While Canadian publisher Somerville clearly licenced the name Easy Money from Milton Bradley, it published a very different version of MB's 1935 game during WWII and for a short period of time afterwards (dropping the word wartime from the title). The Monopoly-like mechanics are the same: roll and move, buy properties and businesses and make money. In this version of Easy Money a player keeps playing/moving their token until throwing a “seven”.

While the MB board had 48 spaces, the wartime Canadian game has only 28 spaces (six spaces and only two properties per side plus four corner spaces labelled "Town Square" (start); Hospital; Victory Bonds; and Income Tax. In addition, there is an inner Chance Circle of 24 spaces, each tied to one of the side spaces. Players who throw doubles on 2D6 take the result from the corresponding inner circle space without moving, and then roll again.

The theme of wartime sacrifices is strongly represented: even when collecting $200 for passing the Town Square, $100 must be donated to the Victory Bond space, and a player landing on Victory Bonds takes only half the money there. There also are spaces for Blackout Regulations, Air Raid Defense Plan, Soldiers Welfare Project, War Project and Red Cross Project on the outer square, and spaces for Buy War Savings Stamps and Extra Call for Victory Bonds on the inner circle.
mechanics: Investment, Ownership, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Stock Holding, Track Movement

name: 50 Overs Cricket
description:
Board game that simulates limited over cricket.

It can be played by any even number of players (teams), but is ideally suited to two players. Each player bats and bowls for one innings (50 overs).

Once play order is established the bowler determines the type of bowler for the next over by a dice roll. They then place their fielders on the board in setting that matches this type of bowler. Then outcome (and runs scored) of each delivery is determined by drawing a card from a deck of cards. Each card has six possible outcomes, however the outcome is determined by the bowler type (fixed for this over) and therefor is typical to a batsmen playing a delivery from that type of bowler. A well placed field by the bowler should ensure lower scores from the batting team.

Each over consists of four deliveries, so each innings is therefore 200 balls.

The game can be played with or without a scoresheet as a simple magnetic scoring grid (with markers) is printed on the game board.

The winner is the player who amasses the most runs.

From the rules booklet "To play a Board game of cricket in the true spirit of the cricketing tradition. To foster a deeper interest and understanding of the tactical skill required in the National summer sport."

Manufactured & Published locally in NZ by F.T. Connor (Blenheim)

Contents

1 Game Board
100 Cards
9 Fielding Tokens
1 Standard Die
1 Rulebook
1 Pad of score sheets
3 Scoring tokens

name: Superbeings Jumbo Card Game
description:
Description from the publisher:

In the Battle Universe, the Alliance Wars between Nlife (natural life made up of Humans and Aliens) and Alife (artifical life made up of Androids, Beasts and Clones) continues to rage on. Furthermore, Xlife (divine super creatures known as Xpets) have been summoned by the HA Masterbeings to intervene as Alife led by Andromeda will not stop until they control all worlds of Nlife. Superbeings from all corners of the universe have taken their sides; it's the rise of the Superbeings Battle Universe!

Superbeings is a relaunch of the anime-styled Humaliens Trading Card Game released in 2003 by AEG with a new design and storyline by creator Rick Medina. Superbeings features a 6-Super Team concept of playing with multiple frontline attackers and multiple backline reinforcements with the objective to win by one of three ways: (1) knocking out your opponent's entire frontline, (2) knocking out a total of 5 Supers, or (3) knocking out 15 rank points worth of Supers. The game uses a variety of D6, D12 and D20 dice-rolling mechanics for establishing turn actions, attacks, and more.

The traditional two-player heads-up game is the easiest to start with and is the preferred play style — but when the opportunity for a massive four-player game is called upon, there's an entirely different feel to the game!
mechanics: Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Hand Management, Open Drafting

name: Horrible Hordes
description:
A Fantasy Board game for 1-6 Players played over 20 rounds on a 10x10 square grid.

At the beginning of the game tiles are placed on to the grid randomly in a checkerboard pattern. There are 50 Terrain Tiles, 10 for each of the 5 Types:
Mountain (Stone)
Forest (Wood)
Farms (Food)
Hills (Metal)
Swamp (Magic)

There is a pool of Horde Counters. Each is unique.
Each Counter has the name of the Horde plus 4 Traits:
1. Type (Humanoid, Undead, or Monster)
2. Attack (Target roll this Horde needs to get or higher to hit)
3. Defence (Subtracted from player attack rolls vs this Horde)
4. Hits (Number of Hit Counters placed under this Horde)

Each player has a set of Army Tokens and Settlement Markers of a unique colour.

Players share a common set of Castle Markers.

Players share a common set of Resource Chits:
Stone (Grey)
Wood (Brown)
Food (White)
Metal (Blue)
Magic (Red)
Gold (Yellow)

Each player gets a Player Sheet which includes
- The Kingdom List
- The Ability List
Players should mark off what Kingdom they are and what abilities they have when they get them.

Player settlements are placed randomly on the board (as determined by a dice roll). Settlements cannot be within 2 spaces of each other.

For each player 1 Horde is placed on a board (also determined by dice roll). These starting hordes cannot be placed on or adjacent to a settlement and not on another horde.

Players take turns.
Each turn has 11 Phases:
1. Event Phase
- Roll once (1D10) on the Event Table and resolve.
2. Resource Phase
- Gain 3 free resources of any type.
- For each terrain occupied by one of your settlements gain 1 extra resource of the type produced by that terrain.
3. Trade Phase
- You may convert 2 gold into 1 resource of any other type.
- You may trade/gift resources with other players who have settlements adjacent to yours.
4. Settle Phase
- You may build 1 settlement. The cost to build the settlement is 2 food and 3 wood.
5. Fortify Phase
- You may build 1 castle on one of your settlements. The cost to build the castle is 4 stone.
6. Train Phase
- You may build armies on one of your castles. The cost to train an army is 1 food, 2 metal, and 1 wood.
7. Move Phase
- You may move your armies to an adjacent space. It costs 1 food to move all the armies in 1 stack (max of 4 armies).
8. Attack Phase
- If your armies and a horde occupy the same space, there will be a battle. Gain a Victory Token every time you destroy a horde stack.
9. Research Phase
- Pick one ability from the Research List.
- You may gain an extra ability for the cost of 10 resources.
10. Spawn Phase
- A new horde appears on the board.
- After turn 10 two hordes appear on the map!
11. End Phase
- Max resource chits you can hold is 7. Discard excess chits.

At the end of a round (when all Players have taken 1 turn) there will be a Horde Segment and a Raid Segment.

Horde segment
- Each Horde will move under a prescribed set of rules.
Raid Segment
- This is handled exactly like Attack Phase except that now castles and settlements are involved in the Battles. They function similar to Armies except that Settlements hit on a roll of 8+ and Castles hit on a roll of 7+. Victory Tokens are gained every time you destroy a Horde Stack.

At the end of the game (20 rounds), the player with the most Units (Settlements, Armies, and Castles) plus Victory Tokens wins.

name: The Hunger Game
description:
A card game based on the Hunger Games first Book and Movie. This primarily depicts events within the arena and not outside of it or before or after.

The common deck has 120 cards, one of each described in the card list. There are 12 card types and 10 cards for each type.
Each card has a level ranging from 1 to 10.
6 types hurt. These are the Threat cards:
Thirst, Hunger, Attack, Exposure, Weakness, and Game
6 types help. These are the Protection cards:
Water, Food, Defense, Shelter, Trait, and Sponsor
Threats and protection cards have a 1 to 1 correspondence

Players start the game with an equal number of Tribute Tokens (The exact number is dependant on player numbers).

The game is played over a number of turns with players playing cards in an attempt to cause other players to lose Tribute tokens whilst trying to avoid losing Tribute tokens themselves.

If you have no Tribute tokens left, you are out of the game.

The game end when only one player has a tribute remaining.
That player is the winner.

name: Hydaspes
description:
A Warp Skirmish format game representing the last major battle of Alexander the Great in 326 BC.

One player is Alexander. The other is King Porus of the Hindu Paurava Kingdom.

Play is conducted on a 12 x 7 grid with 4 different terrain types. The Greeks start stacked just North of the river Hydaspes. The Indians start stacked facing them on the South bank of the river.

Victory is achieved by destroying 50% of the enemy force, or the opposing main leader.

name: Indian Territory
description:
Each player controls one North American Indian Tribe. Players use their people to gather food and to raid each other and the white men.

Different types of tokens are used to undertake actions and record progress:
- Population Tokens (PT) are used to conduct actions such as raiding and hunting. Each Population Token represents about 50 People.
- Land Tokens (LT) are used to give access to food and resources.
- Food Tokens (FT) are used to feed your people. They are gained by claiming certain cards.
- Horse Tokens (HT) give advantages to Raids.
- Weapons Tokens(WT) give advantages to Raids.
- Spirit Tokens (ST) have a variety of uses.
- Trade Tokens (TT) represent things like furs and skins or crafted items that are used to trade with whites for things like weapons and horses.
- Craft Tokens (CT) represent an accumulation of skilled labour.

Players share a common Spirit Card deck. Cards are of 2 basic types: Resource Cards and Bonus Cards.
- Resource cards provide tokens and are then Discarded.
- Bonus Cards are placed face-up in front of the owner and provide either a continuous benefit or are discarded for a one-time benefit.

At the start of the game each player gets 10 PT, 10 LT and 10 ST. A player mater is utilised to track the status of the tribe and indicate how the PT are being utilised throughout the game.

The game is conducted over six turns with each turn comprising 9 phases as follows:
1. Season Phase
- Place 7 x no. of players cards from the top of the spirit deck face up.
2. Braves Phase
- Players take turns activating Population Tokens one at a time. An activated PT can hunt (claim a face up spirit card) or go on a raid or go trading.
3. Hunt Phase
- Resolve Spirit Card purchases and conversions as soon as they are claimed. Some Spirit Cards have a purchase cost in tokens. This must be paid immediately. If the purchase cost cannot be paid, the card cannot be claimed. If the Spirit Card is a resource card, immediately gain the indicated type of tokens and then discard the card.
4. Territory Phase
- If you have more LT than PT, gain FT equal to the difference.
- If you have less LT than PT, lose FT equal to the difference.
5. Food Phase
- Each player discards FT equal to their PT.
- If they are short then roll once on a Starvation Table for each FT they are short and resolve results.
6. Raid Phase
- Players take turns conducting Raids.
- Each PT held in reserve conducts its own raid.
- When making a Raid, declare the target of the Raid:
Target Opponent, Non-player Tribe, or White Men.
- Roll for results on the appropriate raid table and resolve accordingly.
7. Trade Phase
- Players may trade Tokens with each other or with white men (using set conversion rates)
8. Encroachment Phase
- Each player rolls once on an Encroachment Table and resolves results accordingly.
9. Spirit Phase
- All unclaimed face-up Spirit Cards are discarded.

The game is played over six turns. At the end of the 6th turn scoring is conducted as follows:
Player with most LT gets 10 VP
Player with most PT gets 9 VP
Player with most HT gets 8 VP
Player with most WT gets 7 VP
Player with most ST gets 6 VP
Player with most CT gets 5 VP
Player with most TT gets 3 VP
Player with most FT gets 2 VP
Player with the most Bonus Cards get 4 VP
If tied in a category, all tied players get the points -1.

The player with the most Victory Points (VP) at the end of the game wins.

If at any point during the game a player loses all his Population Tokens or Land Tokens he automatically loses.

name: Space Battle
description:
Battleship version on hexgrid with spaceships.

Each player deploys his spaceships secretly on a hex grid. Then each player shoots at the other's grid by calling a location. The defender responds by "Hit!" or "Miss!". You try to deduce where the enemy ships are and sink them. First to do so wins.
categories: Children's Game, Deduction, Space Exploration, Wargame

name: Blind Wizard Brawl
description:
Blind Wizard Brawl is phygital card game by Wrench Games.
It's a mini deck building dueling game where players combat to become the most powerful wizards in the land.
Combining classic cards and a digital app, blind Wizard Brawl combines the classic table top staple with the modern convenience of an app.

In a world where magic is the key to all life, wizards are gods. You play as one of the most powerful wizards in the land, however, all power comes at a cost. The magic has taken your sight, leaving you only aware of your own power and the magic you possess.
Using your limited perception of the world, you must use your skills in magic to absorb and unleash magic upon your enemies to become the one true wizard.

How to play:
Each Player has their own private app on their device.
Generate a Wizard on your app. In private.
Separate the cars into three separate stack, one for each type of card: Wave, Growth, and Blaze.
All players take one card from each of these stacks to create their starting deck of three cards. Shuffle your new deck and draw a starting had of two cards.
The game starts with whoever has the worst eyesight or the most magical powers. You decide which.
On each of your turns, you do one of two things:
Do some Wizard Magic (Chant, Cast, or Mind Blast)
Then, draw a card from your deck.
Now, end your turn and play proceeds clockwise.
Any player who dies announces their defeat.
PLAY CONTINUES UNTIL ONLY ONE WIZARD REMAINS.
TO WIN, YOU MUST BE THIS WIZARD, THE GREATEST WIZARD!
mechanics: Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Player Elimination, Rock-Paper-Scissors, Variable Player Powers

name: Labyrinth Quest
description:
A two player card game based on the Labyrinth movie.

There are 2 decks, one for each player:
1. The Sarah Deck
2. The Goblin King Deck

Each card has a Strength value from 3 to 7.
Each card has 1 or 2 Traits (Companion, Help, Action, Location, Foe, Trick). If a card has 2 traits the player must decide which one to use.

Game is played over a number of turns with each turn having 4 Phases:

Magic Phase
- Each player fills their hand to 7 cards from their own deck.

Memory Phase
- Each player may discard up to 4 cards and draw replacements.

Meld Phase
- Each player makes a Meld.
- For the Sarah player the Meld must have:
- Up to 2 Companion cards
- Up to 2 Help cards
- Up to 2 Action cards
- For the Goblin King the Meld must have:
- Up to 1 Location card
- Up to 3 Foe cards
- Up to 3 Trick cards
- Players add up the Strengths of their Meld cards. The player with the higher Total Strength wins the hand. The Goblin King wins ties.

Mettle Phase
- Discard all cards in play.

The first player to win 7 hands wins the game.

name: Numeria
description:
Abstract Board Game for 2 players named after the Roman Goddess of Mathematics.

A standard chessboard is used with a set of 36 tiles numbered from 1 to 36. To start the 36 tiles are placed, face-up on the middle 36 spaces of the Board. Once completed the central 4 tiles are removed an placed, randomly, on the four corners of the board.

The aim of the game is to move tiles around the board in order to make a recognized mathematical pattern of 4 tiles - a Trope.
A Trope can be orthogonal or diagonal and the tiles within a Trope must form a connected line of adjacent tiles. In an orthogonal Trope tiles will share a side. In a diagonal Trope tiles will share a corner.

The numbers within a Trope must be in line in ascending or descending Order so for instance you could have 1, 2, 3, 4 or 4, 3, 2, 1 but not 2, 3, 1, 4 or 4, 2, 1, 3

Types of Trope are:
Consecutive Run --- (Four Consecutive Numbers) - Example: 1, 2, 3, 4 or 8, 9, 10, 11
Multiples Run --- Example: 3, 6, 9, 12 or 8, 12, 16,20
Irregular Repeating Run--- Example: 4, 7, 10, 13 or 13, 17, 21,2 5
Plus 1 Plus 2 Plus 3 Run--- Example: 16, 17, 19, 22
Prime Number Run--- (Must be consecutive Primes) - Example: 1, 2, 3, 5, or 7, 11, 13, 17 or 23, 29, 31, 33
Power Run--- Example: 1, 2, 4, 8 or 4, 8, 16, 32 or 1, 3, 9, 27
Squares Run--- Example: 1, 4, 9, 16 or 9, 16, 25, 36
Triangular Run--- Example: 1, 3, 6, 10 or 6, 10, 15, 21 or 15, 21, 28, 36
Fibonacci Run--- Example: 1, 2, 3, 5 or 3, 5, 8, 13 or 8, 13, 21, 34

Players take turns to play.
On your turn you may move 1 tile. A tile may be moved like a queen in Chess, it may also jump other tiles like in Checkers.
When Jumping, there may be any number of jumps and they may be in any direction, forwards and backwards.

If you make a Trope on your turn remove it from the board and place it in a pile next to you.

The first player to collect 3 Tropes wins.

name: Smoothie
description:
A zest of memory, a pinch of luck and a lot of fruits... By combining their cards with those from the center of the table, players concoct delicious smoothies.
You have 5 card in hands. Put one of the 10 cards of the centre of the table face up:

If you have in your hands one or two card representing the same fruit,you can put all of these card near of you, face up. Every fruit on these cards give you one point!
If that card is represented on the "Super smoothie" card and if you have in your hands one or two fruits requisite, you can put all of these card (the "Super smoothie" card also!) near of you, face up. Every fruit on these cards give you one point!


At the end, the player with the best score win the game!

name: Canon sijoituspeli
description:
A promotial Canon game
From the Box:
Result counts also in Canon investment game. The aim of the players is to make a good economic result using Canon equipment, they acquaire during the game, as effectively as possible to compleet different task they are given during the game.
But only the right equipement in right task will make good results.
There are six Canon-equipement lines in the game: camera and video, microcomputers, copiermachines, text processing equipment, calculators and microfilm machines.
There are different tasks for each category.
During the game players try to acquire different machines and tasks that they can accomplise with those machines. Each complited task will give a sertain profit. The player that has acquired the most profit will win the game.

name: Adult Mad Libs: The Game
description:
Description from the publisher:

In Adult Mad Libs: The Game, players use the word-filled game cards in their hand combined with the sentence card in play to make the most appropriately inappropriate sentences possible. The funniest sentence by popular vote wins the round, and the first player to win three rounds wins the game.

name: MR MEN Shopping Spree
description:
Contents: colorful board game of the city, 4 mr men figures, dice, 7 bus stop cards and 26 shopping cards.

A roll dice and move along the track following the instructions on the board while trying to collect the most shopping cards. Each shopping card has a price on it written in British pounds denominations. The game is over when one player returns back home after going around the board once. Then, shopping cards prices are totaled and the player with highest number wins.
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: Sushi Kappa
description:
You are the gourmet Kappa Samurai.

The Kappa is the traditional fairy in Japan. It lives in a river, and love a cucumber. And the top of the head is the dish.


The player goes to the Sushi chain, and try to eat Sushi!
But the player is the gourmet. He try one Sushi for each kind.
The sushi is 10 kinds, and the player can keep just two Sushis.
So the player need to eat one or two. Then the card is flipped out.
The players cannot see it.
When the pile is out, the game is end.
The players can score the eaten sushi. But the same sushi is not counted.
Additionally, in the game, the player can add the wife and the child.

name: Medicine Show
description:
A card game for 2-4+ players in which players are Snake Oil Salesmen (USA circa late 1800’s) selling their wares.

Players share a common deck. There are 8 types of cards:
N = Name Cards
G = Gimmick Cards
C = Claim Cards
F = Formulation Cards
I = Ingredient Cards
B = Bonus Cards
S = Special Cards
P = Poison Cards
Each player is dealt 7 cards. Players then take turns. Each turn has 4 phases:
1. Draw Phase
- Draw 1 card from the top of the deck and put it in your hand
2. Action Phase
- Discard 1 special card to activate its special effect.
(Poison cards are a type of special card - discard a poison card to cause a target opponent to discard 1 random card from his Victory Pile.)
- Players may trade cards.
3. Meld Phase
- You may make a Meld. A Meld must contain:
- Exactly 1 Name Card
- Exactly 1 Formulation Card
- 1 or 2 Gimmick Cards
- 1 or 2 Ingredient Cards
- 1 or more Claim Cards
- Zero or 1 Bonus Cards
- Each card has a Victory Point (VP) value. Place these Meld cards into your Score Pile. The total VP in your score pile is your Score at the end of the game.
4. End Phase
- Max hand size is 7 cards. Discard excess cards.

The game ends when all players have passed. A player must pass at the end of their turn if there are no cards left in the deck.
The player with the most Victory Points at the end of the game wins.

name: Mughal
description:
A card game for 2-4+ players themed around The Mughal (Mogul, Moghul) Empire (India 1526 - 1712)

The game lasts 7 Turns. Each turn represents the reign of one Emperor:
1. Babur the Tiger (7 for Military) - Early
2. Humayun (3 for Any) - Early
3. Akbar the Great (5 for Building or Military) - Middle
4. Jahangir (3 for Any) - Middle
5. Jahan (7 for Building) - Late
6. Alamgir (5 for Culture or Military) - Late
7. Bahadur (3 for Any) - Late

The middle and late cards are kept out of the deck at the beginning of the game. When turn 3 starts the Middle cards are shuffled into the deck along with the discard. When turn 5 starts, the Late cards are shuffled into the deck along with the discard.

Players share a common deck.
- Each card has a Suite and a Level. The Suites are: Military (M), Building (B), Culture (C), and Wealth (W). A Card with 2 types listed can be used for either.
- Some cards are unique (removed from the game at the end of the turn it is used), others can be only be used in the middle and/or late ages.
- Disaster (D) have no suite and no level bonus. Getting stuck with disaster cards will hurt you in scoring phase.

Each turn has 5 Phases:
1. Destiny Phase
- Each player is dealt 2 cards face up.
2. Fate Phase
- Each player is dealt a hand of 5 cards. These are “face-down”, only the owning player can see them.
3. Action Phase
- Step 1 - Each player selects one card from their hand and places it face up on the table in front of them.
- Step 2 - Players then pass their hand to the next player (on odd turns the next player is to the left, on even turns, to the right)
- Repeat steps 1 and 2 until all cards are played to the table. Each player should have 7 cards face up in front of them.
4. Scoring Phase
- For each suite each player adds up the levels of all their cards in that suite. The player with the highest total level in a Suite gets 2 Victory Tokens. If 2 or more players tie for highest, each one gets 1 VT.
- If you have cards from all 4 Suites gain 2 VT.
5. End Phase
- All cards played this turn go to the discard.

The game ends after 7 turns. The player with the most VT (Victory Tokens) at the end of the game wins.

name: Aristotle's School
description:
Players are students (Junior Members) of Aristotle’s school in Athens Circa 334 - 322 BC. Players move about the Lyceum (Gymnasium and surrounding grounds) to acquire knowledge in a variety of categories and subjects.

The board is composed of 27 tiles, called Lyceum Tiles. The tiles are organised into a circular track in a random order.

Players share a common deck. When a card is played, immediately gain its reward and then discard the card. When the deck runs out the first time shuffle the discard and draw from it.

Players share a set of action tokens. There are 7 types of tokens: Material Cause, Efficient Cause, Formal Cause, Final Cause, Potentiality, Actuality and Aristotle. Actions tokens are used during the game for additional movement, gaining points in various categories, affecting die rolls etc.

There are 6 Categories: Philosophy, Logic, Life Science, Physical Science, Humanities and Arts. Each Category is further divided into 6 Subjects. During play points are earned in individual subjects, however for final end of game scoring, it is the total points earned by subjects within a category that count. Every time you gain a point in a Subject, you also get a corresponding Action Token according to the subjects tables.

Players take turns with each turn consisting of 3 phases:

1. Aristotle Phase
