Aristotle starts the Game in Aristotle’s Library and moves in a clockwise direction 2D6 spaces.
Whenever he lands on a space containing one or more students, they each get 1 point in one random subject (first roll a random category, then a random subject)
If he lands in a space containing no students, the top card of the deck is placed onto that tile. The first student to land there gets that card, as well as the tile’s regular offering.
If you land on Aristotle, you gain 1 Cause Token of any type.
If on your move you pass over Aristotle you gain 1 Aristotle Token.


2. Move Phase

Move your Pawn forward (clockwise around the track) one or two spaces OR you may move forward 1D10 spaces.
You may spend an Action Token to alter your movement.
When you land on 1 or more opponents pawns, you may steal 1 Token from any one of them.


3. Learning

Follow the instructions on the tile you have just moved to. This will usually earn you 1 card or some Action Tokens or 1 point in one specific Subject or a choice on a list, or a roll on a table.


Scores are tracked using paper and pencil.

The game ends when players have gone through the deck twice.
The player with the highest score in the most categories is the winner.
mechanics: Open Drafting, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Aquaman
description:
A card game for 2-4 players with an Aquaman Theme.

Players share a common deck of 8 suites: Aquaman (A), Companion (C), Sea Creature (X), Plot (P), Foe (F), Power (O), Strangeness (S) and Location (L). Each suite comprises 16 cards ranked from 1 to 16.

The board is an 8x8 grid. Each square must be big enough to easily hold 1 card. 1 card is randomly dealt face up to each space on the board. Each player places their pawn on a different corner space (each pawn represents a different manifestation of Aquaman).

Each player draws 3 cards to start.

Players take turns with each turn comprising five phases:

1. Power Phase
- If you have at least 5 cards in your hand, you may discard 1 card from your hand to activate its special ability:
- Aquaman: Draw 2 cards from the deck & put them in your hand. If the sum of the ranks of the 2 cards is less than the rank of the Aquaman card, draw and keep a third card.
- Companion: Look at the next 4 cards in the deck. Keep one and
discard the other 3. The one you keep must be of a lower rank than the Companion Card.
- Sea Creature: Take the top card of discard and put it in your hand.
It must be of a lower rank than the Sea Creature card.
- Plot: You may move your pawn to any target, non-occupied space this turn in Swim phase (do not bother rolling the dice). The card in the target space must be of a lower Rank than the Plot card.
- Foe: Target opponent who is adjacent to you must reveal one random card from his hand; if it is lower in rank than the Foe card it is discarded.
- Power: Discard X cards and draw X replacement cards. The cards you discard may not be of a higher Rank than the Power card.
- Strangeness: Put 1 target adjacent card on the board in your hand. It must be of a lower rank than the Strangeness card. Immediately draw a card to replace it with on the Board.
- Location: Look at the next X cards in the deck where X = the rank of the Location card.

2. Swim Phase

Roll two dice. Move your pawn on the board orthogonally first the distance of one of the dice, and then the distance of the other. For example, you roll a 2 and a 5. You decide to first move him to your left 5 spaces and then forward 2 spaces.


3. Action Phase

If you land on a space not occupied by another pawn, take the card there and put it in your hand. Immediately replace the card you took with the top card of the deck.
If the space is occupied by another player’s pawn, there will be a fight: Both players reveal 1 card from their hand. High card wins. If tied, players reveal a second card. Discard all revealed cards. The winner gets to look at the loser’s hand and steal 1 card.


4. Mission Phase

You may complete a Mission. To do this play (discard) 8 cards from your hand, one from each of the eight suites.


5. Rest Phase

Max hand size is 10 cards. Discard excess cards.


The first player to complete 3 Missions is the winner.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Hand Management, Open Drafting

name: The Battle of Lake Champlain
description:
A board & card game for 2 players themed around the Naval Battle on 11 September 1814. One player is the British. The other is the United States. Historically the US won the battle.

The game board is an 8x8 grid. The centre 4 spaces are Crab Island. Ships may not enter or move or attack through the island.

Each player starts with a number of ships of a variety of types and strengths:
US: 1x Corvette, 1 x Brig, 1 x Schooner, 1 x Sloop, 5 x Gunboats
British: 1x Frigate, 1 x Brig, 2 x Sloop, 6 x Gunboats

Players share a common deck. Cards types are Attack, Defence, Move or Special.

Each player places one Ship on squares of his back 2 rows. Ships may not stack.

Players take turns with each turn comprising 3 phases:

1. Orders Phase
- Draw 3 cards. Max hand size = 5 cards. Discard excess cards.

2. Manoeuvre Phase
- Play (discard) a move card to move one of your ships. The move card has a number indicating the number of spaces the ship moves diagonally or orthogonally. A ship may make 1 move per turn. The Schooner can make 2 moves per turn.

3. Fire Phase
- Play (discard) an attack card to have a ship attack. The attack card has a number indicating the range of the attack. Attacks can be diagonal or orthogonal.
- Every attack does 1 point of damage. A ship reduced to zero hits sinks and is removed from the board.
- Your opponent may play (discard) defence cards to negate your attack.

You win if you Sink/Disable/Capture the opposing Frigate/Corvette, Brig, and 1 Sloop/Schooner.

name: Enders Game Third Formic War Skirmish Game
description:
A two-player card and board game based on the Ender’s War Book.

Play is undertaken on an 8 x 8 grid. The Humans have 2 starships and 8 fighter squads. The Formics have 8 starships and 32 fighter swarms. Fleets start in opposite corners of the play area. Each starship is stacked with 4 fighter units.

Both sides have their own unique deck of cards. Cards are of 4 types: move, attack, defence and special.

Players take turns with each turn having two phases:

1. Strategy Phase

Draw X cards and put them in your hand. For Humans X = 6, for Formics X = 3


2. Action Phase

Use cards to make your units move and attack. The numbers on attack cards indicate the exact range of the attack. The numbers on move cards indicate the exact distance the Unit Moves. Defence cards are used in response to an attack to negate it.
If 2 or more units occupy the same space then a single move card can be used to move them all, however, they must all be moved together to the same destination. Movement is orthogonal or diagonal.
A fighter can move twice but attack only once in a turn.
A starship can move only once, but may attack twice in a turn.


When an attack by a Human unit hits, all enemy units in the space are hit. Any Formic unit hit is destroyed unless a defence card is played.

When a Formic attack hits, only one unit is hit. A Human unit that is hit takes 1 point of damage. Starships or fighter squads with 4 or more damage are destroyed.

Victory is achieved by destroying your opponent’s fleet.
categories: Movies / TV / Radio theme, Science Fiction
mechanics: Grid Movement, Hexagon Grid, Open Drafting

name: Empire of Islam
description:
A bidding game for 2-4+ players in which each player represents a powerful Arab family faction during The Rise of the Caliphate 632 - 750.

The game is played in 10 turns with each turn representing one conquest: Arabia, Palestine, Babylonia, Syria, Egypt, Persia, North Africa, Afghanistan, Spain, Sind

Players share a common set of victory tokens and fate points and a single caliph token

Players share a common deck comprising three card types: Control, Conquest, Culture. Cards have a value of 1, 2 or 3. There are 4 different types of culture cards: Religion, Science, Art, and Custom.

After 10 turns the game ends. The player with the most victory points at the end of the game wins.

name: The Style of Hermes
description:
User summary
ヘルメスの流儀 (Herumesu no ryuugi) The Style of Hermes is a Japanese card game. Gameplay is language free, so whilst the game is published in Japanese, English rules are available online.

In the region where the God Hermes reigns, all fruits produced must be offered to him. Hermes is a god of trade, he determines the true owner of the fruits
by trading. The fruits are first offered to Hermes (placed on the table), then auctioned off by the true owner.

Players have their own deck of cards which represent the fruits produced in Hermes's region. Each turn, you may draw a card from your deck and either offer it to Hermes, placing it onto the table, or keep it as your bidding resource. When you feel the time is ripe, you may instead initiate an auction for all fruits on the table.

In the end, the victory goes to the player who has the greatest total value of fruits.

Publisher's summary
ヘルメスの神域で採取された産物はヘルメスに捧げなければならない！捧げられたのちならば産物は真の所有者のものになるであろう。捧げられた産物はヘルメスの流儀で所有者が決まる。ヘルメスの流儀とは「商い」である！

プレイヤーはヘルメスの神域で採取された果物を持ちゲームをスタートします。果物はいったんはヘルメスに捧げられますが、捧げられたのちに競りによって真の所有者が決定されます。獲得した所有物の価値がもっとも大きければこのゲームに勝利することができるでしょう。
publishers: ガーデンゲームズ (The Garden Games)

name: Sorcerers
description:
A card game for 2 players based on the movie “Sorcerers Apprentice”. One player is the good Merlinians. The other is the evil Morganians.

Players share a common deck containing cards of seven types:
Merlinian Sorcerers, Morganian Sorcerers, Spells, Amplifiers, Objects, Events and Defence. Most cards have a power rating which is used during the duel (combat) phase.

The Merlinian player starts with Balthazar in play and the Grimhold which is equipped to Balthazar. The Morganian player starts with Horvath in play.

Both players draw 5 cards.

Each turn has 6 Phases:

1. Lore Phase
- Both players draw 2 cards from the deck.

2. Recruit Phase
- You may put one sorcerer into play from your hand and any number of objects. Sorcerers may give their objects to each other (max 3 objects per sorcerer). Excess objects are discarded.
- The Merlinian player may only recruit Merlinian Sorcerers.
- The Morganian player may only recruit Morganian Sorcerers.

3. Event Phase
- Starting with the Merlinian player, players may take turns discarding cards with event abilities to activate and immediately resolve those abilities.

4. Encounter Phase
- Each player randomly picks one of their sorcerers to undertake a duel.

5. Duel Phase
- The two Sorcerers who have encountered each other will now fight as follows.
- Each player will make an attack combo which are then revealed simultaneously. For their attack combo each player may play one spell, one event and up to 3 amplifiers
- Derive a power total for each sorcerer = the sorcerer’s power + equipped objects + spell + played event + amplifiers.
- Each player may play up to one defence card. These will cause certain opposing cards to be discarded, thus changing the power totals.
- The sorcerer with the higher power total is the combat winner. The losing sorcerer is discarded.
- The combat Loser may play a protection spell. This prevents the losing sorcerer from being discarded and his objects from being stolen.
- The winner takes the losing Sorcerers objects AND looks at his opponents hand AND then steals one target card from his opponents hand.

6. End Phase
- Max hand size is 5 cards. Discard excess cards.
- Check for Victory Conditions. Record Time Markers.

The Merlinian player has 2 ways to win:
1. Destroy Morgana: Defeat her by 7 or more power in a Combat.
2. Prime Merlinian Succession: Keep Dave Stutler in play for 7 consecutive turns.

The Morganian player has 1 way to win:
Cast the Rising Spell: Keep Morgana in play for 5 consecutive turns.

Both players may win by the following method:
Army of Sorcerers: Have 6 more sorcerers in play than your opponent in the end phase.
categories: Card Game, Fantasy, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Brew Ha Ha!
description:
Brew Ha Ha is a beer-tasting game ...

Players draw 8 cards, sample a beer, then piece their cards together to create a description of what they taste.

The Brewmaster (judge) of each round gets to wield their almighty power to award 2 points:

1 point for their favorite description of the round
1 point for the description they deem most accurate

name: The Byzantines
description:
A card game for 2 players in which players take turns controlling the Byzantine Empire. On a player’s off-turn he represents the many foes of the Byzantines. The game is divided into 3 ages - the first 4 turns are the Early Age, turns 5-8 are the Middle Age, turns 9-12 are the Late Age. Each player will get to be the Byzantines for 6 out of the 12 turns.

Each player starts with 10 Legacy Tokens. The Byzantine Empire starts with 10 Territory Tokens (TT). The most TT it can have is 20. If at any time the Byzantine Empire is reduced to zero or less Territory Tokens the game ends immediately and the current Byzantine player loses 3 Legacy Tokens.

There are 2 decks: The Byzantine Deck and the Foes Deck. Cards are of certain types and have a force value. Some cards are only useable during specific Ages. At the start of the game all Middle and Late Age cards are removed from the decks and set aside. When the Middle Age starts the Middle Age cards are shuffled into the decks. When the Late Age starts the Late Age cards are shuffled into the deck.

Each turn has 6 Phases:
1. Draw Phase
- The Foe player fills their hand to 8 cards.
- The Byzantine player fills his hand to 9 cards in the Early Age, 8 cards in the Middle Age, or 7 cards in the Late Age.

2. Age Phase
- Discard any cards in your hand that are not useable in the current Age and draw replacements. If the discarded cards are from an earlier age, remove them from the game.

3. Redraw Phase
- Each player may discard up to 4 cards and draw replacements.

4. Meld Phase
- Each player makes a Meld.
- A Byzantine meld may have up to 1 leader card, 2 recovery cards, 4 troop cards, 1 negotiation card and 2 legacy cards
- A Foe meld may have up to 1 Northern foe card, 1 Southern foe card, 2 disaster cards (Max 1 Natural Disaster) and 4 troop cards
- If a negotiation card is played, the Byzantine player may discard 1 target Foe card. The Foe player may replace it immediately with another Foe card if he has one in hand.
- Each player totals the force of the cards in his meld. The side with the higher force total wins. If tied the Foe player wins.
- The Byzantine Empire gains or loses Territory Tokens equal to the difference in the Force Point Totals.
- All Meld cards are discarded. Unique Meld cards are removed from play.

5. Legacy Phase
- The Byzantine Player (BP) potentially earns Legacy Tokens (LT). If the Empire lost TT this turn the BP loses 1 LT. If the Empire gained TT this turn the BP gains 1 LT.
- The BP gains LT equal to the legacy value of the legacy cards he played in Meld Phase.

6. End Phase
- If you have cards left in your hand, discard down to 1 card and pass it to your opponent.
- Players switch control of the Emperor Token.

The game ends after 12 turns. The player with the most Legacy Tokens at the end of the game wins.

name: Cossacks
description:
A card game for 2-4 players in which players take on the roles of the Cossacks and their enemies!

Players share a common deck comprising 20 suits. Each suit has 3 cards. The cards have 7 basic characteristics: Enemy, Disaster, Men, Control, Action, Fight and Victory. Each suit performs one or two of these basic characteristics.

There is a common set of Victory Tokens (VT) and Cossack Tokens (CT) and one Hetman Token (HT).

Each player takes the role of one Cossack enemy: Russians, Poles, Ottomans, or Tatars.

Players take turns with each turn comprising 7 Phases:

1. Fate Phase
- You draw 3 cards. You may discard a control card to draw 2 additional cards.

2. Sich Phase
- You may trade cards, CT, and VT with other players.

3. Control Phase
- You may discard a control card to gain possession of the Hetman Token.
- You may discard a disaster card to cause a target player to
discard 3 random cards from his hand.

4. Cossack Phase
- You may discard men cards: If you discard 2 men cards gain 3 cossack tokens (CT); 3 men cards gain 5 CT; 4 men cards gain 7 CT and so on. Add 1 CT if one or more cards are from the same suit.

5. Raid Phase
- To go on a raid, you must be the current Hetman and you must discard 1 enemy card and 1 action card, otherwise skip this phase.
- You cannot play an enemy card corresponding to the role that is yours.
- Roll 3 dice and add them up to get a raid total. Subtract this total from the number of CT you have. If the result is positive gain that many VT. If the result is negative, lose that many VT.
- You may discard a fight card to cause a 1 of the 3 dice to be rerolled or to cause a roll to be reduced by 1.
- Discard all your CT.
- If you won, the player with the role of that enemy loses VT equal to the amount you gained.

6. Glory Phase
- If you are the current Hetman gain 1 VT.
- If you went on a successful raid last phase you may discard 1 victory card to gain 1 VT, 2 victory cards to gain 3 VT, 3 victory cards to gain 5 VT and so on.
- You may also play an enemy card of the same suit of the enemy card you
played in Raid Phase: Gain 3 VT for each such card played.

7. End Phase
- Discard an enemy card or reveal your hand to all players.
- Max 10 CT. Discard excess CT.
- Max Hand size is 4 cards. Discard excess cards.

The first player to accumulate 35 Victory Tokens wins the game.

name: HALO Missions
description:
A card game for 2-4+ players set in the HALO Universe.

Players share a common deck comprising 6 basic types of cards: Spartan (S), Mission (M), Weapon (W), Enemy (E), Vehicle (V), Special X). Each card has a Mission Point Value (MPV) ranging from 1 to 5. Some of the types have sub-types. There are 15 cards each for Spartan, Mission, Vehicle, and Special. There are 30 cards each for Weapon and Enemy card types. Each player starts with 10 cards dealt from the deck.

Each player starts with 10 Shield Points (SP). If a player ever has less than Zero Shield Points, he immediately discards 3 cards and loses 5 Mission Points. He then immediately goes back up to 10 SP. 10 SP is the Max, you cannot go over this.

Players take turns with each turn having 5 Phases:

1. Insertion Phase
- Fill your hand to 10 cards.

2. Action Phase
- You may play (discard) one of your cards to activate its special ability. Each card type has 1 special ability associated with it.

3. Attack Phase
- You may play (discard) one card to attack 1 target opponent. The card must be either an enemy card or an alien weapon or alien vehicle. The target player loses shield points equal to the MPV of the attack card. You cannot pick the same target the player immediately before you picked.

4. Objective Phase
- If possible, you may make one or more melds in this phase - there are 30 types of melds possible. Score mission points equal to the combined MPV of all of the cards in the meld. Discard the melded cards.

5. Extraction Phase
- Regain 2 shield points.
- Discard down to 9 cards.

The first player to accumulate 100 mission points is the winner.

name: 時の祭壇 (Toki no Saidan)
description:
User summary
時の祭壇 (Toki no Saidan), in English would be 'Altar of Time', a card game with a theme of time. The game is #1 in a series of 5 games, published as a bookshelf volume 'Ars Combinatoria'. The game is published in both Japanese and English.

The key of the game is the ultimate decision between these two: circulating time which denies changes, and flowing time which accepts changes.

Players always have eight cards during play. At the end of the game, the player who has the highest value in their hand wins the game.

They maintain their own schedule in front of them, which determines their actions. Each turn, you may add and remove activity cards in your schedule or your opponent's. Time to be consumed is printed in each card. You must always keep the schedule exactly 24 hours.

To win the game, you should strengthen your schedule while weakening opponent's schedule.

Publisher's summary
「時間」をテーマにしたゲームです。
「すすむ時間」と「まわる時間」という究極の選択が鍵になります。
各自が自分のデッキを持ってプレイします。
待ち時間を我慢できるならば、何人でも同時にプレイできます。
ただし、現実的には6人程度が最大プレイ人数です。
自分や相手の予定表によって行動が規定されます。
最後にもっとも多くの得点を手札に持っていた人が勝ちです。
categories: Abstract Strategy, Card Game, Collectible Components, Educational, Math
mechanics: Action Queue, Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Hand Management, Memory, Set Collection

name: Trödel-Trecker
description:
Trödel-Trecker is tractor racing game. Wooden Houses in various colors are set up in a circle (there is no board). Each player has a wooden tractor and a set of cards with numbers from 2 to 9.

On your turn, you roll a color die and may move to the next house of the corresponding color. In addition, you have to flip over a number card whose number is at least as high as the number of steps you move. When moving onto the same field as another tractor, you push that one one field ahead. If you land on a field behind another tractor, you move up next to that one.

When you cannot make a legal move, you skip a turn. When the first player has no cards left, the game ends and whoever moved furthest is the winner.

name: Knight Hawk Skirmish
description:
A 2-player skirmish game based on the Star Frontiers Space Combat System - Knight Hawks.

The gameboard is an 8 X 8 square grid which can be populated with terrain characteristics (asteroid, nebula, planets) at the discretion of the players.

Players share a common deck of cards comprising four types of card: Attack, Defence, Movement and Special. Movement and Attack cards will have a specified range and all cards have a specified effect.

Players use counters or miniatures to represent the ships of their space fleets. The number and types of ships utilised will be dependent and which of the 5 scenarios is used and on the factions played. There are two main Factions: United Planetary Federation (UPF) and Sathar Empire though certain scenarios use Mercenaries, Pirates and Home Defence Fleets.

Game board set up and victory conditions are scenario driven, but gameplay is conducted in the same manner regardless of scenario.

Players start with 5 cards. Players take turns with each turn comprising 3 phases.

1. Tactics Phase
- Draw 5 cards.

2. Action Phase
- You may play cards from your hand.
- Use move cards to move a ship the indicated number of spaces. Moves are orthogonal or diagonal.
- Use attack cards to engage enemy units at the indicated range. All attacks do 1 point of damage. Attacks are orthogonal or diagonal.
- Use defence cards to negate a target attack.
- Played cards are discarded.

3. End Phase
- Max hand size is 7 cards. Discard excess cards.

Each ship has a number of hits (1-12 dependant on class). If a ship has more damage on it than it has hits, it is destroyed.

Play continues until the victory conditions for the chosen scenario are achieved.
mechanics: Area Movement, Hand Management, Open Drafting

name: Pacific Rim Matchup
description:
A card game for 2+ players based on The Pacific Rim Movie and representing Kaiju vs Jaeger Combat.

Players share a common 52 playing card deck. Each face card has a unique ability for each type of Jaeger or Kaiju which are described in each unit’s unique face card lists (there are six different Jaeger, and six different Kaiju). Number cards are used the same way by all units depending on their suit. Hearts = Attack, Diamonds = Dodge, Clubs = Damage, Spades = Armour.

Each player picks one Kaiju or Jaeger to control. There should be equal numbers of each if possible. Players may play 2 units, but must have a separate hand for each. Each unit (Kaiju and Jaeger) start with 20 Hits.

Players take turns with each turn comprising 8 phases:

1. Draw Phase
- Each player fills their card hand to their base hand size. Seven is the base hand size of all units but hand size can be decreased as a result of card play.

2. Tactics Phase
- The current player may discard up to 4 cards and draw replacements.

3. Attack Phase
- The current player (the attacker) picks a target enemy unit to attack (the defender). The attacker plays an Attack (Heart) card. The attacker may play 1 or more face cards to increase his attack score.

4. Dodge Phase
- The defender may play a Dodge (Diamond) card. The defender may play 1 or more face cards to increase his dodge score. If the dodge score is equal to or greater than the attack score, the attack misses in which case skip the Damage and Armour phases.

5. Damage Phase
- If the attack hit (i.e. was not dodged), the attacker plays a Damage (Club) card. The attacker may play 1 or more face cards to increase his damage score.

6. Armour Phase
- The defender may play an Armour (Spade) card. The defender may play 1 or more face cards to increase his armour score. If the armour score is equal to or greater than the damage score, the attack does no damage. If the damage score is higher, the defender takes hits equal to the difference. Units are destroyed when they are reduced to zero or less Hits.

7. Combo Counter Phase
- The attacker may play a face card with the Combo ability to attack an additional time this turn. This attack may be against a different opposing unit. After this, the defender may play a face card with the counter trait to also make an attack this turn (against the current player).

8. End Phase
- All players may discard up to 2 cards.

Play continues until all enemy units are destroyed.
categories: Card Game, Fighting, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Print & Play

name: Battle of Simancas
description:
A card game for 2 players themed on the battle between the Moors and Christians in Spain in 939 A.D. The Christian forces are an alliance between the Kingdoms of Leon, Navarre, and Castille. The Moors are attacking the mountainous north with an army of 100,000 men. In 3 days and during a solar eclipse the outnumbered Christian Army utterly destroys the invaders. One player is the Christians, the other is the Moors.

Players share a unique common deck. Cards are of 7 different types: Leader, Skirmisher, Cavalry, Infantry, Terrain, Strategy and Weapons. Cards have a force value between 1 and 5 and may also have special effects. Some cards can ony be used by one side or the other.

Play is conducted over a number of turns with each turn comprising 5 phases.

1. Fate Phase
- Each player is dealt 9 cards.

2. Reserve Phase
- Each player may discard up to 4 cards and draw replacements.

3. Strategy Phase
- Starting with the Muslim player each player may discard one card to get its strategic effect:
• Discard a Leader card to draw 3 cards and discard any 2.
• Discard a Strategy card to look at the next 5 cards in the deck and keep one.
• Discard a Terrain card to draw 2 cards.
• Discard a Cavalry card to draw a card and look at your opponent’s hand.
• Discard a Skirmisher card to cause your opponent to discard a random card from his hand
• Discard a Weapon card search for a Cavalry, Skirmisher, or Infantry card in the discard pile and put it in your hand.

4. Battle Phase
- Starting with the Muslim player, players take turns either placing one card down face up from their hand to the table for its force value or discarding one card for its tactical effect:
• Discard a Skirmisher to destroy a placed Infantry
• Discard a Cavalry to destroy a placed Skirmisher
• Discard a Strategy card to draw 1 card and look at your opponent’s hand
• Discard an Infantry to destroy a placed Terrain
• Discard a Terrain to destroy a placed Cavalry
• Discard a Leader to draw 2 cards
• Discard a Weapon to destroy another placed Weapon
- The higher force value wins the hand. In case of a tie, neither player wins.

5. Retreat Phase
- Both players discard all remaining cards in their hands.

name: Great Estates
description:
A card and board Game for 2-4+ players. The theme is the finances and status of the great country houses built in England and Scotland in the 18th and 19th centuries. Each player controls one noble who is making improvements to his estate.

The board is a circular track with 16 spaces. Pawns are utilised to track movement around the track

There are 2 decks of cards: The Income Deck and the Status Deck. The top 4 cards of each deck are always kept face up and are available for purchase.
- The income deck has six types of cards: Agriculture, Mining, Industry, Trade, Titles and Credit. These 6 card types correspond to six of the spaces on the game board. Each card has a cost and an income value.
- The status deck has six types of cards: Architecture, Style, Collections, Accommodations, Features and Construction. These 6 card types correspond to six of the spaces on the game board. Each card has a cost and a status value

Each player gets 20 coins and starts with an Estate Size = 10. Players elect to be one of 5 different aristocrats which gives them a unique starting position (larger estate, extra coins etc.)

On your turn roll one die. You may go either forwards or backwards. If you land on a space that has one or more matching cards face up, you may buy them and place face up in front of you OR if you land on a space that has an income type matching income cards you own you may collect income from them equal to their total income value.
- If you land on the Country space you may discard all the face up income cards and go again.
- If you land on the London space you must pay 2 Coins then you may discard all the face up status cards and go again.
- If you land on the Land space you may pay 2D6 Coins to increase the size of your estate by 1.
- If you land on the Rent space gain 1D6 Coins.

The game ends when any player has more than 30 improvements. End game scoring is then conducted as follows:
- Add up the status points of all of your status cards.
- Get an extra 30 points for each complete set owned – a set is one card from each of the 6 status types.
The player with the most status wins.

name: The Junglies Game
description:
Children's game where players need to collect 4 different birthday party presents to win. Characters are the lion, tiger, giraffe and tortoise.
Move is by spinner (1-4). Landing in a sun is a missing turn.

name: Noddy's Game
description:
Contents: Board, 4 plastic cars, 32 journey cards and 1 die
Winner is the first player to reach the 8 location cards distributed to each player.
By rolling the dice players move their cars to reach the locations depicted on each card. The locations are such:
Ark, steamer, fort, funfair, railway station, petrol station, etc.
Colorful board with some red (miss one turn) and green (roll again) spaces. The driving is on the left, this game was made in England by Gibsons Games.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Warp Chess
description:
A chess variant using cards. Basic two player chess rules board and pieces apply modified by the introduction of a common deck of cards. The deck includes a range of alternative plays that players can elect to use rather than normal movement for that turn. Examples are: move 3 pieces, move pawn like a rook, switch two of your opponent’s pieces, move bishop to any empty space etc.

The deck is placed beside the chessboard and four cards turned face up. One of these forms the start of the discard pile, one is available for use by the black player, one for use by only the white player, and one (the free card) is available for use by both players.

On your turn you can move as normal or you can play either the free card or your colour card. If you play a card it goes to the discard and is replaced by the top card of the deck. If you make a normal move, you may cause the free card or your colour card to be discarded and summarily replaced by the top card of the deck.
If the deck runs out, shuffle the discard and draw from it.

As in normal chess the winner is the player to checkmate his opponent’s King.

name: Restauranteur
description:
A game for 2-4+ players with a restaurant building theme.

An 8x8 grid represents a city. There is a set of 64 counters to be placed on the spaces of the board representing 16 districts (of 6 different types) and 48 restaurants (6 each of 8 different types). A space on the board may only ever contain 1 district or 1 restaurant.

To start the 16 districts are distributed to the board such that each row gets 2 random districts randomly placed. All restaurant counters are in a pile called the build pile which is shuffled and placed face down next to the board.

Each player gets a set of 20 tokens, 10 coins, 4 random restaurant counters and 4 cards from a common card deck. Cards are of three types: Number, Income and Improvement.

Players take turns with each turn comprising has 6 phases:

1. Investment Phase
- The active player receives 1 Coin.
- If you have the most restaurants of a given type (for each type) get one extra coin.

2. Recruit Phase
- The active player draws 1 card and puts it in his hand.

3. Build Phase
- You may build one restaurant. This costs 10 coins and the restaurant must come from your restaurant pool.
- When a restaurant is built, draw a replacement counter from the build pile.
- Place the restaurant counter on an open space on the board with one of your tokens on top of it. When building a restaurant, you must also discard a number card and the restaurant must be placed on a row or column matching that number.
- You may not build a restaurant adjacent to another of the same type.

4. Improvement Phase
- You may play one Improvement card. This costs 5 Coins.
- Place improvements face up on the table in front of you.
- You can have a maximum of 5 improvements.

5. Income Phase
- You must either play an income card or initiate a random income sequence.
- When playing a restaurant income card all restaurants of that type earn income.
They gain 1 coin for every adjacent (orthogonal or diagonal) district. When playing a district income card all restaurants adjacent to that type of district earn 1 coin each.
All players earn income, not just the active player.
- To initiate a random income sequence roll 2D8 to get a random space on the board. If that space is a restaurant, that restaurant earns income for each adjacent district. If that space is a district, each adjacent restaurant earns 1 coin.
- If you have the only restaurants of a given type on the board they gain 1 star. All restaurants start with a base rating of 1 star. Certain Improvements and bonuses increase the number of stars. When a restaurant receives income multiply by its star rating to get the number of coins it earns.

End Phase
Discard cards in your hand in excess of 4.

The game ends immediately when one of the following happens:
- Any player runs out of tokens to use.
- All restaurants of a single type are built.
- Players go through the deck twice.
The player with the most coins at the end of the game wins.
mechanics: Hand Management, Open Drafting, Tile Placement

name: Lotto-spel bilar
description:
Each player receives a mini board with 9 pictures, corresponding to 36 tiles. The tiles are placed faced down in a draw pile. Players take turns in drawing tiles, and the player who has the corresponding picture on his board recieves the tile. The player who first fills his mini board with tiles wins.

The game can also be played as a version of memory. The tiles are placed faced down on the table, and players take turn choosing tiles and turning them face-up. If a player chooses a tile with a picture corresponding to his board, he places it there and continues his turn. If the tile corresponds to a picture on another players board, he puts it back face-down and lets next player take his turn. The player who first fills his mini board wins.

name: Resident Evil Relived
description:
A meld making card game for 2-4+ players based on the Resident Evil Franchise.

Players share a common deck comprising 10 card types: Alice Cards (Friend), Ally Cards (Friend), Team Cards (Friend), Weapon Cards (Friend), Mission Cards (Friend), Villain Cards (Foe), Umbrella Cards (Foe), Experiment Cards (Foe), Zombie Cards (Foe), Event Cards (Foe). There are 10 cards of each type with every card having a point value between 1 and 5.

Each turn has 5 phases:


Deploy Phase: 2 cards are dealt face down to each player. Next 3X stacks of 2 cards each are dealt to the centre of the table (X = number of players). All stack cards are visible to all players.
Recruit Phase: Players take turns taking 1 stack of cards and putting it into their hand. This continues until all stacks are taken (each should get 3 stacks). On each consecutive turn, the player to the left of the player who went first last time now gets to go first.
Action Phase: Players take turns taking one action each, in the same order as in Recruit phase. When taking an action, discard 1 card from your hand. This produces a result that that depends on the type of card you discard (i.e. if you discard an Alice card you may draw 3 cards and keep 1, discarding an Ally card allows you to draw 2 cards
Meld Phase: To make a meld, a player needs to have 1 card of each of the 10 types. Melds are played face up and score points equal to the total point value of all the cards in the meld. If the total of the friend cards is greater than the total of the foe cards an extra 5 meld points are scored. All meld cards are discarded after scoring.
End Phase: Max hand size is 10 cards. Discard excess cards.


The winner is the player to be the first to score 70 meld points.
categories: Card Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Resident Evil Quest
description:
A quest style game using track, cards, and dice for one or more players, based on the Resident Evil franchise. Each player is a team of Operatives, Mercs, and/or Survivors that have infiltrated a Top Secret Underground Umbrella Corporation Research Facility with the intent to destroy it. The teams will fight zombies, mutants, Umbrella employees, and facility defences. They will be aided by cards representing weapons, Alice, and new recruits.
There are 4 common decks:
Agent Deck - Contains agents you can recruit for your team.
Aid Deck - Helpful events and things you find along the way.
Encounter Deck - Foes and unfavourable events.
Boss Deck - Big Monsters
Agents and Foes have stats for Life, Evade, Attacks Initiative, Aim and Strength.

The facility is represented by a track that is 40 spaces long. The first space is the entrance. The end space is the final encounter.

Each player draws 7 cards from the Agent deck and discards one. Players start with 3 Aid cards in their hand.

Players take turns with each turn comprising 6 phases:

1. Aid Phase
- Draw 1 Aid card and add it to your hand.

2. Recruit Phase
- Some Action Aid cards are played in this phase.

3. Move Phase
- Roll 1D6 and move your marker forward that many spaces. If you land on another player’s pawn immediately move forward 1 space.

4. Encounter Phase
- Draw 1 card from the Encounter deck. This will be something you have to fight this turn. If you reached the final space draw a card from the Boss deck instead of the Encounter deck.

5. Fight Phase
- Units make attacks in order of Initiative.
- When making an attack roll 1D10: if this is equal to or less than the Aim score then the attack hits.
- The defending unit then rolls 1D10: if this equal to or less than the Evade score of the Unit then the attack is negated.
- Attacks that hit and are not evaded do damage. A Unit that has more damage than life is killed.
- During a fight phase turn all Units get to attack (usually just once)
- Repeat the Fight Phase sequence until one side is completely killed off or an Aid card allows you to escape.

6. End Phase
- Make contamination checks if the Agent has been damaged but not killed to determine if they will turn into a zombie.
- Max hand size is 6 cards. Discard excess cards.

The winner is the first player to make it to the end of the track and destroy the Boss Monster encountered there.
categories: Card Game, Dice, Movies / TV / Radio theme
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Hand Management, Open Drafting

name: Resident Evil Skirmish
description:
A 2-player 8x8 skirmish game using miniatures and cards, based on the Resident Evil Franchise. One player is the Heroes. The other is the Umbrella Corporation.

An 8x8 grid is used as the playing area, with figurines or chits representing units.
Players select their units from a unique list. Units have a set number of hit points and may have other characteristics. For a typical game, each side should have about 20 hit points worth of units with units being placed on a player’s back 2 rows.

Players share a common deck. Cards types are, Attack, Move, Defend, Special

Players take turns with each turn comprising 3 phases:


Draw Phase
Draw 5 Cards.

Action Phase
Play cards from your hand to have your units move and attack. Move and attack cards have an associated range value that determines the exact distance in spaces in which a unit moves or is hit by an attack from its source. Attacks do one hit point worth of damage unless otherwise stated. Units are eliminated when their hit point value is reduced to zero.
You opponent may play defence cards to negate attacks.

End Phase
Max hand size is 5 cards. Discard excess cards.



The winner is the first player to completely eliminate all enemy units.
categories: Card Game, Miniatures, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Deadlands Skirmish
description:
A 2 player skirmish game using miniatures and cards, based on the Deadlands RPG game.

Play is conducted on an 8x8 grid using figurines or counters to represent units. Players select units from a list of over 50 characters/units with differing hit points, equipment and capabilities. For a typical game each side should have about 20-24 hit points worth of units. To start units are placed on a player’s back 2 rows.

Players share a common deck containing Attack, Defence, Move, Special and Option cards. The Option cards are used to activate one of the six options available to each unit. Options include but are not limited to healing, regeneration, disarming, immobilization and fear.

Players take turns with each turn comprising 3 Phases:

1. Draw Phase
- Draw 5 Cards.

2. Action Phase
- Play cards from your hand to have your units move and attack. Move and attack cards have an associated range value that determines the exact distance in spaces that a unit moves or is hit by an attack from its source.
- Attacks do one hit point worth of damage unless otherwise stated. The attacked player may play defence cards to negate attacks. Units are eliminated when their hit point value reaches zero.

3. End Phase
- Max hand size is 5 cards. Discard excess cards.

Victory is achieved by completely eliminating all enemy units.
categories: American West, Card Game, Horror, Science Fiction
mechanics: Area Movement, Hand Management, Open Drafting

name: Farmyard
description:
Players race along paths through a typical farm setting to reach their bus. They can travel along multiple routes that can either detour them along a shorter path or delay them by sending back to an earlier space on the default track.

Spaces can be described by various encounter scenarios such as drawing cards from the Hay or Straw decks, moving a certain number of spaces, or switching places with other players.
Encounters that will distract and delay the players include being sent to visit animal spaces such as chickens, sheep, and pigs.

name: Mulan: A Grande Batalha
description:
Description from the back of the box (translated):
Mulan: The Great Battle

Disney's newest movie tells the story of a young Chinese woman named Mulan posing as a warrior to honor the family and defend their people. At first it is still fragile and awkward. Then, with the effort and help of his friends, he becomes a valiant soldier.

This game plays with the great battle that Mulan hangs with Shan-Yu, leader of the barbarian army and great enemy of his people.
You can win with Mulan, but you will have to be skilled, since it will not be an easy fight.

Description from the back of the box (Portuguese):

O mais novo filme dos estúdios Disney conta a história de uma jovem chinesa, chamada Mulan, que se passa por um guerreiro para honrar a família e defender seu povo. No começo ainda é frágil e desajeitado. Depois, com esforço e ajuda dos amigos, torna-se um valente soldado.

Este jogo brinca com a grande batalha que Mulan trava com Shan-Yu, líder do exército bárbaro e grande inimigo do seu povo.
Você poderá vencer com Mulan, porém terá que ser hábil, já que não será uma luta fácil.
categories: Action / Dexterity, Children's Game, Party Game

name: Game of Life: New York Life Edition
description:
Description from the publisher:

The company you keep has teamed up with the Game of Life to bring you the New York Life edition of the classic board game. Will you attend college or start a career? Invest in retirement certificates along the way or try you luck in the market mania? Visit the Statue of Liberty on your quest to win the game with the most money and retire at Sunset Estates.

name: Diddl auf dem Kaktus
description:
All 16 card pairs and the cactus card are shuffled well and equally distributed among all the other players.
If a player has one or more pairs, he may place them face-up, the remaining cards are held in their hands.

Now the first player draws an random card from the player to the right and adds it to his hand cards. If he has a pair, he can discardit. In clockwise direction, the next player again draws a card from the hand of the player to the right and possibly discards pairs. So there will be fewer cards in the hands. The player, who was able to discard all his cards, has survived this round and is allowed to leave. (It actually says that!) The remaining players continue until only one player with the cactus card remains. This player lost!


Das schadenfrohe Kartenspiel

Rules on back of box:
Alle 16 Karten-Pärchen und die Kaktus-Karte werden gut gemischt und unter allen Mitspielern gleichmäßig verdeckt aufgeteilt.
Hat ein Mitspieler ein oder mehrere Pärchen, darf er diese offen vor sich ablegen, die restlichen Karten werden aufgefächert in den Händen gehalten.

Nun zieht der erste Spieler eine beliebige Karte aus dem Kartenfächer seines rechten Nachbarn und steckt sie zu seinen Karten in der Hand dazu. Hat er nun ein Pärchen, darf er dieses ablegen. Im Uhrzeigersinn zieht nun jeweils der nächste Mitspieler wieder eine Karte von dessen rechten Nachbarn und legt eventuell Pärchen ab. So werden es immer weniger Karten in den Händen. Der Mitspieler, der all seine Karten ablegen konnte, hat diese Spielrunde überstanden und darf ausscheiden. Die restlichen Spieler machen so lange weiter, bis nur noch ein Spieler mit der Kaktus-Karte übrigbleibt. Dieser hat verloren!
mechanics: Open Drafting, Player Elimination, Set Collection

name: Lost Girl Quest
description:
A board game for 2 -4+ players based on the TV show Lost Girl. Players move their pawns around a circular track collecting the tokens needed to solve a central mystery and its complications.

The board is a circular track with 12 spaces around which players move in a clockwise direction. The spaces on the board allow players to gain tokens, or draw cards from the various decks.

There are six token types each representing one of six traits: Guile, Lore, Search, Heart, Fight, Magic

There are 3 common decks of cards:

Mystery Deck

Each card represents a mystery that must be solved or resolved. To solve a mystery a player must collect 3 of each token type, plus extra tokens required by individual mysteries and complications. An individual mystery card lists any extra tokens required in addition to the 3 of each type. When a mystery is solved, the solving player keeps the card and a new card is drawn from the mystery deck to be the new mystery.


Complication Deck

When a player lands on the complication space on the board, they draw a complication card. This card is placed face up next to the board. This card lists extra tokens that need to be gained to solve the current mystery. This additional burden applies to all players. When the current mystery is solved, these cards are discarded.


Assistance Deck

When a player lands on the assistance space, they draw an assistance card. This card gives that player one or more extra tokens. The assistance card is then discarded.


To start the top mystery card is placed face up in the middle of the movement track. Players then take turns with each turn comprising 3 phases:


Move Phase
Roll 1 die and move that many spaces clockwise along the track.

Action Phase
Most spaces when you land on them give you 1 or more Tokens.
If you land on a Deck space, draw a card from the indicated deck.
If you land on an opponent’s Pawn, steal 1 Token of your choice from him. Skip all other actions you would take at that space.

End Phase
If you have enough of the right tokens to solve the Mystery and all of its complications, declare your intent. Keep the Mystery card and discard all complications. All players discard all of their Tokens.



The winner is the first player to solve 3 mysteries.
categories: Card Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme
mechanics: Open Drafting, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Angels & Bears
description:
Publisher Description

Modern air and naval combat between the superpowers 1980-1989. Using the same [miniatures wargaming] air system from Air War-Vietnam, but mating it with a naval combat system to allow gamers to launch large airstrikes against fleets during the Cold War era. Features rules, counters for aircraft, and all the templates needed to play the game.

name: Belle Alliance
description:
Description from the rulebook:

This set of wargame rules for the Napoleonic period was developed through trial games during the years 1996-2000. A first edition was
published under the working title Depression over the Hebrides.

name: I Say Holmes!: The Plot Thickens
description:
Expansion kit which supplements the base game with new characters, villains, locations and situations to "expand your adventures as the great Consulting Detective".

The expansion kit includes 25 cards in the following eight categories:

3 x travel cards
1 x information card
5 x villain cards
5 x interrupt cards
2 x country cards
2 x action cards
1 x city card
6 x "I Say" cards

Game pieces included are:

5 x villain tokens (Count Dracula, The Mummy, Sweeney Todd, Jack The Ripper and The Werewolf)
1 x case closed book token (A Scandal In Bohemia, valued at 60 case points and worth 5 victory points)
categories: Card Game, Deduction, Expansion for Base-game
mechanics: Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Storytelling

name: Star Control
description:
Description from the publisher:

Star Control is a family board game, set in a theme based on the conquest of the universe. The game is for 2, 3 or 4 players with games of an estimated duration in 75 minutes and oriented to players of more than 8 years.

It allows you to create your own game scenarios and uses a mixture of simple, well-oiled mechanics that make the game very dynamic and fun.

There are two possibilities to win the game, Achieve the mission objective or get 4 victory points.

The objective of the mission may be based on occupying spaces, conquering planets for a certain time, capturing enemy ships, etc.

Victory points can be achieved by capturing enemy ships, conquering enemy bases and developing technologies.

Depending on the number of players, we choose a mission from the book of missions that make up the planets, the bases of the players and the ships that we have initially, once prepared the game scenario we are ready to start the game. We have the option to create our own adventures with the help of a blank mission that appears in the book of missions.

The turn of the player consists of 4 phases:


Collection: materials are collected, base (+2) and colonizers (+1) provide us with materials that produce the planets that we will add to our metal, crystal and gas counters.
Management: we develop our empire executing different actions in exchange for materials, such as moving, building different ships, stealing letters, etc. We can make use of the honor stamps and 1 technology card.
Combat: we obtain marks of honor and spaces in the board, by means of a roll of dice and modifiers. Players involved may use 1 battle card per battle.
Redeploy: we have 5 movements to distribute as we wish between our ships. We can also make use of Seals of honor.


Throughout the game we will have to expand our empire by the board, facing the other players through different spaces, we will form fleets of ships and we can launch to the conquest of other planets.

Different ways and ways to achieve victory in a game of strategy and management, suitable for the whole family and simple rules.
categories: Abstract Strategy, Civilization, Expansion for Base-game, Science Fiction, Space Exploration
mechanics: Action Queue, Area Majority / Influence, Modular Board

name: Dust 1947: Raketentruppe Command Squad
description:
Description from the publisher:

The Luftwaffe Raketentruppe Command Squad is a special unit of field officers whose skills are invaluable. They are equipped with assault rifles and a rocket launcher, and their presence on the battlefield can change the entire course of battle, thanks to their precious skills. A wise general should take care to protect these experienced officers.

This squad comes with its own Dust 1947 unit card. Like all regular Dust 1947 miniatures, it comes already assembled and primed.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Science Fiction, Wargame, World War II
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Modular Board

name: Box Quiz: Love
description:
One of the over 50 implementations of the Box Quiz series, this one with the theme 'Love'.

The game consists of a tin box with 50 questions and answers within a category, here about love. It is a small and simple quiz game, where players simply answer the different questions.

name: Super Genius: Multiplication 1
description:
This is a collection of games teaching single-unit multiplication equations (from 2 to 5). The game contains 42 cards, half of which have 5 numbers (products) on them, the other half have 5 equations. One of the equations on an equations card will match one of the numbers on a number card.

In one of the games, players find the matching equation and number on a pair of cards (similar to Catch the Match). In other games, players find matches between two products, or two equations.

name: Cthulhu Quest
description:
A card game for 2-4+ players with a Cthulhu theme.

Players share a common deck comprising 10 card types: Investigator, Ally, Object, Book, God, Monster, Location, Transport, Spell and Event. Each player is dealt a hand of 13 cards.

Players take turns with each turn having 4 phases:

Investigation Phase
- Draw 2 cards from the deck and put them in your hand.

Insanity Phase
- You may discard 1 card from your hand for its effect (e.g. discarding a Transport card allows you to look at the next 5 cards in the deck and keep one; discarding a God card allows you to discard your hand and draw 9 new cards).

Story Phase
- You may play a Meld. A Meld must include the following: 1 Investigator card, 0 to 2 Ally cards, 0 to 1 Object card, 0 to 1 Book card, 0 to 1 God card, 1 to 2 Monster cards, 1 to 2 Location cards, 0 to 1 Transport card, 0 to 1 Spell card, 0 to 1 Event card.
- Melds score story points for the number of cards in the meld (3 cards is worth 2 Story Point (SP), 4 cards is worth 4 SP, 5 cards is worth 6 SP and so on …..). Certain card combinations will award extra Story Points.

Mythos Phase
- If you played a Meld this turn, draw X cards where X is the number of cards in the Meld. Max hand size is 13 cards - discard excess cards.

The game ends when there are no cards left in the deck and no one can play a Meld. The player with the most Story Points (SP) wins.

name: ¡Bola va!
description:
This game haven´t got any theme.

The players have a few marbles and in their turn, they have to throw them trying to make 3 in line or more combinations. Some combinations give you differents points and the person who reach 50 points, win

name: Piglet's Delivery Service
description:
User summary
仔ぶた急便 (Piglet's Delivery Service)
Once upon a time Mother Pig asked her piglets to delivery some packages. In order to deliver the packages, the piglets decided to form their own delivery companies.

When delivering a package for receipt confirmation they received a hoof print rather than a signature. Each of the piglets' companies compete to see who makes the speediest deliveries.

In this game, the goal is to move the three pig pieces to the four home bases (other than your own) and collect four hoof print chips before anyone else.

Each player controls three piglets, starting with all three piglet pieces placed on their home base. There are a total of 5 home bases, one for each player from the center.

On their turn, players also draw animal tiles and add them to their hand. After drawing a tile, the player carries out all of the following actions, in any order, during their turn: moving a piglet, placing an animal tile, and returning a piglet. Throw away tiles to ensure a player’s hand does not exceed three tiles. The game ends when a player successfully moves their piglets to the other four home bases and collects all the hoof prints to win the game.

Moving a piglet - This action, in combination with the below action (placing an animal tile), can only be carried out a maximum of three times during a single turn (e.g., place one animal tile + move 2 spaces). A player may move their piglet one space in any direction. The player can also use the secret passage spaces to travel even further. However, except for the home base spaces, a piglet cannot move to a space that is already occupied by another piglet. In addition, if a piglet moves onto a space with an animal tile placed on it, they must obey the law of that tile. If a piglet successfully moves to a home base, they can receive the hoof print from that base.

Placing an animal tile - This action, in combination with the above action (moving a piglet), can only be carried out a maximum of three times (e.g., place two animal tiles + move 1 spaces). A player places an animal tile from their hand onto an open space. An open space is a space where no animal tiles or piglets are currently placed. However, some tiles can take the place of other tiles and some tiles cannot be placed on some spaces.

Returning a piglet - This action can be used an unlimited number of times per turn. Move one piglet that is not currently placed on your home base back to your home base. At the same time, you can add a tile (without a piglet piece placed on top) into your hand.

ある日、お母さんぶたは仔ぶたたちに荷物運びのお手伝いを頼みました。子ぶたたちは荷物を運ぶために運送会社を作りました。荷物を渡したら、サインの代わりに足跡のハンコを貰います。
さあ競争です。誰よりも早くみんなの家に荷物を運んでしまいましょう。
このゲームの目的は、3匹の仔ぶたコマを動かして自分以外の4か所の拠点を回り、他の誰よりも早く4つの足跡チップを集めることです。

name: Onigiri-San
description:
In おにぎりさん　(Onigiri-San), players work together to make onigiri (Japanese rice balls) using cards that show seaweed, rice, or one of three different fillings. To win, players must create one of each type of onigiri in front of each player.

On each turn, the active player must either (1) play one of their hand cards onto another player's tableau; or (2) "eat" (i.e., discard) a completed onigiri from their tableau and then discard and replace one of their hand cards. Played cards are replaced from the draw deck. Discarded cards are not reshuffled when the draw deck runs out.

The game ends either when a player is unable to act on their turn (a loss) or when each player has one of each nigiri in front of them (a win).
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Pattern Building, Set Collection

name: Kobito-san no Yasai Batake
description:
User summary
小人さんのやさい畑 (Kobito-san no Yasai Batake) is a game about little people growing crops. Kobito-san means 'small beings', akin to Halfling or dwarvish people in a fairy tale. Yasai Batake would be a vegetable farm or field. In this context 'Little People's Vegetable Patch' is probably a close match.

The object of the game is to plant, grow, and harvest the vegetables. Successfully harvested vegetables grant you points. The game itself has a simultaneous action choice with butting mechanics. Butting is the Japanese gaming term for matching values cancelling out, as in games like Hols der Geier.

There are 3 types of cards: Plant card (green border) / Supply card (yellow border) / Buy-in card (white border). Each turn, every player chooses a card from their hand, and reveals it simultaneously. If any players have played the same kind of Plants, those Plants are cancelled, dumped to the discard pile, and their turn is skipped.

Any remaining vegetables are played on the field, "slow growing" ones first. You place your chips around your planted vegetable, the same number as the "required turns to harvest" value.

Then the supply cards come in to action. Shovel icon cards have an one-time instant effect, resolve it and discard. Trap icon cards may be placed on the field with your chip as an identifier.

Finally, resolve the Buy-in cards. You may draw cards from the deck, but the more players that played Buy-in the same time, the fewer card you may draw. If you are the only one playing, you draw 3 cards. If 2 players are playing, you both draw 2. Otherwise, each player may draw 1 card. The played Buy-in card is returned to your hand.

After that come the Planting phase, the Saboteur phase and Grow/Harvest phase.

At the Saboteur phase, the Saboteur (some destructive animals) moves in the field. If the Saboteur runs over any of the vegetables, or chips that belong to a vegetable, that vegetable is wasted, and removed from the field.

Then the Grow/Harvest phase. For each vegetable, pick a chip that belongs to that vegetable, and stack it on the vegetable card. If there are no chips left on the field for that card, it is considered grown and may be harvested to score you points.

Publisher's summary
Place your hobbits in the vegetable patch and grow, harvest your vegetables!

Kobito-san no Yasai Batake is a game where you place your hobbits in the game field and harvest the vegetables. The first player to harvest the predetermined amount of vegetables is the winner.

The field is small. You may need to race to get a better area. Should you work steadily on a small, quick and easy-to-grow vegetable? Or a slow but huge one? It's up to you. But beware, Saboteur animals maybe lurking nearby. They maybe after your hard-grown vegetables, so watch out!

畑に小人さんを配置してやさいを収穫しよう！

「小人さんのやさい畑」はフィールドに小人さんを配置してやさいを収穫するゲームです。いち早く、規定量のやさいを収穫できた人が勝者となります。

土地は狭いため取り合いになってしまうかもしれません。小さくコツコツと育てるか、大きく大逆転を狙うかはあなた次第。

しかし、畑にはお邪魔物がいます。せっかく育てたやさいを台無しにされないように気を付けてください。

name: El Libertador
description:
A board game for 2-4+ players themed on the Latin American revolutions 1809 - 1826.

The board is a circular track of 41 spaces. Eight countries are represented on the track by a series of consecutive spaces of length 3, 4 or 5. Countries are separated from each other on the track by a revolution space

Players share a common deck comprising cards of two main types: Liberation cards and Royalist cards. There are 5 types of Liberation Cards: Simon Bolivar, Leader, Troops, Battle, and Ideals. All cards have a force value between 1 and 8.

Players start with two cards drawn from the deck and a set of counters and markers.

Players take turns with each turn comprising 5 Phases:

Draw Phase

Draw 1 Card and place it in your hand.


Move Phase

Roll 1 die and move forward that many spaces OR discard a card from your hand and move forward a number of spaces equal to its force value.
If you land on a Revolution space you may do one of three actions:
Roll the die and move again
Move to any other Revolution space on the board
Draw 1 card and place it in your hand
Play a counter onto any country space you have liberated



Action Phase

If you land on a Country space that has no card on it, you may (but do not have to) play a Liberation card to that space. Tuck it partially under the board directly next to the space. Place 1 of your counters on the space if you placed a card there. If you have a card under a space you are said to have liberated it.
If you land on a Country space that you have already liberated (You have a card and one or more counters there already) you may do one of the following:
Place an additional counter on the Space
Exchange the tucked card with one from your hand
Draw 1 card and discard 1 card (It may be the same card)

If you land on a Country space liberated by another player, you can either do nothing or play 1 or more Royalist cards with a combined force value equal to or greater than the number of counters your opponent has on the space. If you do so, discard all the counters on the space and the card tucked under it. Remove the Royalist cards from the game.
If you land on a Country space that is Independent skip over it and go to the next space and resume your move.


Independence Phase

If you played a Liberation card under a Country space this turn and all the other spaces for that country have already been liberated (by you or others) the Country is now said to have gained its Independence. Immediately score Victory Tokens (VT) for the country.
You gain 2 Victory Tokens for playing the final card to make the country go Independent.
The player with the highest combined total of counters and card force values gets 5 VT.
The player with the second highest total of counters and card force values gets 3 VT.
All other players with at least 1 card and counter in the country get 1 VT each.



End Phase

Max hand size is 5 cards. Discard excess cards.


The game ends when all countries have been liberated. The player with the most VT at the end of the game wins.

name: Doctor Who Episodes
description:
A rummy style card game for 2-4+ players with a Dr Who theme focused on Doctors 9-11.

Players share a common deck comprising 15 cards in each of 6 suits: Doctors, Companions, Gadgets, Foes, Plots and Specials. Cards have a force point value ranging from 1 to 15.

Players are dealt 7 cards each and then take turns with each turn comprising 4 phases:

Draw Phase

Draw 2 cards from the top of the deck and put them in your hand.


Action Phase

You may play (discard) one card from your hand to activate its special ability.
Discard a Doctor card to look at the next 7 cards in the deck.
Discard a Companion card to draw 2 cards.
Discard a Foe card to steal 1 random card from an opponent’s hand.
Discard a Plot card to look at an opponent’s hand.
Discard a Gadget card to draw 3 cards, keep 1 and discard the other 2.
Discard a Special card to cause target opponent to discard 1 random card.



Episode Phase

If possible you may play (discard) one episode from your hand. An episode consists of one card of each of the 6 card types. The total value of the FP for the Doctor, Companion, and Gadget cards must exceed the total FP value of the Foe, Plot, and Special cards (The Threat).
Gain Victory Points equal to the value of the Threat.
After completing an episode draw 4 cards from the deck.


End Phase

Max hand size is 7 cards. Discard excess cards.


The first player to earn 50 Victory Points is the winner.
categories: Card Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Print & Play

name: Renaissance Inventors at War
description:
A card and board skirmish game for 2 players themed on renaissance warfare with Leonardo da Vinci style inventions. The setting is Italian City States at war circa 1490 - the Fivizzano are invading the Piombino.

Play is conducted on a 16 x 16 square grid map. Each 8 x 8 section is referred to as a quadrant – the 2 eastern quadrants are land, the 2 western quadrants are water. The 6 squares of the NE corner of the SW quadrant contain city squares - the Port City commune of Piombino. The remainder of the map layout is determined at discretion of the players though most of the land spaces should be flat land with a few clumps of forests and mountains and a few solitary hills, villages, and swamps.
One road connects the city to a village or two and then goes off the map. A few Islands dot the Tyrrhenian Sea. Terrain types will affect the movement of the different unit types.

There are 11 different unit types: Infantry, Engineers, Cavalry, Artillery, War Machine, Flying Machine, Fortification, Small Warship, Large Warship, Transport and Mine Field. Each unit type has a move rating, hits score and range, and may have a special capability.

The players start with a pre-defined army comprising a mix of the various units. The attacker (the Fivizzano) starts with his units in the bottom half of the Southern quadrants. In addition the Fivizzano gets one roll against the leader table and 4 rolls against the invention table – these give advantages / enhancements that last for the duration of the battle. The defender (the Piombino) starts with units scattered in the Northern quadrants, one roll against the leader table and 6 against the invention table.

Players share a Tactics deck comprising cards that mostly give short duration benefits. These cards can be used, when appropriate, to enhance your own actions or negate those of your opponent

Players take turns with each turn comprising 4 Phases:

Draw Phase

Draw 2 Tactics cards.


Move Phase

Each of your Units may be moved once up to a number of spaces equal to its move rating.


Attack Phase

Each of your units may make 1 attack vs. a target within its range. When attacking roll 1D10. On a roll of 7 or higher the attack is successful and the target loses 1 hit. A unit with zero hits is destroyed.


End Phase

Max Hand size is 5 cards. Discard excess cards.


The Fivizzano win if they occupy 4 of the spaces of the city.
The Piombinos win if they destroy 20 or more units.
mechanics: Area Movement, Grid Movement, Hand Management, Open Drafting

name: CROWDFUN!
description:
CROWDFUN! is a simulation game of crowdfunding. People can learn and experience the fun of operating a crowdfunding project while playing it! Through these well-designed game mechanics, players would be able to act as a project initiator, sponsor or even the marketing company, to consider how effectively use their strategies and street smart can lead them achieve the goal, earn final victory!

The object of this game is to provide the players the chances to earn victory points through the crowdfunding project, and the player who obtains the highest score is the winner. Different projects have different levels of difficulty, capability and locations. Every single game, as well as every round will appear unpredictable trends and chances. Therefore, only thos who have acute observation, precise operation of strategy and power of persuasion will win the game.

name: HOJO Toryo Murder Case
description:
Board game designer Mr. Hojo was murdered by someone.
Collect the evidence, narrow down the perpetrators and lead us to arrest.
The player who was able to cooperate in arresting the criminal, however, will be the winner.

name: Speechless: Dice Tower Promo Pack
description:
An addon set of 9 new cards given out from the 2017 Dice Tower Indiegogo campaign.

Red - breakfast/blender, jellyfish/rocket, radio/auction
Green - crawl/ghost, chew/kick, throat/punch
Yellow - singer/lunch, dice/tower, photographer/ostrich

name: Haikubes
description:
You roll dice and make haikus based on the theme dice and using the word dice. Then, I guess you grade each other's haikus - praise them or shame them depending on their quality.

Game includes 63 word cubes

name: Redneck Madness
description:
In Redneck Madness, two teams are faced by the dominance of the drink that is consumed in the USA. On the one hand, there is the Mega-corporation Puke Cola, which with all its economic power and Human Resources is implanting a new drink very sugary that is becoming addictive to the population. This Mega-corporation will be controlled by a single Player who with his fleet of Delivery trucks must distribute the Puke Cola throughout the States of the USA, hire Employees for his company and form a Puke Cola dispatcher army, manufacture the different varieties of Puke Cola, reinforce its Headquarters with traps to avoid fortuitous incursions and, finally, to avoid that the side of the Redneck steal to them the secret recipe of the Puke Cola.

Against him is the team of the family of Rednecks, the Hickey. They were on vacation in Hawaii when the Puke Cola began to be commercialized. In this team of 1 to 3 players will have to cooperate and help each other. To be able to get Hawaiian Air Tickets to bring back all family members, knock down Puke Cola advertising banners and put up Beer Posters, bribe Puke Cola workers to reveal company secret information, or get drunk to the employees and leave them out of the game. All this while getting better objects and new members of the Hickey family to infiltrate the Puke Cola Factory. Since there will be epic clashes to see who sticks more drinking and who ends up collapsing first, if the members of Puke Cola for the excess of alcohol from the beer. Or the Rednecks for blood sugar overdose.

Once they face the length and breadth of the US, everything will be decided at Puke Cola Headquarters where both teams will face for control of the drink. Will the Rednecks steal the Puke Cola recipe or will Puke Cola's loyal employees get the Redneck out of action for blood sugar overdose?

The game is developed over 10 rounds on a map of the USA in which as the rounds progress the player who manages the corporation of Puke Cola will incorporate in each turn a new delivery truck with which to move and conquer states and put the difficult things to the Rednecks locking up and making difficult the movement, as it conquer states it manages to recruit more distributors for its army that they incorporate to its factory to generate more Puke Cola that gives to him more force of attack for the battle final. Redneck will have to do different missions that will pick up from the deck of missions at the beginning of each turn and for which they will spend cards of resources to move that will be obtained at the beginning of each turn and when completing missions in the form of rewards. Each mission that can complete an ally involves traveling to one of the 48 US states having to travel on a map of the US with more and more presence of Puke Cola trucks. Among the different types of missions we will have to recruit new Redneck, pay bribes with the money obtained from completing previous missions, combats the deliverymen to reduce their army, release states under Puke Cola control and thus reduce the power of the corporation. The enemy moves all of their trucks to an adjacent state on each turn while allies have to make use of the resources and rewards in the form of cards that they get as the game progresses. After the 10 turns on the map of the USA in which Puke Cola will have increased its army and attack power and the Redneck will see their resistance to the reduced Puke Cola will take place a direct confrontation in the factory of Puke Cola in the pure style Dungeon Crawler with simplified mechanics and fast combat between all the characters at once in each room. The fighting is resolved with a bidding system in which each side bets on all the plates that it picks from its bag which assigns to attack and defense and are compared with the bet by the opposing side, these bids can be modified by the different reward cards obtained in the previous phase.
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Hand Management, Push Your Luck, Worker Placement

name: Pizzeria Boss
description:
Pizzeria Boss is a set-collecting and hand management card game with just a little bit of a “take that!” element (let’s face it, sometimes it’s fun to stick it to your neighbor). With limited resources can you complete more pizza orders than your competitors before the end of the game? Need some help along the way? Great! You can bring in managers and even The Boss to help out! Let’s just hope that they don’t get fired before they serve their usefulness. To win, you’ll need to play the right cards at the optimal time.

The game comes with two decks of cards, the “Boss deck” and the “Order deck”. The two decks work in conjunction with each other. The "Order deck" determines what toppings you need on your pizza. The Boss deck provides the toppings and all the little things needed to help your business along the way. If you play your cards right you might even disrupt your competitors. Once you order is prepared it must be cooked. Be wary--until that order is done and the money is in your pocket that customer could still decide to cancel. That's just how pizza life goes, right? Health inspectors, cancelled orders, not having what you need in stock - these are all possible disasters that could happen. But there is also the good things - helpful managers, a boss willing to lend a hand or customers who pay for their order early. Explore all these things and more in Pizzeria Boss.
mechanics: Hand Management, Set Collection, Take That

name: Bushido: Bakemono Boomers
description:
Description from the publisher:

A lot could be said for the subterranean races’ savage and cruel practices however their ability to adapt and change based on the environment and resources available cannot be ignored, their resourcefulness is something to be admired when considering the scarcity of materials offered in the dark places they claim as their own. Now with the world in turmoil, ravaged by war, the bakemono tribes pick the battlefields clean like maggots at a wound. This has led to the advancements of the Prefecture being turned against them. The boomers are one such example of this, two brave and possibly a little stupid bakemono eagerly working the famous ryu arquebus to deadly effect.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Miniatures, Wargame
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Variable Player Powers

name: BuddySays: The Bla-Bla-Blaa Card Game
description:
BuddySays is a friendship-provoking game- A simple, fun and easy to play the game; BuddySays focuses on trolling, pranking and social interaction as its themes.

Designed with 2 Gameplay modes; Core and Alternate - BuddySays uses the point system to determine the winner. Integrating mobile phone; specifically on making calls as the main method in Core Mode, while playing with other players on the table in Alternate; - making BuddySays a potential super fun and engaging party game.

Get your buddies to say weird stuff with BuddySays. Made for people who are in a relationship with their mobile phones. And trolling buddies.

—description from the designer

name: Wer war's?
description:
This learning game consists of cardboard rectangles containing pictures of animals and the traces they leave behind when eating. For example, a slug and a mushroom with bites taken out of it.

There are two sets included:

one set of two-part black & white cardboard rectangles: one square shows the animal, the other the traces they leave behind when eating
one set of pairs of colored cardboard squares of just the animals
one set of pairs of colored cardboard squares of just the traces
