The rules describe how to play dominoes with the black & white pieces, and a couple of variations of memory with the colored pieces.

–user summary

name: Dungeon Scoot
description:
The ancient evil has awakened, and the dungeon is collapsing. RUN!
You've accidentally awakened an ancient evil, and now you're running for your life as the dungeon collapses around you! Rubble, monsters, and treasure are crashing down from the dungeon floor above, and the ancient evil is hot on your heels! Can you make it out of the dungeon alive?

Dungeon Scoot is a fast and fun game with easy to learn rules and quick gameplay. On your turn, play a "Scoot" card to show where you run, and increase your Panic to move even more. Watch out for the rubble and monsters dropping from the floor above, but try to scoop up that treasure as you run past! After each player's turn, draw from the "Collapse" pile and see what falls next...or whether the Ancient Evil advances. If he catches you, you're doomed.

For advanced games, add in the "Alignment" cards, which give each character a secret goal, and change how victory points are scored at the end.

With simple mechanics that elicit surprisingly complex interactions, the mad scramble to the dungeon exit becomes a quick but compelling light strategy game, perfect for repeat plays to satisfy that "just one more game" urge.

Enough talk! The evil is here! RUN!

—description from the publisher

name: Sweets Bingo! Fruit Patisserie
description: Fruit patisserie is a bingo battling card game using eleven cards. Players will play cards to complete a line of three cards (horizontally, vertically or diagonally). The player who plays the biggest card can turn over his bingo card. If there are multiple cards with the largest number, the player who played the card with the lowest number can turn over his bingo card. When to use your shopping card to return all of your cards to your hand is the key to the game. Which player can bingo first and make sweets? It is a game that you can play many times with easy-to-understand, simple rules.
publishers: Little Future (リトルフューチャー)

name: Crimson Sands
description:
Combines memorization, bluffing, economics and combat. Crimson Sands is set in an ancient fantasy world where giant lizards and large flightless birds are used to transport guards and goods between four cities separated by a hostile desert. The birds are fast, but cannot carry much. The lizards are slow, but can carry a great deal.

The players must balance trade goods, guards, and water if their caravans are to reach the other side alive. The game includes miniatures of the beasts that carry the tiles representing these guards, goods and the tiles representing raider opponents.

Besides limited water, the principle danger in the desert is the raiders and their dread leader, the self-styled Raider Queen. At the conclusion of their turn a player must draw an encounter card, view it secretly, and then decide where to place it on the game board. Players can choose ever longer routes to avoid encounter cards or risk the hazard to take a direct route to their goal.

If the raiders are encountered, battle will ensue. The other players control the raiders in these fast-paced contests. The defending player must decide how to best ward off attacks and get as many elements of the caravan to safety as possible. The raiders have to decide whether to intercept and make off with individual beasts or try to eliminate all the guards and capture the entire caravan.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Betting and Bluffing, Commodity Speculation, Hexagon Grid, Memory, Pick-up and Deliver, Point to Point Movement, Trading

name: Aku Ankka matkapeli
description:
A trivia game developed in cooperation with the Finnish Donald Duck magazine. The questions have a heavy emphasis on stories by Carl Barks and Don Rosa.

A stand-alone travel version of Aku Ankka that can also be used as an expansion. Cards contain trivia questions in four categories.

name: 海賊と金塊 (Kaizoku to Kinkai)
description:
User summary
海賊と金塊 (Kaizoku to Kinkai) is a Japanese card game. Players must connect cards that have already been placed in the playing field by setting down cards from their hands in a line. The title of the game translates in English to 'Pirates and Gold Bullion'.

They are two types of cards a player can play:
1) Pirate cards that can be played freely from their hand
2) Gold bullion cards that a player can draw and play from the stack.

If a gold bullion card is placed next to a player's pirate card and the pirate card is stronger, you may claim the gold bullion card. The player who collects the most gold bullion cards wins the game.

Publisher's summary
すでに場に出ているカードと接するようにカードを並べて置いていきます。
カードには手札から自由に出せる海賊カードと山札から引いて出す金塊カードの２種類があります。
金塊カードの隣に置かれた自分の海賊カードの強さがもっとも強いプレイヤーが、その金塊カードを手に入れることができます。
手に入れた金塊カードの合計点数がもっとも多いプレイヤーの勝ちです。

name: Monopoly: Steven Universe
description:
Featuring collectible tokens including Garnet's Gauntlet and Greg's Van along with custom gems and gem clusters. It's monopoly with a Steven Universe twist.
Join the crystal gems as you fuse your way to victory by buying, selling, and trading locations from beach city including Big Donut, Keystone motel and the Temple.
The goal of the game is to be the last player remaining with any money.

—description from the publisher
categories: Economic, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Negotiation
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading

name: Resan till Månen
description:
Object of this space game is to be the first player to reach the moon after leaving Earth

It is a simple roll and move game, where players advance their pawns and obey instructions encountered along the way upon landing on the Roman numerals. The track winds in and out until you reach the moon. The first to do so, wins.

This Swedish space game dates back to around the early 1960s.

name: Wargasm
description:
A card game for 2-4+ players with a modern combat theme

Players share a common deck comprising cards of 4 different types of military unit (Infantry, Vehicle, Artillery, Air). As well as their Unit type these cards also have an attack characteristic, and an event characteristic. These cards can be used in three different ways - as a unit, to attack, or as an event.

In addition there are Intel cards which do not function as a unit but will list an attack and an event, or two events.

Cards being used as Units are kept face-up on the table in front of the controlling player. Cards put into play as units are said to be Deployed.

Players take turns with each turn comprising 5 phases:


Logistics Phase
Draw 4 cards from the deck.

Deploy Phase
You may put 1 unit card into play from your hand.

Attack Phase
You may make 1 attack this phase by playing a card for its attack function. The attack function of a card will specify attacker type and target type. (e.g. Infantry attacks Vehicle). When a card is being used to attack, you must have the appropriate type of Unit in play (deployed) that can make the attack. The attack targets either the opponent’s base or a specific type of Unit that the opponent has in play. As a result of the attack, the attack card is discarded and the target unit is discarded, or if the base was attacked, the target player will gain 1 damage for each unit that attacked. The attacking unit(s) remain in play. Some event cards will allow the defender to negate the Attack.

Event Phase
You may play 1 event card this phase. Discard the event card when played.

Friction Phase
Max hand size is 5 cards. Give excess cards to one or more opponents.



Players are eliminated when they have accumulated 20 or more points of damage. The goal of the game is to be the last player standing.

name: UrgentOlogyBYEBYECHUCHU
description:
Byebyechuchu makes debut with mysterious surprises.
Go with Ology for the delivery!!
Sprint, deliver and upgrade.
Map out the best routes.
Deliver the most merchandises and complete the most orders.

You may collect the goods from bookshops, pizza, beverage and hamburger shops. Find those who want to gain some weight. Deliver the goods to others and get paid. Then you will get stronger. After upgrade, you can get various kinds of fancy abilities.

name: Xenophon and the Ten Thousand
description:
A board game for 1-4+ players in which each player is a unique incarnation of Xenophon and the Ten Thousand. The 10,000 are Greek mercenaries who have come to fight for Cyrus, the younger brother of the Persian King Artaxerxes. Cyrus is killed in battle against the King leaving the Greeks abandoned, deep in hostile territory. The Greeks begin a long march northward to the Black Sea and Greek territory. The player whose pawn reaches the sea first and with the most men is the winner.

There are 2 Tracks:

The Distance Track. This track has 60 numbered spaces. The first space is that of Cunaxa where Cyrus was killed. The last space is the Coastal Greek Colony of Trapezus. Each player has his own uniquely coloured pawn which he moves along


the distance Track. Each space represents about 10 Miles.

The Time Track

This track has 60 numbered spaces. A single neutral pawn is moved a single space after all players have completed a single turn. When a player reaches the sea he should take his coloured pawn from the distance track and place it on the time track on the current space to mark how long his journey took. Each space represents about 2 days.


Each player starts with 10,000 men. Men are lost during the journey due to fighting, exposure, starvation, and desertion. Paper and pencil to keep track of your manpower total.

Each Food Token represents 1 days supply worth of food for the Army. Lack of Food Tokens will result in accumulation of Starvation Tokens. Mutiny Tokens represent dissent and despondency amongst the ranks. Anger Tokens represent the accumulation of barbarian forces arrayed against you.

Players share an action deck. Most cards will increase or reduce the value of a target die-roll. Most improve your rolls. Others will be to the detriment of your opponent.

Players take turns with each turn comprising 16 Phases:

Draw Phase - The current player draws 3 cards.
Route Phase - Roll against the Route Table. The result will generate modifiers for one or more of the forage, travel and battle rolls.
Weather Phase – Roll against the Weather Table. The weather conditions will generate modifiers for the forage and travel rolls
Satrap Phase – Roll against the Satrap table to determine whether you encounter a Satrap.
Negotiations Phase - If you encountered a Satrap this turn make a negotiation roll. This will result in gaining Anger or Food tokens.
Attack Phase - Make an Attack Roll. If your result is equal to or less than the number of AT you have, you are attacked by Barbarians.
Battle Phase - If you are attacked by Barbarians remove 1 Anger Token and make a battle roll to determine the number of casualties.
Exposure Phase - If the weather was harsh this turn make an exposure roll and lose men accordingly.
Forage Phase - You may choose not to forage, if so skip this turn. Otherwise make a roll against the forage table to gain a combination of food and anger tokens
Consumption Phase - If you currently have a food token, discard all your starvation tokens. Discard 1 food token. If you have no food tokens to lose gain 1 starvation token.
Starvation Phase - If you have Starvation Tokens make a roll to determine the number of men lost.
Morale Phase – Roll on morale table to determine whether you gain a mutiny token.
Rally Phase - If you have mutiny tokens make a rally roll to see whether you can remove any of them.
Desertion Phase - If you have mutiny tokens make a desertion roll to see whether any men desert.
Travel Phase - Make a travel roll to determine how far your pawn advances on the distance map. This roll will be modified by weather and route markers and other activities undertaken during the turn.
End Phase - Max hand size is 7 cards. Discard excess cards.


The game ends when all players have finally reached the last space on the Distance Track. Players then calculate their scores:
Player Score = (Remaining men) divided by (number of turns to reach the sea)
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Hand Management, Open Drafting

name: Volt Egyszer Egy lakoma
description: Roll and move game where players try to be the first to reach the end of the path by overcoming written movement instructions on each space.

name: Fruit Ninja: Slice & Dice
description:
Fruit Ninja: Slice & Dice is a strategic dice game for 2 to 4 players where each players are trying impress Sensei by slashing specific combos of Fruits.

Each round is splited in 2 phases:


Rolling Phase: Simultaneously and in real-time, all players have 20 seconds to roll up to 3 times their dice.



Buying Phase: In clock-wise order, starting from the first player, all players get a chance to spend their dice result on Combo Cards and claim one of the 6 Goal cards.


The game ends as soon as the Combo Deck runs out. The winner is the one with the most points!

—description from the publisher

A Kickstarter campaign was initiated for a series of 3 games based on the popular app game. Having not met the expected goals, the campaign was terminated. From the 3 games announced, only 1 made it to print: Fruit Ninja: Combo Party.
mechanics: Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Push Your Luck

name: Wacky Willy's Word Warehouse
description:
The objective of Wacky Willy’s Word Warehouse is to complete your Word-O-Gram before your opponents and read aloud the ridiculous story it manufactured. Word-O-Grams are ridiculous stories with missing components, Who, what, When, Where and Why. Each player will get a complete 5-set of each of the Word-O-Gram’s missing categories. Category cards are to be kept separately. Wordsmiths will take turns rolling the die which will determine which category is played that round. The category will display an unrelated question in which you compete for the best answer. The winning Wordsmith of that round gets to add the answer to their Word-O-Gram in the matching category. Once they have one of each category, the Word-O-Gram’s story will be readable and complete. If a player gets 5 of the same category they may trade 4 in to get one they are missing. Remember, the goal in playing cards is not only to get picked but mainly to complete your Word-O-Gram, so choose cards that will impress your opponents but also play well with your story.

—description from the publisher

name: Size Matters
description:
Bigger is definitely better.

Roll the big, purple dice and score points by building the biggest or longest dong, schlong, wiener, peeper, schmecky...you get it. Another roll of the bulbous consequence die can add points of take them away. So, like a lot of things involving manhood, this game's about luck and risk. ;)

Contains:
8 Purple Dice
Circumstance Dice
Dice Cup
Dice Tray
Score Pad
2 Tent Pads
Rules

Players take turn's rolling dice trying to build the longest penis out of dice. Player may have to roll the larger consequence die and that can cause players to gain additional or lose points.

name: Killing Code: Venice Vendetta – Dead End Bridge
description:
Promo card for Killing Code: Venice Vendetta.

This card allows the player acting as the Killer use one more killing method to murder the target.
categories: Deduction, Expansion for Base-game, Medieval, Murder/Mystery
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Area Movement, Team-Based Game, Variable Player Powers

name: El Joc de Granollers
description:
Welcome to Granollers!, a dynamic and lively city. Explore the streets and know all the city's most attractive spots. Have you camera prepared to capture its entire heritage or pay attention to learn thousand of histories hidden in this town founded by Romans, which has become a point of commercial and cultural exchange over the course of centuries. See who knows it best!

In "El Joc de Granollers", each player has its own deck and uses it to visit the city and to take photos. The game uses the mechanics of deck building and press your luck, so when you get cards of Granollers' sites they become part of your deck.

"El Joc de Granollers" is a light and family game that introduces these mechanics to new players.
mechanics: Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Push Your Luck

name: Alligator Jones: The Game
description:
The game is a Roll and move game set in Australia. The aim is to be the first player to complete 5 tour cards and get back to Fullasaboot Pub and shout the bar.

The game is for 2 to 6 players, all players start at the pub and receive their first tour card, once they roll a 5 (shout the bar) they then get to move out. To complete their first tour.

There are three types of Tours, river, Railway and Track

The board comes in several pieces and fits together like a jigsaw, the parts are stored in a styrofoam box in the shape of Australia
mechanics: Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Battle Quest Adventure Game
description:
Battle Quest is an adventure game for 1-4 people. Each player takes the roll of a heroic adventurer, seeking to make his or her fortune in the dark and dangerous areas of the world. It is a world of dragons and ogres, knights and wizards, swords and sorcery, where the life of your adventurer can be snuffed out at any moment.

Players start by choosing one of 4 characters - warrior, mage, thief, and treasure hunter. They then spend gold to buy a weapons, armor, equipment, and spells. Once that is done, the players set of for the dungeon. Players are exploring a hidden dungeon. Within the dungeon an ancient dragon lives. Players roll 2d6 to determine what they encounter on their turn - could be a creature, trap, pit, getting lost, or a locked door. Players can head back to town to buy more equipment. Encounters are resolved with 1 or a series of d6 die rolls. If they survive the encounter, players roll on a treasure table to determine what they have gained.

When they are ready, players can choose to encounter the dragon. First player to kill the dragon wins.

—description from the publisher
categories: Adventure, Dice, Fantasy, Fighting, Print & Play

name: The Garden Bird Game
description:
A simplified P-n-P board game with small play tiles with a design of play for younger players to help with matching four types of birds in a garden, counting colours (flower beds), counting scores along a score track, taking turns and taking tiles from a cup or bag. The game can also be played by older players as well, as there are Advanced Optional Rules included – the game can actually get quite tactical for older players. The game is designed for 2 players but can be played with 4 in pairs.

The correct placing of the bird types and the 'wild tile' fish pond tiles scores points which are recorded on the included score track and the winner has the highest score at the end of the game. There is also some final end-game scoring of only the coloured background tiles of the birds that have been placed within each players own columns of garden squares. Bonus points can also be scored by correctly placing the 'wild tile' fish ponds in a player's garden column.

This P-n-P home-made test version includes the game-board (that represents a garden of squares and a score track), a counter-mix and a set of game rules for use by families with younger (and older) gamers at BGG to try out. It should only take about 15-30 mins to play a game.

name: Winston Cup NASCAR Team Trivia Game
description:
Nascar Trivia! It brings the thrills of racing right into your living room! It is a Collector's First Edition Game , and only 25,000 were ever made!

Relive the exciting record-setting performances by the legends of stock car racing. When you answer the questions correctly, you advance around the NASCAR Winston Cup, International Raceway; Completing Laps, Pit Stops, Making unbelievable passes and experiencing unfortunate encounters with retaining walls.

Will your Knowledge and Luck drive you to the checkered flag?

name: Max Farmer
description:
The players must help Max the farmer to harvest all the vegetables, but watch out! Because if you get a worm you lose the whole harvest and you'll also have the harvest before the crow reaches the market garden and eats all the vegetables.

All the players work to achieve the objective together. In a COOPERATIVE game the top priority is for everyone to achieve a goal together.




























Los jugadores deberán ayudar a Max el granjero a cosechar todas las hortalizas, pero ¡cuidado!, porque si te salelun gusano pierdes toda la cosecha y además deberás intentar cosechar antes de que llegue el cuervo al huerto y se coma todas las hortalizas.

Todos los jugadores trabajan para conseguir juntos el objetivo. En un juego COOPERATIVO lo prioritario es conseguir un objetivo entre todos.

name: A-Morphos
description:
Model and guess without saying the prohibited answer!

Use plasticine to model the pictures that appear on the cards so that the other players an guess what you're doing.

But watch out! On each other card there's a prohibited picture and if another player names it you'll both lose points.

¡Modela y adivina sin decir la respuesta prohibida!

Modela con plastilina los dibujos que aparecen en las tarjetas para conseguir que los otros jugadores adivinen qué estás haciendo.

Pero cuidado, en cada tarjeta hay un dibujo prohibido, y si otro jugador lo nombra ambos perderéis puntos.

name: Mermaid's Purse
description:
An epic game of Put & Take using colorful Mermaid jewels. Polished Stones, 1 Wagering Top, Pouch & 20 page Handbook with game rules and Mermaid legend.
—description from the publisher

The Mermaid's Purse is just a spot on the table that contains treasure.
Player 1 is the "spinner" and sets the ante, which can be any amount of jewels, gems, pearls or gold. They can also set any other rules they desire for the round.
Each player pays the ante to play. Spinner then spins the top and performs the action that comes up.
The top is then passed to the next player who becomes the Spinner.
Repeat for as many rounds as you want and winner is the one with the most treasure.

The top has the following sides/results:

T1 - Take 1 jewel/gem from the purse
T2 - Take 2 jewels/gems from the purse
P1 - Put 1 jewel/gem in the purse
P2 - Put 1 jewels/gems in the purse
AP - All players put 1 jewel/gem in the purse
TA - The spinner takes of the jewels/gems in the purse and the round is over.

name: Motor Mouth Card Game
description: Make curious and crazy word connections! Race to play your entire hand by naming examples that fit the letter and category cards.

name: Elementabble
description:
Elementabble is like a game of scrabble with a scientific twist.
The Players use tiles to form words on a gameboard, but instead of the Alphabet the tiles show the chemical elements of the periodic system.

Every Player draws 10 tiles and gets two "-273,15 °C" tiles. A new word has to cover one of two startingpoints on the board or use at least one element of a word already on the board or be separated by an absolute zero tile from a word on the board.
Some Elements can also be used as Joker, in that case you cannot get points from them.
The Player score points according to the atomic numbers or the atomic mass (e.g. if a Joker element is used as the element and not as Joker). There are Bonus Points for longer words.
There are 4 levels of difficulty.

The games Ends when one player reaches at least 1000 Points, no one made a new word for two rounds or a Player forms the word "Schluss" ("end").
The single player game ends at reaching 4500 Points or if the player exchanges three tiles in a row without forming a new word. The game is lost if the Player didn't reach 4500 Points.

name: Øisteins Drodlespill
description:
Game teaching kids to draw. A player draws a card, tries to draw it, and the other players try to guess what it is.
—User summary

name: Newfoundlandia
description:
This trivia game is "For those who know Newfoundland and for those who want to know it better."

"Newfoundlandia is a cultural experience probing our past and present. Dabble in Viking lore. Recall the Smallwood Era. Saunter through the alleyways of North America's oldest city."

The ARTS & CULTURE category tests your knowledge of Newfoundland's life style, language, music, literature, arts and sports. PEOPLE & POLITICS draws on your knowledge of politics past and present and your ability to recall who's who and who was who in Newfoundland. HISTORY & GEOGRAPHY deals mainly with the events of our past, nomenclature, and general geographic knowledge. The TOWNIE TRIVIA section is designed to test your knowledge of St. John's, past and present.

Although every culture has its unique features, Newfoundland, to Newfoundlanders, is more than a quaint place. It's home. Newfoundlandia is about our land, our people and our ways. Based on our history, geography, and culture NEWFOUNDLANDIA will provide hours of entertainment for Newfoundlanders at home and abroad.

name: Malifaux: Ryle
description:
Ryle is an expansion unit for Malifaux. He belongs to the Guild faction.

From the Malifaux Tactica Wiki page:

Overview
Ryle Hoffman is the older brother of C. Hoffman and the end result of breach psychosis and the wonders of Ramos. This once-brilliant individual was almost destroyed entering Malifaux, and only Ramos' hasty work was able to rebuild him into the creature he is now.
Ryle is a melee oriented construct with above average damage tracks and a few tricks to stay alive.
external image 14d94912-b346-4e5d-8fc7-bd27dac8eab7.jpg
Table of Contents
Overview
Mobility
Offense
Resilience
Soulstones
Tricks and Tips While Joining a Crew
Tricks and Tips While Leading a Crew
Building a Crew
Playing Against Ryle
Mobility
He has a strictly below average Walk and Charge but his (0) Socially Repressed allows him to push 4" aways from a model within 12" so with good positioning you can move him 12" a turn. The Socially Repressed action also allows him to escape melee easily if needed (eg. taking interact actions).

Offense
Damage is where Ryle shines. He has a gatling gun attached to one hand and a mechanical fist attached to the other one.

Hydraulic Fist
This as an above Ml stat and a remarkable 3/5/7 damage profile. Moreover it comes with Critical Strike so if you use a soulstone for Rams and cheat a high Ram card you will be doing 5/7/9. This is enough to kill a large proportion minions model in one action and threaten the rest with two.

Modified Steam Gatling Hun
This is Ryle ranged attack and comes with an average Sh stat and lower damage profile than his fist. However it comes standard with a positive on the attack flip allowing you to target models in cover at your leisure and an automatic Trigger that gives a positive flip to the damage, meaning you can get the moderate or severe damage far more reliably.

The other Trigger Raking Fire requires an extra Ram and allows you to take the Modified Steam Gatling attack against another model which has not been targeted with it this activation. It also comes with no restriction on the number of times you can use it, so as long as you have soulstones or Rams in hands and eligible targets you can keep on firing away. This is immensely powerful against crews that clump together such as gremlins or spider swarms. However, against more elite crews you will find yourself using Concentrated Burst almost exclusively.

Resilience
Ryle's weakest points are his low Df and terrible Wp stats, both of which are well below average for a Henchman. This makes him vulnerable to potshots from enemy Minions and Enforcers and means you'll rarely be able to win defensive duels against Masters or other Henchmen. He does come with a few tricks to help with this though.

Firstly he has Armor +1 and decent wounds take the edge off weaker attacks. He also has the Grinding Halt Trigger to gain an additional Armor +2 with Tomes on his Df. This means you can often pitch a weak tomes or spend a soulstone to cut 4 damage down to 1, however it cannot protect himself from attacks that target Wp or those that ignore Armor.

He can also heal with (0) Field Repairs at the cost of a card, letting him recoup wounds in the thick of things whenever you don't need to use Socially Repressed. This can also be used on friendly constructs, which is a handy way to spread the healing around.

Finally as a Henchman he can use Soulstones to prevent damage and to aid defensive flips.

Soulstones
Ryles has several options to use his soulstones. He can use them to increase the damage of his Mechanical Fist, automatically trigger Raking Fire on his gatling gun or to protect himself but adding Tomes to his Df. As well as that with his low stats Df and Wp stats you will want to keep a few stones for damage prevention flips if he gets in trouble.

Tricks and Tips While Joining a Crew
Ryle is a construct so he has obvious synergies with C. Hoffman. Hoffman can Power Loop Ryle to increase his stats and use Machine Puppet to get around his low mobility and provide more attacks.

His Field Repairs action plays well with with Hoffman but also gives him a bit of synergy with any crew with an interest in taking some constructs, such as Lucius the various construct minions.

He is also a good choice for any crew that wants a shooting model with some extra melee punch, meaning Sonnia and Perdita might like to take him as insurance against enemies getting too close to them.

Tricks and Tips While Leading a Crew

Strategies and Schemes
Ryle is pretty killy and tends to lean towards strategies and schemes which reward eliminating enemy models. He's also reasonably mobile and can support other constructs with his (0) actions and upgrades so he can serve as a dangerous and durable anchor for a crew more focused on marker based schemes.

Building a Crew
Francisco Ortega is useful if you are building a crew around Ryle as he can buff Df and Wp. He also provides ranged support, movement shenanigans and decent melee presence, so the two form an effective tag team.
Including constructs in a crew is also a good idea as they can benefit from Field Repairs and Ryles construct oriented upgrades.
Finally Ryle lacks a bit of speed so including fast objective runners should be a priority if needed.
Playing Against Ryle
Ryle is in many ways a glass cannon. Focus on him and he will die. This is especially true if you have models that can target Wp or ignore Armor. Models that can ignore armour are also useful specially if Ryle is in an C. Hoffman crew.

Do not let him hit you with his Hydraulic Fist. It's every bit as dangerous as it sounds, so you're often better off hitting him from range or after he's activated.

name: Knight Court
description:
Knight Court is a tiny chess-like abstract. Each side has a knight, bishop, and rook on a 3x3 board.

A captured bishop or rook is returned to its owner, who can re-introduce it onto any open space on a future turn. In contrast, a knight in jeopardy of capture is compelled to move, because checkmating an opponent's knight wins the game.

name: Box Quiz: Magt
description:
One of the over 50 implementations of the Box Quiz series, this one with the theme 'Power'.

The game consists of a tin box with 50 questions and answers within a category, here about power. It is a small and simple quiz game, where players simply answer the different questions.

name: StoryWorld
description:
StoryWorld is a card game whose main objective is to tell a story among all the players using their imagination and creativity. It's a game without language dependence for all ages that guarantees really fun moments. Ideal for children, fun for adults.

It's not a competitive game, rather it is a collaborative game that seeks to strengthen teamwork and moments of coexistence.

The game is composed of cards, which only contain drawings that must be interpreted by the players when telling their part of the story. Each player decides what to say during his turn following the course of the story.

—description from the designer
categories: Card Game, Children's Game, Educational, Fantasy, Humor, Party Game, Word Game

name: Mission: Escape
description:
Escape-Room for kids from 7 and up.
To stop the counter, kids have to retrieve a key from a plastic cage, using dexterity. With this key they can activate a "Quizmaster" which gives them three riddles (on cards). If they can solve three consecutively they retrieve a second key, used to stopthe timer.
It can be replayed, because the riddles are card based and there are enough cards (with different levels of difficulty) for 20 games or so.

name: Eight Is Great
description:
From the box: First player to lose all their cards wins! Fun for up to 8 players, ages 6 and up."

A card game that is basically Uno with a light LDS theme and without most of the special cards. There are ten characters in four different colors as well as "Eight Is Great" cards as wilds.

Players are dealt five cards to start the game. A card from the deck is flipped face-up to start the discard pile. Players can play a card from their hand of either the same color or of the same character as the face-up card in the discard. If they cannot match a card or play an eight is Great card as a wild to change the color, they draw one card from the draw pile.

Play continues until one player plays their last card and wins.

name: De Feiten van 2016 op een rij
description:
Review the year 2016 with this 'talk & guess game'. Each time, three news facts are presented and the purpose is to put them in the correct chronological order. Score a point when guessed right. With the 'double or nothing' card, you can earn two points per correct guess.. or zero at all.
This compact and easy to learn game contains 104 news facts which allows for unlimited combinations.
—description from the publisher (Translated)

Een 'raad & praat-spel' waarmee je gezamenlijk spelenderwijs het jaar 2016 nogmaals doorneemt. Steeds 3 nieuwsfeiten van het afgelopen jaar liggen naast elkaar... raad jij de chronologische volgorde? Per goed antwoord scoor je 1 punt... tenzij je de 'dubbel- of niets-kaart' hebt gepakt en strijd voor 2... of 0 punten per goed antwoord! Dit handzame, eenvoudige en leerzame spel bevat 104 nieuwsfeiten die in ontelbaar veel combinaties gespeeld kunnen worden.
—description from the publisher (Dutch)

name: Togo
description: Togo is a miniature game that portrays naval combat in the Russo-Japanese War of 1904-1905. Miniatures represent ships and are maneuvered across a 4 by 6 foot area. Six-sided dice are used to determine various events, such as gunfire hits and the result of damage control.

name: Pictureka: Mega Mat
description:
The preschooler version of the classic Pi0ctureka game with a giant mat

Pictureka! is a new kind of game, both in mechanic as in artwork. The mechanic is invigorating with its large square gaming tiles. The game board is composed of 3 by 3 game tiles, so the game board on which is played is a huge square of 63 cm x 63 cm. This is large enough for several players to be able to play the game at the same time. The game board is “alive”, it is not a static board as the tiles are flipped over, turned and moved. So it is not possible to memory map the board. The mechanic of an ever changing board makes it not only fun; also the challenge is kept into the game all the time.

A game turn
Players will have to throw a color dice at the beginning of their turn. According to the color thrown (3 possibilities) they must draw a mission card of the same color. There are 3 kinds of missions.

How to win the game?
Be the first one to have successfully accomplished 10 missions. Each successful mission gives 1 point, so be the first one to get 10 points.
The artwork is something not to be found in ‘standard’ games. The personal drawing style of the artist Eugene makes this a kind of playing artwork.
mechanics: Pattern Recognition, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Rock'n Rodeo: The Shufflettes
description:
The Shufflettes is a promo for the German board game Rock'n Rodeo.

The Shufflettes are a fictional band consisting of members of the German blog erklaerpeer.de. They are a Local Band and you can book them for 5K.

—user summary
mechanics: Hand Management, Tile Placement, Worker Placement

name: Pokémon TCG: Black Collection/White Collection Expansion
description:
User summary

Black Collection/White Collection - ブラックコレクション · ホワイトコレクション is a Japanese-language expansion roughly corresponding to the contemporaneous English-language expansion Black & White.

The expansion includes 112 cards.
categories: Card Game, Collectible Components, Expansion for Base-game

name: 5-Minute Dragon Slayer
description:
Solitaire, print and play game. The Hero must inflict 8 wounds on the dragon before the dragon inflicts 4 wounds on the Hero.

The board shows the body of the dragon, divided in boxes with target numbers in them. The player places Aim cubes to indicate the area the Hero is targeting, and rolls dice. An aim cube must be removed to reroll the dice, narrowing the area that can be hit.

After rolling, the player uses the dice to attack the dragon and/or cast spells.

Next, the player rolls to determine the type of attack the dragon will perform, and resolves that attack.

The game continues until either the Hero or the dragon is dead. It *is* possible that they will both die in the same turn, ending the game in a tragic tie.

—description from the publisher

name: Flight of Pollen
description:
When a tree is old enough, it starts to make flowers. The flower is a message from the tree to you, the pollinators. Calling you to come by day and by night – to drink its nectar, to pick up its pollen grains, and to transport these to another tree of the same species. Because it’s ready to breed.

Flight of Pollen is a semi-cooperative game where you pollinate as many trees as possible by visiting them with a variety of different New Zealand pollinators, with different pollinators being more successful under different weather conditions. Rounds are split into day and night segments, with different pollinators active during the day versus the night. Each pollinator must move from one plant to the next of the same species, moving pollen between them until all of the plants of the target species are pollinated- if any are missed, the game is lost. One or more different native New Zealand plant are the focus for each of the four rounds, and as the rounds progress more pollinator species are added, as well as more plant species with more challenging pollination requirements. If all of the required plants have been pollinated, then the team that collected the most berries wins the game.

Over each of the four levels different trees send out differing messages in their flowers. You’ll need to work together to complete each level, moving as the elements allow.

As flowers pollinated by you (or the wind) become seeds or berries, teams can collect the resulting berries.

Locally made, with recycled materials and FSC card

name: Emojical Mau-Mau
description:
Now play Crazy Eights crazier than ever!

Playing cards with numbers are history. In this new interpretation of Crazy Eights, emojis are the name of the game. Who will be the first to shed all their cards and win the game? Emojical Mau-Mau contains completely new and crazy action cards which put additional spice in the game. "Donating" and "Gambling" cards will drive your fellow players crazy – and get you on your way to victory.

Easy to learn rules - Quick game start - Great fun for the whole family!

—description from the publisher

name: Le Monde en 100 Pays
description:
This game makes you discover and know 100 countries. From your travels, you will bring back "Souvenirs" of the countries.
Goal of the game:

Get the "Souvenir" cards from each country
Be the richest at the end of the game by having the most cards possible "Souvenir" and capitalizing the most points possible

name: Caduta Libera
description:
Answer correctly to all the question to increase your possibility to win as much money as possible. In this game, everytime someone is wrong, another one wins.

Every match is composed of 10 rounds: at the end of the round, an amount of money is assigned to the player who makes is opponent to fall down. The player with most money at the end of the game, will win.

name: President Bigly
description:
A light-hearted game of pigs, politics and pandemonium.

This is a card game where you’re creating as much chaos as possible, battling your friends and trying your best to avoid any signs of tranquility… all with the hopes of blazing a path to personal glory. There are two fun and strategically very different “ways” of playing President Bigly and playing is simple… BUT only one pig can be left at the end!

This game is appropriate for all ages, political persuasions and pig lovers alike.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Hand Management, Player Elimination, Push Your Luck, Take That

name: Xiangqi: 4 Players
description:
This is a four handed version of the abstract game Xiangqi, the latter also known as Chinese chess.

In the tradition game, the board is divided in half by a line called the river. In the four player version, one might call this a sea. Then each player uses a standard set of pieces set up on their half of a standard board. (Hence only two sets of standard pieces are needed. Ownership of pieces is marked by their orientation since they would read as right-side-up to the controlling player.) Where the river would normally be is extended into a large empty square. Pieces cross but do not go onto this space, the sea. Lines of the board extend across the sea no differently than across the river as far as players opposite each other are concerned. The lines of movement connect to players at either side's boards as if the board on which a player's pieces begin were rotated toward the player on either side. Play is clockwise and otherwise the standard rules of xiangqi apply in all instances.

If at the start of a player's turn, the player's "king" (to use Western terminology for simplicity) is checkmated-- whether by a single player's pieces or pieces of multiple players in combination-- that player is immediately eliminated from the game. Only the "king" is taken from the board but that player's turn is thereafter skipped. Remaining pieces may be taken but do not otherwise move. The last remaining player wins.

This is a game intended primarily for DIY play. Two sets of pieces are needed along with four half-boards. These can be printed from files on BGG or fashioned using multiple sets from the traditional game.

To play a 3 player variant, one of the 4 half-boards is simply not used. A 2 player variant would be the traditional game.
mechanics: Grid Movement, Player Elimination, Point to Point Movement

name: Draw Poker
description:
Draw poker is any poker variant in which each player is dealt a complete hand before the first betting round, and then develops the hand for later rounds by replacing, or "drawing", cards.

A complete hand is dealt to each player, face-down, and after betting, players are allowed to attempt to change their hand (with the object of improving it) by discarding unwanted cards and being dealt new ones. Five-card draw is the most famous variation in this family.

Five-card draw (also known as a Cantrell draw) is a poker variant that is considered the simplest variant of poker, and is the basis for video poker. As a result, it is often the first variant learned by new players.

Source: Wikipedia, "[en.wikipedia.org]", available under the CC-BY-SA License.
mechanics: Betting and Bluffing, Player Elimination, Set Collection

name: Face to Face
description: Each of the 60 multi-level challenge cards will show you a combination of cubes that needs to be recreated. That's the easy bit. The hard bit is working out how to position the faces of the cubes correctly. Rows and columns of cubes must show either every face with the same expression, with each being a different colour, or every face having a different expression, but all the same colour. The rules have to apply from the front, back, sides and from above.
publishers: FoxMind Israel, The Happy Puzzle Company

name: Hustle: Card Game
description:
If you can master the poker face, And read the faces of others. If you've got the calm for Russian roulette, But can make others fall under pressure. If you can charm, and not be charmed yourself. And manipulate but not be manipulated. If you can persuade like a King, But not be led astray. And make others believe in illusions, By creating smoke and mirrors. If you can adapt when the odds are against you, And look cool when the game turns. If you can win in the face of defeat. And know when to lose a won game. Then my friend.... You have what it takes to be a Great Hustler. Hustle card game is an exciting new game that'll have you and your friends and family hooked. It's a fast-paced game that changes at every turn. One minute you're winning, and then suddenly the odds are against you. The next minute you may be losing but using your charm and skill and with a little bit of luck you can win in the face of defeat. The rules are simple and very quick to master. It's a game that requires confidence, skill and keeping cool under pressure. Call out values for opponents to match and the first to get rid of all cards wins the game. But be careful of different Hustle cards and opponents who may try to charm, manipulate and hustle to a win. Perfect for all ages and for bringing friends and family together. Remember you can either Hustle or be Hustled!!

—description from the back of the box

name: Auto écolo
description:
THE PURPOSE OF THE GAME: To be the player who has converted the most "Oxygen" throughout his course.
THE RULE OF THE GAME: Who will have enough oxygen to finish the game? "Depending on your behavior on the course, you will quickly see that your Oxygen supply is limited. You will be able to stay on some huts to try to make more ecological gestures that will give you Oxygen. You will be able to plant trees to put Oxygen in the wind farm or to walk there to take a breath of Oxygen. Be environmentally friendly, the first come will not necessarily be the winner.
Everyone will discover that they can choose to adopt behaviors in favor of a less polluting means of transport.
mechanics: Events, Roll / Spin and Move, Track Movement

name: Piet Piraat: Piratengevaar
description:
Pirate danger is a running and gathering game.
The players each leave in a corner and try to reach the central island as many times as possible. They charge one gold coin each time they move to their home base. They are all hindered by one joint opponent who takes on the role of Captain One Eye. He too tries to collect as many gold pieces as possible, but only obtains them by taking them from some pirate. Dolphins must make it possible for the pirates to reach their goal faster, while sharks support the Captain.

—user summary

name: Games and More: Polarion
description:
With this game of skill one block of ice is knocked away around the polar bear. Take care: when the polar bear loses its balance and falls down, you will have lost the game. Slowly and surely the polar bear is standing on extremely shaky ground. By carefully selecting the ice blocks, you can get your opponent's polar bear to fall.

—description from the publisher

name: Noboribetsu (のぼりべつ)
description:
In Noboribetsu, a.k.a. のぼりべつ, each player wants to build a fine city, but you never know what you're going to get — and in the end your plans might just get shot to hell anyway.

Each player starts with an onsen (hot springs) card, and a deck of twelve locations, twelve characters, and four Hell cards is shuffled. On a turn, the active player rolls the die. On a roll of 2-5, they take the top card of the deck and add it to their city. If it's a location, they place it on the road from their hot springs; if it's a character they place it in a location or hot springs; if it's Hell, hey, it's also a location, so it gets connected to the road.

On a roll of 1 or 6, the first player to call "Noboribetsu!" gets to take the taxi (which allows them to draw two cards on a roll of 2-5) and move one top card in a city. They can steal an opponent's location or character; they can move a character to a matching location; or they can place a lone Hell card on an opponent's location.

When the deck runs out, players score nothing for Hell-inflicted locations, 2 points for each location and matching character card on it, and 1 point for all other cards. Whoever scores the most points earns 1 victory point, and after multiple games whoever earns 3 victory points first wins.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Set Collection, Take That

name: Goosebumps: The Card Game of Monster Mayhem
description:
Goosebumps: The Card Game of Monster Mayhem is a furious battle between monsters. Giant Mantis versus Werewolf. Slappy versus the Mummy. This easy and fun card game uses different characteristics to determine which monster will come out on top. Features large oversized cards with art from the Scholastic books.

Shuffle the monster cards, Slappy card, and Mastermind card together and deal all 60 cards. All players place their cards face down in a draw pile in front of them.

The game is played in 6 rounds. In each round, players battle their monsters to win a trophy. Trophies are awarded in the same order as outlined on the monster cards. Ie: in round 1, players only use the Strength ability when battling each other.

Player 1 takes the top card from their draw pile, places the card face up on the table, and declares either “high” or “low”. All the other players flip over their top card and place them face up on the table. Players now battle by comparing their monster’s ability ratings. If “high” was declared, the monster with the highest rating wins the battle. If “low” was declared, the monster with the lowest rating wins the battle.

Both Slappy and Mastermind are special cards. They have a 1 or 9 rating for all abilities (depending on whether “high” or “low” is declared).

The player who wins the battle places all the cards from the battle into their winnings pile, and then takes the top card from their
draw pile and declares “high” or “low” for the next battle. Play continues in this manner until all the monsters have done battle and there are no monster cards left

When the round is over, players count the number of cards in their winnings pile. The player with the most cards wins the round, and collects the corresponding trophy card.

Repeat this process 5 more rounds for the remaining abilities and award trophy cards in the same manner.

The game ends when all 6 trophies have been won. The winner is the player with the most trophies.
categories: Card Game, Children's Game, Fighting, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Novel-based, Science Fiction

name: Skyrim: Chapter I (fan expansion for T.I.M.E Stories)
description:
- Wake up...
- Where am I? Why are my hands tied? And why can't I remember anything about my last time transfert?

This Time Stories fan scenario is the 1rst chapter of my SKYRIM Trilogy.
It takes place in 4E 201 in an heroic fantasy environment.

Updates:
- 28/12/2017 : V2. Major update. Improve texts. Change Places.
- 14/05/2018 : V3. Correct few typos.
- 19/07/2018 : V4. Add riddles.
- 05/09/2018 : V5. Add new riddles.
>> This scenario will not be updated anymore.

To download the scenario (PDF):
https://drive.google.com/open?id=1cZ_9ht-WSxummil7kLYrSmIW6R...
Print it in A4, both sides of the paper.

To download the scenario (.DOCX, best quality):
https://drive.google.com/file/d/1mr5Zo98GeQxI__010L3oGZ8PN9I...
Print it in A4, one sides of the paper and fold the cards.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Exploration, Fan Expansion
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Turn Order: Time Track, Variable Player Powers

name: SPLAT!!!
description:
Are you ready for some Paintball action but you can’t get to the park? Then come and join the Kids of Patterson Street in their debut game SPLAT!!!

In SPLAT!!! You have to out play your opponents using the four cards in your hand to scheme and outsmart your fellow players. Once you get covered in paint, you will be eliminated from the game and have to watch the action of your fellows. But, don’t think that you have to survive until the end to win. The other way to end is just like the game Connect Four and get four matching colors in a row. That will automatically win you the game. You can play with a single buddy or grab an entire gang of eight and settle down for some quick and easy fun.
mechanics: Pattern Recognition, Player Elimination, Take That

name: Star Trek: Attack Wing – Sabotaged Systems
description:
This card is the competitive prize for the episode Star Trek: Attack Wing Organized Play Tournament, "Resource Rumble."

Unique Independent Tech (3 SP)
During the planning phase, you may discard Sabotaged Systems and target an opposing ship within range 3. Switch that ship's Primary Weapon and Agility Values until the end of the round.
categories: Aviation / Flight, Dice, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Science Fiction, Wargame
mechanics: Action Queue, Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement, Simultaneous Action Selection, Variable Phase Order

name: Circuit Breaker
description:
Circuit Breaker is a casual strategy game that can be played solo or with up to two other friends. All players attempt to successfully re-wire their own houses in time for a hastily scheduled house party, and they score points by connecting a variety of quirky electrical doodads to their home circuits. Resource management and a crafty rodent will be put to use in a fun and cheeky race to be the most "happening" place on the block.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Set Collection, Take That, Tile Placement

name: Book of Mormon: Mania
description:
This is a Book of Mormon themed game of Nerts. Here is the description from the back of the game:
"This fast-paced game combines the concentration of Solitaire with the quickness of Speed - and throws in a Book of Mormon twist. Each player is given one of the decks of 48 cards representing the Nephites, Lamanites, Jaredites, or Mulekites. Players try to be first to rid themselves of their pride piles by building prosperity piles in the middle of the table. The fun rises to a feverish pitch as everyone begins flipping and placing cards at the same time!
The breathless action comes to a screeching halt when the first 'pride-less" person yells out whatever favorite Book of Mormon name was chosen at the beginning of the hand - if they can remember it!"
categories: Action / Dexterity, Card Game, Party Game, Real-time, Religious

name: Mêlée, the Medieval Combat Card Game
description:
Mêlée is a maneuver and fight, dice-less card game of medieval hand-to-hand combat. The game is for two or more players. It recreates combat with playing cards that represent individual warriors and warhorses. In game play, Mêlée is like a traditional miniatures game, except that it uses cards rather than miniatures -- i.e., a miniatures game without the miniatures -- making it very affordable. Multiple sets of decks are being manufactured, allowing it to serve as a collectible.

Battles are fought on a table top, upon an imagined grid of card-sized columns and ranks. Alternatively, players may either create their own or purchase a large scale roll up play mat so that spacing is more visually apparent, though this is not required by any means.

The game is designed for simplicity and ease of play. It is challenging and enables fast-paced play in 30 minutes or less, even when there are 50 warriors or more on each side. The biggest limitation is the size of the gaming table available, rather than the cost or availability of armies of warrior cards.

The game designer's goal was to make a medieval combat game that cuts out the many complexities that often bog down miniatures combat games. Instead, the focus was on rendering a more historically realistic experience on the battlefield with colorful and unique coats of arms carried by each warrior, as depicted in large size on the cards. Launched through Kickstarter, the first sets of the game had cards that were sponsored by individual backers whose names and coats of arms appeared on each warrior card.

While most miniatures and fighting/combat games use various forms of hit points, unit points, and strengths, and these are slowly degraded in various engagements with dice rolling, routing, critical hits, and so forth, Mêlée is different. There is no extensive paperwork and unit tracking round by round. There are no chits or markers to indicate wounded warriors or degraded units -- warriors are either alive and fighting, or are killed.

The game depicts small, medium, or large-sized battles, but focuses combat right down to the individual level. Its combat methodology is drawn from the actual experience of the designer (and play testers) in medieval reenactment battles, where an individual fighter is generally doing fine, fighting away, moving, charging to engage, and so forth, but then at some critical moment in the battle, quite suddenly, he or she gets out too much in front or ends up on the flank with opposing forces circling around.... Things happen quickly from there -- and WHAM, WHAM, WHACK, they're down. Mêlée captures that experience perfectly.

In Mêlée, to be defeated, an individual warrior almost universally is first overwhelmed and is simultaneously hit by multiple attacks at once. For instance, the warrior is attacked by a pole axe, two spears, a great sword, and someone with big mace hitting from the side, and, in that case, no amount of fancy footwork can save the day. Thus, the key to victory is to maneuver your forces and focus your attacks selectively, maintaining a mobile reserve and carefully planning when, where, and how to engage.

The game's combat methodology is easy to learn, quick to grasp, and fast to play. The rules are one sheet -- front and back -- and can be explained in a few minutes to almost anyone. Combat is resolved simply by comparing "Combat Values" on cards. Generally, if the Combat Values of the combined attacking cards add up to a value of TWICE the defending card's Combat Value, the defender is killed and removed from play. While simple in practice, skilled players find that there are multiple dimensions of complexity that result. A unique set of modifiers also are applied based on the four medieval elements -- Fire, Air, Earth, and Water -- as each of these represent combat styles that are chosen and employed in by each player during each combat round.

To win, either the majority of the opposing forces are defeated -- and the other side gives up, seeing no possible victory -- or the opposing side's banner is seized, which brings and early and glorious end to the battle.

Players may also make up their own victory conditions, such as escaping off the field with more than half of the remaining forces when the game is started with vastly unequal sides, or killing the opposing side's Commander, and so forth.

Scenario Packs and Add-On Expansion Card sets are also available, although the basic game provides extensive replayability as it is.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Grid Movement, Simulation, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: Takeover
description:
'Take Over' is a board game about gaining control of a company by building up a holding of the shares, and subsequently preventing other players from doing the same.

For up to 9 people - 8 players and a Chairman. With less than 8 players, the excess companies are removed from play and their squares on the board are covered over leaving only the companies in play.

The players take turns to roll a die and move a single counter around the board, the square the counter lands on affects all players in the game who has the shares in that company.

The board is similar to monopoly with the companies separated by general bonus or penalty squares that affect all players in the game.

When the counter passes the start the current round ends and the chairman invites bank investments or overdrafts, collects overdraft payments, and oversees the buying and selling of shares.

If at any time during the round, a player cannot pay all the penalties then he has to sell shares to the chairman for a fixed price. At the beginning of the next round all players can buy those shares also at a fixed price.

The game ends when 1 player has all 8 shares in 1 company, they get a £1000 bonus. All players then add up their holdings in shares and money the player with the largest holding wins.
publishers: Leslie Barnes Toys and Games Ltd.

name: Gob'z'Heroes: Legendary Pack
description:
Additional figures and their profile cards for Gob'z'Heroes:

Gob'nan - when you posses 3 combo cards, Gob'nan becomes accurate, lucky, and swift; but also unlucky and has a weak spot.

Gob'ius - starts with a shinny shield and can only be targeted by 1 rival gob' during each rival player turn. Gob'ius may only attack the rival player's gob'z that is was last targeted by.

Gob'zales - is accurate. Gob'zales can attempt a free, extra attack during movement. This attack is not accurate.
categories: Card Game, Dice, Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Fighting, Humor, Miniatures
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Hand Management

name: Gob'z'Heroes: Gang Pack Style
description:
Additional figures and their profile cards for Gob'z'Heroes:

Papa'gob - Starts with knuckles, rolls 2 dices when attacking the rival gob' with the highest charisma on the board.

Gob'barbosa - starts with wine barrel and trumpet gun, can have up to 3 stuff cards

Gob'croft - starts with twin pistols. At the beginning of your turn, roll a die for each rival gob' in line of sight. On a result of 6, you may immediately activate the rival gob' as if it was part of your crew.

Radioactiv'gob - is unlucky. Roll a die during your crew rehab phase - if you roll 1 to 3 Radioactive gob' is on. If you roll 4 to 6 radioactive gob' is off.
categories: Card Game, Dice, Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Fighting, Humor, Miniatures
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Hand Management

name: Puppers & Doggos
description:
Puppers & Doggos are pack animals. In groups, they live under the dominant rule of the alpha dawg—the supreme leader of them all. Yet, to survive and thrive, in a dangerous, unforgiving world, it necessitates the entire pack working together, as one. Such is the nature of puppers and doggos.

How To Play
Separate the "Alpha Dawg" cards and give one to each player, who is to set it face-up on the playing surface before him or her. This card is invincible and is the card all others shall be played around.

From the remaining deck, deal each player 5 cards and set it face down between all players. A single discard pile shall exist beside it. The player left of the dealer has first turn.

For each turn, a player draws up to six cards (the hand limit) and then must play one card into his or her "pack" by placing it in any of 8 possible slots around the "Alpha Dog" (above, below, to the sides, or any of the four corners) that are open.

When a card is played, the action written on the card must be completed (if possible), and is only valid for cards played from the player's hand. The turn ends once the card's action has been taken. Play continues clockwise.

If the deck exhausts, reuse the discard pile.

The first player to assemble a complete pack of 9 puppers and doggos, wins!

—description from the publisher

name: Tiny Cloud
description:
In Tiny Cloud, players are faeries who try to control a cloud.

This fast dexterity game is quite simple:
-The cloud is in the center of the table.
-Each player has 10 tokens (faeries).
-They will try to control the cloud by throwing their tokens on it.

At the end of the game (when all the tokens have been thrown), each faerie on the cloud will give one point to his owner. The player with most points is the winner of the game. If there is a draw, the two players win.

name: How to Become a Bug
description:
Как стать Жучиной (How to become a Bug) is about the best bug-scout academy graduates, who are trying to pass their final examination in a wilderness camp. Tutors set the difficult task for them: the young bug-scouts should search the wilderness and find the firewood for the alarm bonfires. The squad who lit their bonfire first would be the winners. The problem is while searching for the wood all the colourful bug-scouts got all abroad. And now every beetle claims about what bonfire should be lit first. To work out the winner fair and square bug-scouts settled the distinct rules of lightning the bonfires. Meanwhile the goal remains the same: whoever light his alarm bonfire is the winner!

The game consists of 6 decks consisting of the identical cards, but with different images on the back of the card, 6 "bonfire" cards representing goals and 30 small "ember" cards to count victory points. During game players place his or her cards in the shared stacks face down. When every player put 3 of his cards on the table, the stacks are revealed, and the bugs are counted to match certain color-combination printed on one of the "bonfire" cards. Whoever have this bonfire card gets victory points for the round. 3 kind of active cards affect other cards in its stack to add a strategic component to the game.

name: Monopoly: Fürth
description:
A monopoly (from Greek monos μόνος (alone or single) + polein πωλεῖν (to sell)) exists when a specific person or enterprise is the only supplier of a particular commodity.

Monopoly is a roll-and-move game where players move around the game board buying or trading properties, developing their properties with houses and hotels. When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.

The classic Monopoly with constructions and other elements of Fürth, in Germany
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading

name: Monopoly: Kaiserslautern
description:
A monopoly (from Greek monos μόνος (alone or single) + polein πωλεῖν (to sell)) exists when a specific person or enterprise is the only supplier of a particular commodity.

Monopoly is a roll-and-move game where players move around the game board buying or trading properties, developing their properties with houses and hotels. When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.

The classic Monopoly with constructions and other elements of Kaiserslautern, in Germany
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading

name: A Wrinkle In Time: A Daring Adventure Game
description:
A Wrinkle In Time: Daring Adventure Game is a cooperative dice game that captures the journey of the 2018 theatrical adaptation of the Madeline L'Engle novel.

In the game, players take on the role of the story's main characters — Meg, Charles Wallace and Calvin — and work together to solve mathematical puzzles, decode secret messages, and tesser to new locations to rescue Mr. Murry and get home. The engineering of a hexaflexagon is behind the "Flex Enfolders", which when used in conjunction with dice rolls must sum up to progress through five movie-based locations, or levels.

A coding portion of each round relies on players' abilities to communicate and lay out an "operation chain" that aims to generate a successful result, after which they will use the color filtration of Mrs. Who's "Quizzing Glasses" to reveal Mr. Murry's hidden whereabouts.
categories: Dice, Educational, Math, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Puzzle, Science Fiction
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Pattern Recognition, Storytelling

name: Cliques
description:
Cliques is the quick, fun card game in which you try to be the first to get rid of all your cards by collecting, and playing, same color groups of cute, quirky characters!

How To Play
Shuffle the deck and deal all players 10 cards. Set the remaining deck face down, which shall have a single discard pile beside it. The player left of the dealer takes the first turn.

For every turn, the player shall draw 1 card (from the deck or the discard pile), and conclude it by discarding 1 card. Prior to discard, the player may set down 3 cards of the same color, face-up on the playing surface, as a "clique." Any player may also add 2 more cards of the same color to any clique of 3 to increase it to 5. Cliques may only ever be a total of 3 or 5 cards. Only 1 clique of each color is permitted. Any number of cliques may be created, or added to, during a turn. Play moves clockwise. Ninjas can join any clique to finish it. Zombies are played singularly on any clique to eat it, remove it from play and send 1 card of that clique into the hand of the opponent of the player's choice.

When any player discards all cards, or the game deck is exhausted, the hand is over. Players score 1 point for each card they still hold.

The player with the least points, wins!

—description from the publisher

name: Gem Quest
description:
Gem Quest is the fun and simple card game in which you try to be the first to buy and collect sets of matching jewels, while attempting to stop your opponents from doing the same!

How To Play
Shuffle the deck and deal all players 5 cards. If a player gets an "Action" card, it must be traded in for a replacement. Blindly insert said action card back into the deck. Set the deck face down between all players, which shall have a discard pile beside it.
The player left of the dealer takes the first turn.

For each turn, the player flips the deck's top card onto the discard pile. If it's an Action card, take the action (if possible). If it's a coin, the player takes it in to hand. If it's a gem, the player may put coins equal (or greater) to its value on the discard pile to buy it into hand. If the player cannot afford (or doesn't want) the gem, remove it to a field of cards on the playing surface (the Gem Store), from which gems may be bought during one's turn by paying coins to the discard pile. Change is not given.

When a pair of the same gem is collected, it must be set down for all to see. A third of that gem may be added to make a trio. The diamond counts as a pair or trio by itself. Play moves clockwise. If the deck exhausts, reuse the discard pile.

The first to get 3 pairs, or 2 trios, of gems, wins!

name: Card C-Quence
description:
Card C-Quence is a light family speed game. It consists of a deck of 144 cards and a game board. This game is unique in that it only contains Hearts, Spades, and wild cards.

The deck is shuffled and each player is dealt 20 cards face down. Players stack them in order without looking at them to form their "stockpile". The Top card of the stock pile is turned face up.

Each player is then dealt an additional 5 cards which form their hand. The remainder of the cards are placed in the center spot on the game board. The other 4 spots on the board are for community piles 2 for hearts and 2 for spades. The player to the left of the dealer goes first.

On your turn you may play any number and combination of cards from your hand, stockpile, or discard pile to their respective community spaces on the board. Wild cards may be played in place of any card in matching suit. Community piles must start with the number 1 and build consecutively to the number 5.

Once a pile is completed place it to the side and start a new one. If you run out of cards in your hand immediately draw back up to 5. When you play the top card of your stockpile turn up the next card. You may play a card as long as you have one available to play or until you choose to stop playing cards.

Each player also has their own separate discard piles one for hearts and one for spades. To end your turn you must discard one card to its respective discard pile. Play continues with then next player in a clockwise fashion.

At the beginning of your turn draw back up to 5 cards. If the draw pile runs out shuffle the completed community piles to form a new draw pile and place it in the center of the board. The first player to exhaust their stock pile scores 0 points. The other players score 1 point for each card left in their stockpile. When a player reaches 30 points the game ends. The player with the lowest score wins.

The game may also be played in teams and requires 4 players. All rules remain the same except during you turn you may play from your partners stockpile and discard piles. You may not play from your partners hand. play continues until both players on the same team exhaust their stockpiles. Scores are kept by teams and not by individuals by adding the number of cards/points from both stockpiles.

Card C-Quence is a perfect mix of strategy and luck. Be the first to exhaust your stockpile and maintain the lowest score.
mechanics: Simultaneous Action Selection, Take That, Team-Based Game

name: Face Off Duels
description:
Ever since we saw our first ninja movies in the 80's we’ve all been wondering –Cowboys or Ninjas? On the one hand Cowboys have their trusty six shooters and faithful horses to help them. On the other hand, Ninja are well versed in the dark arts, possess secret knowledge and skills, and have no qualms about murdering you in your sleep if they think they might lose the show down at sun down.

In Face Off Duels you are installed as the leader of one of these mighty factions and over three rounds of tactical combat you get to figure out which group, which leader, is the greatest of all time.

What separates Face Off Duels from other fighting card games is a unique scoring system that forces players to not only play their opponent, but the board as well. The result is a quick game that, like a great puzzle, you will want to return to again and again. The Face Off scoring system plus the magical whimsy that is the Power Deck means no two games of Face Off Duels are the same.

Face Off Duels present you with multiple paths to victory, a myriad of strategic options, and a sense of humor that is way more engaging than this blurb. In order to win, you must be able to plan ahead, bluff when appropriate, and occasionally pull that one card off the top of the deck. If you can do all these (and add seven plus five in your head) you just might be able to lead your chosen faction to glory.
mechanics: Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Hand Management

name: Halali
description:
Halali is a hunting/catching themed game from Swedish publisher Aristospel, in which the players tries to shoot or catch four (out of ten) domestic and/or international animals. According to the rules the game is intended for 4 or 5 players, but it is quite possible to be 2 or 3.

This is a fairly simple roll-and-go dice game. On each single track one animal is possible to shoot or catch with the help of the dice. If successful - that is if the dice rolls exactly the numbers needed - the hunter is awarded an animal card with varying victory points. Whoever manages to collect the most points wins.

Since alla players is supposed to go on the same animal in the same order, animal for animal, it is teorethically possible that player one shoots all four selected animals and thereby win even before player two (not to mention players three, four or five!) has had a go.

The animals and their value: Tiger (100), Elephant (75), Lion (50), Rhino (50), Capercaillie (40), Bear (30), Owl (30), Hyena (20), Crocodile (5) and Chimpanzee (5).

This game would probably be seen as politically incorrect nowadays and impossible to publish.

—user summary
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: No Thumbs Challenge
description: No Thumbs Challenge is the hilarious game that calls for fast-moving teamwork creative thinking and maximum dexterity as you and your team members try to execute simple tasks without the use of your thumbs! Using thumb straps, players “attach” their thumbs to their palms and then try to perform tasks like opening a water bottle, applying lip balm, or tying a tie.

name: Forests: Timber! (fan expansion for Carcassonne)
description:
Adds wood trade goods on Forest tiles.

Approved by carcassonnecentral and carcassonne-forum
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Fan Expansion, Medieval

name: In the Stocks (fan expansion for Carcassonne)
description:
When a player draws a tile with stocks he must play it to an existing city. The player is free to deploy his follower to the city or he may place a follower into the stocks. A player is not obligated either to deploy a follower to the city or detain a follower in the stocks. If the tile cannot be played, it is removed from the game and a new tile drawn to replace it.

Approved by carcassonnecentral and carcassonne-forum
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Fan Expansion, Medieval

name: Bill of Health
description:
Bill of Health is the captivating medical care strategy game for three to five players. Players must set prices low to attract patients, while still being able to afford care of their patients over the patients’ lifetimes — no matter what happens.

Compete with other health care providers to increase revenue and finance improvements in quality. Should you invest in quick fixes or in better systems and training? Bid wisely, invest strategically, and make care the best it can be or the next bill will be yours!

—description from the publisher

name: You Can't Win
description:
After the heist, there’s always room for an argument – an argument about who gets the least, who gets the most, who gets enough.

You Can’t Win is a player-versus-player trick-taking rule-making game. Each round, you’ll try and lay out a rule for the rest of the game, you’ll see if that rule sticks, then see if your final card is one of the few cards that has a chance.

And maybe you’ll find you just can’t win.

But maybe you can make sure someone else can’t win, too.





You Can’t Win comes with twenty cards and two facing cards for the deck to keep things looking nice.

You Can’t Win requires very little table area, and players will need to be able to read or handle one another’s cards, so being able to reach a common area is important. It does require some reading, but not much math. The game’s in a single shared deck that only needs to be shuffled once per game, and nobody needs anything to track the game’s points.

—description from the publisher

name: その男、班文虎 (That Man, Going Halfsies)
description:
At the end of the century, we brothers are suffering from food shortages and have decided to live by eating only sweets — but sweets are limited as well, so let's make the best of it by going halfsies. Can we do that? With me possibly getting slightly more than half? After all, when the mountain of sweets has run out, whoever has the most sweets wins!
